name: A1 Meats
description: A-1 Meats was a wheel company that started in the late 1980s and was backed by Tracker Trucks. A-1 Meats made a little noise with the release of multiple early 90s videos, but was forced to throw in the towel around 1995. A-1 Meats team riders included Matt Hensley, Kris Markovich, Bo Ikeda, Laban Pheidias, Jeff King, Robert Douglas, Adrian Demain, Anthony Oglesby, John Sonner, Jason Dill, Chuck Wampler, Bo Ikeda, and Brandon Carabajal to name a few.

name: Death Box Skateboards
description: Death Box was founded by Jeremy Fox in 1987 and was Europe's number one skate brand during it's existence. The name Death Box related to the term used for the swimming pool overflow channel and was originally aimed toward old school backyard pool skaters. Death Box also had a sister company named Bash which eventually evolved into Flip Skateboards. In 1993, Death Box merged with Flip and shortly after relocated to the USA.

name: Carveboard
description: Brad Gerlach and his father Joe came up with the idea for Carveboard in the late 1990s. The main objective was to create a board which enabled beginners to pros, the ability to work on their surfing or snowboarding when the snow melts or the surf is flat.

name: Bizo Shoes
description: Bizo was a completely random shoe companies that operated in the late 1990s. Their shoe silhouette's were pretty hideous and never saw or heard of any shops carrying them, so it's kind of a mystery how they lasted as long as they did. Bizo even went as far as to offer a free deck with shoe purchase and 6 month warranty, but nothing seemed to help create a demand. Bizo team riders included Ozzy Alvarez, Steve James, Leonard Crowley, Casper Friedl, Szabolcs Ocsai and Benjamin Bohaner.

name: Adrenalin Skateboards
description: Adrenalin Skateboards was founded by Jaya Bonderov and Chris Senn in 1995, but in 1997 the two felt they were being ripped off by the financial backer and canned the brand. In 2000, Mike Manzoori, Taos, Jon Minor and Chris Senn started Adrenalin back up on their own, but after Chris Senn quit the brand in 2004 it was scrapped shortly thereafter.

name: Billabong
description: Billabong was founded on Australia's Gold Coast in 1973 by surfer and surfboard shaper Gordon Merchant and his partner. The business found immediate traction, with surfers drawn to the superior functionality of the Billabong boardshorts. In the 1990s, the company followed its core customers into other boardsports markets, including skate and snow, where it replicated its proven business model.

name: Almost Skateboards
description: Daewon Song and Rodney Mullen formed Almost Skateboards in 2003 after Deca folded and Rodney left enjoi. Their vision with Almost was to put the fun back into skateboarding while simultaneously pushing the boundaries of board construction. In 2004, Almost released their Round 3 video which was the third installment in the Rodney Mullen vs Daewon Song video series, and the first in which the two rode for the same team.

name: Adidas Skateboarding
description: Adidas was formed back in August of 1949 as the manufacturer of athletic footwear and apparel. Over the years, Adidas has grown to encompass all major sports and by the mid 1990s introduced a line of skateboard footwear with a diverse group of team riders. This original skate division lasted into the early 2000s, but was re-booted in the mid 2000s under the name Adidas Skateboarding with a condensed team consisting of Mark Gonzales, Tim O'Connor and Dennis Busenitz.

name: 411VM
description: 411 Video Magazine was founded by skateboarder/videographer Josh Friedberg and Steve Douglas as skateboarding's first ever video magazine. With segments which included branded industry spotlights, metrospective's, spot checks, contest highlights, amateur/pro sections, and more, this quarterly and later bi-monthly video magazine became an instant hit and forever changed the landscape of skateboard video formats.

name: Birdhouse Skateboards
description: In 1992, Tony Hawk left Powell Peralta to start Birdhouse Projects with friend and ex-Powell pro Per Welinder. Birdhouse turned out their fair share of classic videos through the 1990s, with their crown jewel coming in the form of 98s The End video. The End was the first skate video to be filmed primarily on film rather than digital tapes, and significantly raised the bar for video production. In 2008, Tony Hawk acquired controlling interest in the company and moved it's distribution from Blitz to Eastern Skateboard Supply, and then again to Syndrome near the end of 2010.

name: Emergency Skateboards
description: Emergency Skateboards was founded by John Lucero as a veterans division of Black Label Skateboards. Emergency originally started under the name Red Kross in 2002, but after receiving multiple Cease & Desist letters from the Geneva Convention, was forced to change it's name to Emergency to avoid further litigation. Emergency offers a variety of larger shape decks for the older guys who are trying to keep it moving.

name: Black Box Distribution
description: Black Box Distribution was founded in 2000 by Jamie Thomas in order to independently house and distribute Zero Skateboards. In the fall of 2003, Black Box launched Mystery Skateboards and shortly after integrated Fallen Footwear, $lave Skateboards, Insight Clothing, Destroyer Pads and Mouse Grip. The goal of Black Box is to efficiently create, market and distribute quality skate products while supporting skateboarding on every level.

name: DGK
description: DGK Skateboards was founded by Stevie Williams in 2002 after parting ways with Chocolate. DGK is an acronym for Dirty Ghetto Kids, which was the name of Stevie's skate crew growing up in Philadelphia. In 2004, Stevie entered into a contract with Reebok which included the licensing of DGK shoes and clothing, but lasted no more than a couple years. Today, DGK continues to produce quality decks, apparel and accessories under the umbrella of The Kayo Corp.

name: Nash Skateboards
description: Nash Manufacturing first started as a water ski company, but in the 1960s introduced hardwood skateboards once sidewalk surfing began to grow in popularity. Nash Skateboards really took off during the 1980s skateboard boom by offering an extensive line of price-point completes with all the plastic bells and whistles of the time. These boards and component parts were total garbage but were readily available and served as a entry level skateboard for the masses.

name: Listen Skateboards
description: Listen Skateboards was founded by Danny Montoya and Rob Gonzalez in the early to mid 2000s. The two longtime friends ran Listen out of Montoya's back house for years before taking the brand to Syndrome in 2010, where it was tweaked and re-launched as BLVD Skateboards. Listen pros included Rob Gonzalez, Danny Montoya, Rodrigo Peterson and Brian Brown in addition to a solid team of technical amateurs.

name: NSA
description: NSA was a acronym for the National Skateboard Association. The NSA was founded by Frank Hawk in the mid 1980s as a professional counterpart to the California Amateur Skateboard League(CASL). Throughout the 1980s to early 1990s, contests were king and NSA played host to the majority of these high-profile events. But as contests became less and less important, the association began to struggle and eventually called it quits.

name: Mad Circle Skateboards
description: Mad Circle was started by Steve Douglas in around 1993 as a sub division of New Deal. Mad Circle was headed creatively by Justin Girard, and released two classic videos in Let The Horns Blow and 5ive Flavors, but had it's plug pulled by Giant Distribution around 1999. Mad Circle team riders included Mike Cao, Scott Johnston, Rob Welsh, Cairo Foster, Bobby Puleo, Tas Pappas and Karl Watson to name a few.

name: Mada Clothing
description: Mada Clothing was started in 2004 by Vince De La Pena and Shane La Voie after leaving Ezekiel, a brand in which they both founded in the early 90's. With Vince and Shane being Christian in faith, the name Mada came from the backwards spelling of Adam. Mada was meant to be a bit edgier, along the lines of Volcom, but to not be over distributed like most brands within the surf and lifestyle industry. Mada's foundation was built on using only the best fabrics and fits, but ended up calling it quits around 2008.

name: Mack Dawg Productions
description: Mack Dawg Productions was formed by Mike McEntire in 1988 as a skateboard video production company. MDP's first production was the video Sick Boys and was seen as one of the most revolutionary videos of it's time. Soon after, McEntire was contacted to help produce the H-Street video Hokus Pokus with the late Mike Ternasky. After that, Mack Dawg Productions shifted its focus to the documentation of snowboarding where it has remained since 1990.

name: Monkey Business
description: Monkey Business was founded as a hardware & grip tape company around the year 2000. The company saw early success through their Monkey Grip line of grip tape in which each rider was given a signature monkey silhouette die-cut logo. In addition to Monkey Grip, Monkey Nuts hardware, Monkey Balls bearings, and Monkey Poop wax, the company also went on to launch a short lived deck division under the name Monkey Stix.

name: Monster Trucks
description: Monster Trucks was a short lived brand that launched out of Giant Distribution toward the end of 2000. Around this time, Giant was trying to capitalize on the success they saw with Destructo and introduced both Monster and Destroyer truck brands. Monster was marketed as a more durable truck with specifically designed bushing seats to prevent bushing blowouts, but was scrapped after falling short in sales.

name: Race Wheels

name: Plan B Skateboards
description: Plan B Skateboards was founded by Mike Ternasky in 1991 under the distribution of World Industries. And by 1992, had cemented itself in skate history with the release of Questionable, the first of many groundbreaking Plan B videos. Ternasky owned and operated Plan B until 1994 when he was killed in a car accident. Danny Way and Colin McKay continued with the company after Mike's death but eventually called it quits in 1998. Then in 2005, Danny and Colin revived Plan B through Syndrome Distribution but have since taken it independently.

name: Motto Grip Tape
description: Motto Grip Tape was started in 2003 as a community based design grip tape company. How this works is, independent artists can submit design ideas which are then evaluated by Motto's skate team and the broader Motto community for conversion into laser cut or printed skateboard grip tape. If an artists design is chosen, they will then receive royalties or can choose to have a percentage of design sales go to a non-profit organization.

name: Mystery Skateboards
description: Mystery Skateboards was started by Black Box Dist. in the fall of 2003 as a sister company to Zero. Mystery was originally supposed to be Matt Mumford's company, but when that didn't work out, the company was pitched to Adrian Lopez. For years, Mystery had a black & white theme that played through their graphics, ads, and video, but in 2010 introduced color to the company. In 2014, as Black Box began to dissolve, Adrian Lopez decided to take Mystery on his own and operate it independently.

name: Molotov Skateboards
description: Molotov was a deck brand out of Minneapolis, MN. that was founded by brothers Matt & Andy Schansberg in 1989. The brand was heavily art driven through simple graphics, ads and zines, and gained instant local support. Molotov had a few fake pro's whose names were picked out of the phone book, but also housed some legit talent including Jahmal Williams, Mike Graham and Darren Navarrette. In 1993, Molotov relocated to California where they joined up with Small Room, but once Small Room folded in '94, Molotov wasn't far behind.

name: Life Skateboards

name: Nike SB
description: Nike Skateboarding was launched in 2002 with an initial team of Richard Mulder, Danny Supa, Reese Forbes, and Gino Iannucci. The idea behind Nike SB was to produce limited edition colorways with creative stories behind the shoes. The idea worked, and got sneaker collectors clamoring, and every other shoe company mimicking limited edition colorways. Today, Nike SB still manufacturers limited edition colorways in addition to a full line of footwear, apparel and accessories.

name: Maple Skateboards
description: Maple Skateboards was started in 1994 by Charlie Watson of Watson Wood Shop and ex-& team manager Chris Capparo. Maple turned out more than a few amazing videos over the years and launched many a career but eventually went under as riders began leaving and competition increased. The original Maple team consisted of Marc Johnson, Thom Hornung, Joe McClellan, Chad Muska, Paul Smith and Nick Bell, plus Kien Lieu and Jason Carney who both left Planet Earth to help launch Maple. Ed Dominick was the brand's staff photographer which also helped in landing Maple's riders on the pages of countless Transworld's.

name: Poweredge Magazine

name: Santa Monica Airlines
description: Santa Monica Airlines was started by Skip Engblom in 1978 out of the back of he & Jeff Ho's Zephyr surf shop. Skip was a gifted surfboard shaper and originally shaped all of Santa Monica Airlines' skateboards by hand. In 1988, Skip convinced and helped Steve Rocco start SMA Rocco Division which later became World Industries. Around 1989, Skip moved Santa Monica Airlines to NHS where it got overhauled and shortened it's name to simply SMA. NHS eventually pulled the plug on SMA around 1993, at which point most the team got absorbed into other NHS brands. Today, Skip is back to doing the brand on his own and offers amazing hand stained wood decks in a variety of shapes and sizes.

Team Pain is comprised of skaters who possess extensive design and build knowledge gleaned from years of personal experience. This knowledge allows them to create skate structures that inspire a skater to constantly improve his or her skills.

name: Revenge Trucks
description: Revenge longboard trucks are a revolution in torsion skateboard truck technology which allow longboard skateboards to perform like surf and snowboards. Revenge trucks perform turns not previously possible on any type of deck.

raw_data.name: Revenge Trucks
raw_data.description: Revenge longboard trucks are a revolution in torsion skateboard truck technology which allow longboard skateboards to perform like surf and snowboards. Revenge trucks perform turns not previously possible on any type of deck.

name: Shuvit
description: Shuvit was a clothing and deck company that started as a division of Vision Skateboards. Shuvit ran from the 1990s to early 2000s with team riders that included Chris Gentry, Mad Dog, Jamie Smith, Donovan Dresti, Ave Bunachita, Nate McGlone and Jean-Louis Besancon.

raw_data.name: Shuvit
raw_data.description: Shuvit was a clothing and deck company that started as a division of Vision Skateboards. Shuvit ran from the 1990s to early 2000s with team riders that included Chris Gentry, Mad Dog, Jamie Smith, Donovan Dresti, Ave Bunachita, Nate McGlone and Jean-Louis Besancon.

name: Tech Deck
description: Tech Deck was founded in the 1990s at the beginning of the fingerboard craze and quickly became the leading manufacturer of fingerboard skateboards and accessories. Tech Deck skateboards come equipped with metal trucks, grip tape and real skate company graphics and can be found everywhere from toy stores to grocery stores worldwide. Tech Deck also produced fingerboards for other action sports including surfing, snowboarding and bmx.

raw_data.name: Tech Deck
raw_data.description: Tech Deck was founded in the 1990s at the beginning of the fingerboard craze and quickly became the leading manufacturer of fingerboard skateboards and accessories. Tech Deck skateboards come equipped with metal trucks, grip tape and real skate company graphics and can be found everywhere from toy stores to grocery stores worldwide. Tech Deck also produced fingerboards for other action sports including surfing, snowboarding and bmx.

name: SoBe
description: SoBe is a line of Elixirs and Tea and Elixir beverages with unique flavor concoctions and herbal ingredients.

raw_data.name: SoBe
raw_data.description: SoBe is a line of Elixirs and Tea and Elixir beverages with unique flavor concoctions and herbal ingredients.

name: Sheep Shoes
description: Sheep was a playful shoe company founded in 1996 by Sole Technology, the makers of Etnies and eS Footwear. Sheep was geared more toward price points and with an initial team of Ed Templeton, Laban Pheidias and Mike Manzoori found an instant following. And by utilizing synthetic materials, Sheep also discovered the untapped vegan friendly skate shoe market. But due to importing costs, Sheep shoes weren't as cheap as originally intended and therefore the brand was discontinued.

raw_data.name: Sheep Shoes

Sheep was geared more toward price points and with an initial team of Ed Templeton, Laban Pheidias and Mike Manzoori found an instant following. And by utilizing synthetic materials, Sheep also discovered the untapped vegan friendly skate shoe market. But due to importing costs, Sheep shoes weren't as cheap as originally intended and therefore the brand was discontinued.

name: Steadham Designs
description: Steadham Designs, also known as Team Steadham was a deck company started by Steve Steadham in late 1985 after leaving Powell Peralta. Steadham Designs was managed by Steve but was backed by Sure Grip International. The Steadham team included Steve Steadham, Otis Christian, Nate Cavazo, Matt Davis, Dave Hoffman, Jake Piasecki and Dave Messick.

raw_data.name: Steadham Designs
raw_data.description: Steadham Designs, also known as Team Steadham was a deck company started by Steve Steadham in late 1985 after leaving Powell Peralta. Steadham Designs was managed by Steve but was backed by Sure Grip International. The Steadham team included Steve Steadham, Otis Christian, Nate Cavazo, Matt Davis, Dave Hoffman, Jake Piasecki and Dave Messick.

name: Seismic Trucks
description: Founded in 1993 by Daniel Gesmer, Seismic Skate Systems designs and manufactures high-performance boards, wheels and trucks for carving, cruising, racing, and beyond. Seismic's patented spring-loaded truck technology delivers advanced control and superior rebound with precise turning response.

raw_data.name: Seismic Trucks
raw_data.description: Founded in 1993 by Daniel Gesmer, Seismic Skate Systems designs and manufactures high-performance boards, wheels and trucks for carving, cruising, racing, and beyond. Seismic's patented spring-loaded truck technology delivers advanced control and superior rebound with precise turning response.

name: High Grade Distribution
description: High Grade Distribution was created in 2004 as the distribution home for Creation Skateboards, Satori Wheels, Upful Hardware, Paradox Grip, Red I Eyewear and the now defunct Yellow Brand Skateboards. The goal of High Grade Distribution is to produce the highest quality products for eco-conscious consumers.

raw_data.name: High Grade Distribution
raw_data.description: High Grade Distribution was created in 2004 as the distribution home for Creation Skateboards, Satori Wheels, Upful Hardware, Paradox Grip, Red I Eyewear and the now defunct Yellow Brand Skateboards. The goal of High Grade Distribution is to produce the highest quality products for eco-conscious consumers.

name: SuperCush Bushings
description: SuperCush is a bushing company that has been operating out of Deluxe Distribution since the 1980's.

raw_data.name: SuperCush Bushings
raw_data.description: SuperCush is a bushing company that has been operating out of Deluxe Distribution since the 1980's.

name: Grizzly Grip
description: Torey Pudwill first started making Grizzly Griptape in 2001 by stamping out the Bear Logo for himself and local friends. This was a short lived endeavor, but in 2010 Torey teamed up with Diamond Supply Co. to handle the production and distribution of Grizzly Griptape, in addition to a full line of Grizzly Griptape apparel & accessories.

raw_data.name: Grizzly Grip
raw_data.description: Torey Pudwill first started making Grizzly Griptape in 2001 by stamping out the Bear Logo for himself and local friends. This was a short lived endeavor, but in 2010 Torey teamed up with Diamond Supply Co. to handle the production and distribution of Grizzly Griptape, in addition to a full line of Grizzly Griptape apparel & accessories.

name: Incase
description: Incase Designs was founded in 1997 by four longtime friends as a carrying solution for today's technology driven lifestyle. If you're the owner of an Apple product, chances are Incase has a functional case to help you protect it. Incase created the first iPod case for Apple, and today Incase products are available in nearly all of Apple's retail stores. Incase is also the manufacturer of quality guitar cases.

raw_data.name: Incase
raw_data.description: Incase Designs was founded in 1997 by four longtime friends as a carrying solution for today's technology driven lifestyle. If you're the owner of an Apple product, chances are Incase has a functional case to help you protect it. Incase created the first iPod case for Apple, and today Incase products are available in nearly all of Apple's retail stores. Incase is also the manufacturer of quality guitar cases.

name: Unit
description: Unit Trucks was started in the mid 1990s in hopes of offering a more lightweight truck design. Unit most notably produced the Phantom style truck which eventually became it's own brand, and introduced the ever so popular Unit Skateboard Tool. Today, Unit has ceased truck production, but continues to manufacture the Unit Skateboard Tool in a variety of colors.

raw_data.name: Unit
raw_data.description: Unit Trucks was started in the mid 1990s in hopes of offering a more lightweight truck design. Unit most notably produced the Phantom style truck which eventually became it's own brand, and introduced the ever so popular Unit Skateboard Tool. Today, Unit has ceased truck production, but continues to manufacture the Unit Skateboard Tool in a variety of colors.

name: Killing Machine
description: Killing Machine was a skateboard hardware company that seemed geared more toward transition or more raw type skaters. A few of Killing Machine's riders included Jason Adams, Chet Childress, Bam Margera, Alan Petersen, Chris Senn, Eric J, Tino Razo, Nate Jones, Aaron Suski, Chad Bartie, Patrick Melcher, Dorian Tucker, and Kristian Svitak.

raw_data.name: Killing Machine
raw_data.description: Killing Machine was a skateboard hardware company that seemed geared more toward transition or more raw type skaters. A few of Killing Machine's riders included Jason Adams, Chet Childress, Bam Margera, Alan Petersen, Chris Senn, Eric J, Tino Razo, Nate Jones, Aaron Suski, Chad Bartie, Patrick Melcher, Dorian Tucker, and Kristian Svitak.

name: Big Black Clothing
description: Big Black Clothing was a brand founded by Christopher "Big Black" Boykin in the early 2000s. The brand saw unbelievable success through repeated exposure on MTV's Rob & Big reality show in which the highly likable "Big Black" usually wore the company tees and hats. After Rob & Big went off the air, Big Black began to focus more energy on the brand, and there were even talks of a Big Black footwear line but don't believe anything ever materialized.

name: Anti Hero Skateboards
description: Anti-Hero Skateboards was started by Julien Stranger in 1995 when Deluxe offered him his own company. After a short lived pirate theme, Anti-Hero cemented it's identity behind Todd Francis's eagle and pigeon logos. With a ragtag team and graphics which often poke fun at politics and society as a whole, there are no fucks given.

name: Aerial Wheels
description: Aerial was a wheel brand that was founded and co-owned by Kareem Campbell and Guy Mariano. Started in 2000, Aerial was distributed through Kareem's then newly formed KSL Distribution. Unfortunately, Aerial never really caught on for whatever reason and was scrapped not long after it was started.

name: Black Flys
description: Black Flys was founded in 1991 in Orange County, California as an eyewear brand geared toward the youth culture of the early 1990s. With roots in the surf, snow and skate communities, Black Flys has created a following that epitomizes their idea of the Southern California lifestyle. If you've got a raised pickup truck, goatee, tribal tattoo or stripper girlfriend, chances are that Black Flys has got a style of shades just for you.

name: 60/40 Skateboards
description: 60/40 Skateboards was started by Mark Gonzales after parting ways with his newly formed ATM Click. Mark built up 60/40 with a little help from Ron Chatman who continued to guide the brand after Mark's departure in 1996. Other 60/40 riders included Jay Stephens, Gino Perez, George Morales, Steven Cales, Florentine Marfaing, John Deago and Doug Diaz to name a few.

name: Anex Trucks
description: Anex was a truck company that was founded by Chet Thomas and Gailea Momolu in the mid 2000s. Anex Trucks had a Grind King style kingpin, and were designed to be light, stable and responsive. A few Anex team riders included Chet Thomas, Gailea Momolu, Jesse Landen and Pierre Luc Gagnon.

name: 303 Boards
description: 303 Boards has been holding down the Colorado skate scene since 1997. 303 is an independently owned and independently minded skate shop.

name: Beloe Footwear
description: Beloe Footwear was a Southern California based shoe company that was founded by Ethan Fowler, Austin Stephens and artist Russ Pope in 2007. Beloe focused on thoughtfully designed products and artist collaborations, but ended abruptly in 2008. Beloe team riders included Ethan Fowler, Austin Stephens and Cooper Wilt on the skate side, and had a BMX division as well.

name: Baker Skateboards
description: Baker Skateboards was founded by Andrew Reynolds and Birdhouse team manager J. Strickland in the year 2000. J. Strickland was the brand manager and marketing genius behind the brand, but left Baker in 2001 to start the now defunct Bootleg Skateboards. Baker is one of skateboarding's last no-nonsense brands and is 100% committed to skateboarding and nothing more. In late 2011, Baker bought out their partnership with Blitz Distribution and relocated the brand to Baker Boys Distribution.

name: Almost Skateboards
description: Daewon Song and Rodney Mullen formed Almost Skateboards in 2003 after Deca folded and Rodney left enjoi. Their vision with Almost was to put the fun back into skateboarding while simultaneously pushing the boundaries of board construction. In 2004, Almost released their Round 3 video which was the third installment in the Rodney Mullen vs Daewon Song video series, and the first in which the two rode for the same team.

name: Chapter 7 Skateboards
description: Chapter 7 was a deck and clothing company that was started by Mike McGill in the early 1990s. Chapter 7 team riders grew to include Mike McGill, Malcolm Watson, Kanten Russell, Peter Smolik, Oscar Jordan, Matt Rodriguez, Peter McBride, Rich Colwell, and Jeff Toland, but was forced to call it quits in the mid 1990s.

name: Dragon Sunglasses
description: In 1993, Will Howard founded Dragon Sunglasses as an independent eyewear and accessories brand for the surf, skate and dirt bike riding communities of the time. Dragon eventually added snowboard goggles to it's line of products and quickly established itself as a leader in the goggle business. More recently, Dragon developed and introduced the ECO(Environmentally Conscious Optics) series, which include the first-ever sunglasses and goggles made from 100% renewable origins.

name: IPath Footwear
description: Ipath Footwear was started in 1999 as a humbly green brand that promoted environmental sustainability for the benefit of present and future generations of skateboarders. Since it's beginning, Ipath carved out a niche for itself by offering alternative materials such as hemp, organic cotton, and other sustainable materials to it's customers. But Ipath took a turn for the worse in 2007 when it was sold to mainstream footwear giant Timberland, and then again to Klone Lab(the licensing house of New Balance) in 2011.

name: ON Video
description: ON Video was created by Kirk Dianda of 411VM after feeling skate videos lacked the element of storytelling. ON Video premiered in the Summer of 2000 and became skateboarding's first documentary format video magazine with featured segments on current and previous skaters, era's and spots. ON Video produced 11 videos in total, with the last being their Winter 2004 issue.

name: Torque Skateboards
description: Torque Skateboards was an Atlanta, Georgia based brand that was formed in 1997 by professional skateboarder Thomas Taylor. Torque riders included Thomas Taylor, John Montesi, Stormy Pruett, Brian Chung, Graham Bickerstaff and Thomas' young son Grant Taylor amongst others but eventually called it quits in 2001. Thomas Taylor went on to later start Stratosphere skate shop which still operates today and is considered Atlanta's premiere skate shop.

name: Transworld Skateboarding
description: Transworld Skateboarding was founded in 1983 under the ownership of Larry Balma and Peggy Cozens. At the time, Balma and Cozens saw Thrasher Magazine's content as being unsuitable for young kids and created Transworld Skateboarding Magazine in response. In around 1994, Transworld also began producing videos and by the end of the 1990s was a leader in video production quality and editing. Today, Transworld still produces videos & magazines as well as operating skateboarding.com as it's online news, photo and video hub.

name: Vehicle Skateboards
description: Vehicle Skateboards was founded by Robbie Gangemi, Giovanni Estevez, and Jamie Story in 2000. With an all East Coast team, Vehicle hoped to embody their roots of street skating, and inner city street culture. Gangemi also started Boston based wood shop Pop Master Wood to manufacture all of Vehicle's decks, and in 2010 developed a way of producing maple decks with 100% recycled wood.

name: Vivo Headwear
description:
Vivo Headwear is rider driven, rider owned, and artist inspired
headwear brand based out of Canada. Vivo brings together a unique collection of timeless designs with a boutique approach and feel. Vivo comes from the Spanish vocabulary and stands for I Live. Vivo supports a talented crew of skate and snow riders including Wade Desarmo, Mark Appleyard, Spencer Hamilton, Paul Trep, Grant Patterson and Ronnie Creager amongst others.

name: TSA Clothing
description: TSA Clothing was a '90s clothing brand that was co-founded by Angel Cabada.

name: Rasa Libre Skateboards
description: Rasa Libre Skateboards was founded by Matt Field in 2003 out of Deluxe Distribution. The original Rasa Libre team consisted of Matt Field, Nate Jones & Reese Forbes, and was infused with the cosmic art direction of Michael Leon. Somewhere along the way, Rasa Libre left the Deluxe camp and eventually disappeared, but got a second life in 2006 with an updated team. Today, Matt Field is still behind the wheel at Rasa Libre where he continues to promote the meaning behind the name, which is The Essence of Freedom.

name: Prime Skateboards
description: Prime Skateboards was formed by Mark Oblow and Kris Markovich in 1993 after Color Skateboards dissolved. Kris brought a few Color team riders with him in the process and with the brand being backed by World Industries ran into the late 1990s. Prime was also the name of the wood shop which developed and manufactured all of World Industries' shapes in the 1990s before Dwindle moved it's deck production to China in the early 2000s.

name: Tunnel Wheels
description: Tunnel Skateboards and wheels was founded in 1975 by California surfer Mitch Haake. Mitch grew up in San Francisco and his love for skateboarding started when he made his own skateboard with metal wheels nailed to a 2 by 4.

name: S-One Technology
description: S-One was founded around 1998 as the manufacturer of skateboard specific insoles which helped reduce the painful impact associated with skateboarding. But what started with insoles quickly grew to include helmets, ankle braces and wrist guards. Today, S-One focuses solely on the production of professional grade skateboard helmets for every type of skateboarding, size and age group.

name: Real Skateboards
description: Real Skateboards is a San Francisco based company that was founded by Tommy Guerrero and Jim Thiebaud in 1990. Real was started under Fausto Vitello's Deluxe empire where it still operates today.

name: Physics Wheels
description: Physics Wheel Concepts was founded by skater Mark Hostetter in the mid 1990s. Mark brought in Frank Hirata to help establish the team and overall company direction along with Nanda Zipp. Physics produced a quality line of wheels and was constantly pushing new designs by experimenting with different wheel shapes.

name: Red Dragon Apparel
description: The Red Dragons first started as a tight crew of skaters from the Vancouver area. Then in 1996, Colin McKay, Sluggo and Peter Sullivan(former Girl team manager) opened RDS Skate Shop/Mail-Order Supply in North Vancouver with the original team of Colin, Sluggo, Moses Itkonen, Sam Devlin and Ben Nicholl. The Red Dragon name and apparel brand grew out of the shop and eventually other shops in Vancouver began to support the brand. Soon after, RDS products were being shipped across Canada, to International distributors, and to the second RDS Skate Supply location in Encinitas, California.

name: Rhythm Skateboards
description: Rhythm Skateboards was started by Felix Arguelles in the mid 1990s as a sister brand to Planet Earth and ran until 2001. Jose Gomez was the company art director, giving Rhythm more of a city feel and vibe. Rhythm team riders included Felix Arguelles, Danny Montoya, Richard Angelides, Joey Pepper, Ryan Bartsma, Jeff Taylor, Chany Jeanguenin, Jerry Fowler, Jon McGrath, Forrest Kirby, Rodney Torres and Mike Wright.

name: Planet Earth
description: Chris Miller founded Planet Earth Skateboards after leaving Schmitt Stix in the late 1980s. Planet Earth was originally ran out of H-Street until 1991 when Miller decided to take the brand on his own. Through the 1990s, Planet Earth carved out a loyal fan base, and by the mid 1990s had launched a sister deck company in Rhythm. But in 2002, Planet Earth ceased the production of decks, but remained the manufacturer of clothing and snowboard outerwear.

name: Reef Shoes
description: Reef was founded in 1984 by two brothers from Argentina, Fernando and Santiago Aguerre. Their sandal and shoe company embodied the casual attitude of the beach and the lifestyle that comes with it. Reef also received quite a bit of attention by featuring bikini models in their ads as well as holding various bikini model searches. By the mid 1990s, Reef added a skate division which over the years sponsored Laban Pheidias, Adil Dyani, Diego Bucchieri, Pat Channita, Jaya Bonderov, Jason Ellis and Kyle Berrard amongst others. But due to shrinking sales, the entire skate program was scrapped in 2003.

name: Schmitt Stix
description: Schmitt Stix was a deck company started by Paul Schmitt in the early 1980s. Being an expert craftsman, Schmitt furthered innovations in rail shape, deck shapes, concave, and more. In 1985, Schmitt moved Schmitt Stix from Florida to California and entered into a licensing agreement with Vision where he'd receive a royalty of sales. But by 1990, not owning the rights to his own company began to wear on Schmitt, at which point he left the company with Andy Howell and Steve Douglas to start New Deal Skateboards.

name: Sabre Vision
description: Sabre Vision was founded in 2006 as a eyewear and goggle company geared towards the skate, surf, art and street cultures of today. Sabre Vision draws their inspiration from the last 50 years of fashion, offering an extensive line of sunglasses for those searching for something different. Sabre team riders have included Al Partanen, Tom Knox and Marquis Preston.

name: Rannalli Trucks
description: Rannalli was a 1980's truck brand that offered correct geometry and a lifetime guarantee.

name: Race Wheels
description: Race was a wheel brand owned and managed by Mark Oblow through Fausto Vitello's distribution. Eric Ricks was the team manager as well as team rider along with Karma Tsocheff, Doug Saenz, Lib Layraman, Eben Jahnke and a few others. Oblow later left Race around 1993 to start Color Skateboards with Rich Metiver who also owned Union Wheels. Oblow and Metiver originally tried forcing Color riders to get on Union Wheels as well, at which point Vitello slapped a Thrasher ban on all Color riders.

name: Primitive
description: Primitive was founded by Paul Rodriguez in 2008 as a retail store front in Encino, California. Through a unique collection of hard to find items, Primitive quickly gained traction and amassed quite the loyal following. A Primitive apparel line wasn't far behind, and then in 2014, introduced a line of Primitive decks with a group of skaters which continually push the boundaries of technical skating.

name: Retro Wheels
description: Retro is a longboard wheel brand which was born out of a desire to develop high performance products for skateboarding. By using state-of-the-art technology and high quality urethane, Retro is able to deliver superior products at a reasonable cost for skaters.

name: Positiv Skateboards
description: The mission of Positiv Skateboards is to make high quality skateboards available to skaters of all levels, especially those looking for a great value on their first skateboard. Positiv Skateboards are designed and produced by Skate One, a manufacturer with over 30 years experience in building top quality skateboards. Positiv team riders include Andy Macdonald, Sandro Dias, Rodney Jones and Fabrizio Santos.

name: Popwar Skateboards
description: Popwar Skateboards was founded by Giant Distribution after New Deal dissolved in 2003. Popwar was originally named Populis Skateboards, but after only a few months felt the need to have a more defined focus. The name Popwar was meant to symbolize a war on popular culture. Graphic designer Grant "Yogi" Proctor worked as creative director and brought a level of enthusiasm and fun to the brand. Popwar introduced quite a bit of high end technology including their Drops decks & wheels, but ended up calling it quits in 2005 as sales dwindled.

name: Rewind Clothing
description: Rewind Clothing was a Montreal, Canada based company that started around 1997. Rewind manufactured a full cut-and-sew line using a variety of materials while focusing on quality of construction.

name: Randal Trucks
description: Randal Truck Co. has been manufacturing downhill and longboard specific trucks for over 30 years. Randal trucks are manufactured in the United States under strict environmental standards with the highest quality virgin aluminum, grade 8 axles and kingpins, and the highest grade urethane bushings available.

name: Phantom Trucks
description: Phantom started as a singular truck model under the Unit line of skateboard trucks but quickly began to be marketed as it's own brand of trucks. Today, Phantom continues to produce trucks in addition to price point decks and wheels.

name: Revenge Trucks
description: Revenge longboard trucks are a revolution in torsion skateboard truck technology which allow longboard skateboards to perform like surf and snowboards. Revenge trucks perform turns not previously possible on any type of deck.

name: Quiksilver
description: Quiksilver produces and distributes clothing, accessories and related products for young-minded people and develops brands that represent a casual lifestyle driven from a boardriding heritage. Quiksilver's authenticity is evident in its innovative products, events and retail environments across the globe.

name: Pacific Drive Skate Shop
description: Pacific Drive is a San Diego, Ca. based skate shop that was founded by Jim Ruonala in the late 1980s. As San Diego's premiere shop and mail order since the early 1990s, Pacific Drive has supported some of skateboarding & snowboarding's finest for over 20 years and shows no signs of slowing down.

name: Pyro Shoes
description: Pyro was a short lived shoe company that started popping up in magazines around the year 2000. The Pyro team consisted of Pat Duffy, Pancho Moler and Tim McKenney, but by the end of '01 Pat Duffy and Pancho Moler opted to quit, and the company basically faded into obscurity.

name: Santa Monica Airlines
description: Santa Monica Airlines was started by Skip Engblom in 1978 out of the back of he & Jeff Ho's Zephyr surf shop. Skip was a gifted surfboard shaper and originally shaped all of Santa Monica Airlines' skateboards by hand. In 1988, Skip convinced and helped Steve Rocco start SMA Rocco Division which later became World Industries. Around 1989, Skip moved Santa Monica Airlines to NHS where it got overhauled and shortened it's name to simply SMA. NHS eventually pulled the plug on SMA around 1993, at which point most the team got absorbed into other NHS brands. Today, Skip is back to doing the brand on his own and offers amazing hand stained wood decks in a variety of shapes and sizes.

name: Rusty
description: Before 1984, no one had ever seen or heard of the "R-dot", though they probably should have. At that time Rusty Preisendorfer was shaping surfboards under the Canyon label for 10 of the top 16 surfers in the world. Creating the simple yet powerful R-dot didn't cross his mind until one of his riders, former world champion Peter Townend, suggested he develop his own, independent label. Today Rusty is one of the most powerful surf and skate inspired companies in the world.

name: Reliance Skateboards
description: Reliance is a Christian based skateboard brand founded by Darren Wells. Reliance aims to be the most legit skateboard brand that reps Jesus Christ.

name: Pheonix Trucks
description: Pheonix was a short lived truck brand with team riders that included Mike Santarossa, Justin Reynolds and Anthony Carney. The Pheonix truck shape wasn't bad but just couldn't cut it in the ultra competitive truck market.

name: Quickies Bearings
description: Quickies was started in 1993 as a bearing division of Shorty's Hardware and found success in offering inexpensive abec-3 bearings with removable shields. But as the demand for higher rated bearings increased, rather than produce Quickies in multiple ratings they introduced Black Panthers as a superior bearing guaranteed against breakage for life. Needless to say, Black Panthers quickly grew to overshadow Quickies although original Quickies bearings are still produced today.

name: Queen City Skateboards
description: Queen City Skateboards was a deck company that operated out of Charlotte, North Carolina in the late 1990s. The name Queen City comes from the nickname of Charlotte, NC., and the company had plenty of local talent backing it including Kyle Moen, Ray Goff and Chris Bittikofer. Queen City also had a sub-division wheel company named Carolina Urethane.

name: Powell Peralta
description: Powell Peralta Skateboards was founded by George Powell and Stacy Peralta in 1978. In '91, the two went their separate ways with Stacy starting Powell skateboards in the process. In 2010, George Powell, the Godfather of skateboard manufacturing and Stacy Peralta, legendary skateboarder and film producer, re-joined forces and are proudly re-issuing some of the most popular and classic skateboards of all time along with wheels, soft goods, and many more must-have collectibles.

name: Pitcrew Skate Shop
description: Pitcrew Skate Shop was started back in October 1994 in Frederick, Maryland by Tim Reardon and Malcolm Bryan. Through years of local support, Pitcrew grew to have one of the more loyal followings amongst the neighboring skate communities. Pitcrew also went on to support some of the best skaters and released several solid skate videos, but unfortunately was forced to call it quits toward the end of 2017.

name: Rob Dyrdek's Fantasy Factory
description: Rob Dyrdek's Fantasy Factory is a MTV reality show which first premiered in 2009, hot on the heels of Dyrdek's previous hit MTV show Rob & Big. The Fantasy Factory is a commercial building in which Dyrdek conducts his many business ventures as well as grants fantasies for himself and a close knit group of friends including Christopher "Drama" Pfaff, Chelsea Chanel Dudley, Christopher "Big Black" Boykins, Tony Turbo, and Dyrdek's manager Jeremy Larner among others.

name: Rockstar Bearings
description: Rockstar Bearings began in the summer of 2000, out of the back doors of the legendary core skateshop, ABC-named after the neighborhood where it stood; Alphabet City. Founded by ABC owner Adrian Lopez-Guevarra and Harold Hunter, their vision was to create something that could reach out to others, especially the young kids.

name: Plan B Skateboards
description: Plan B Skateboards was founded by Mike Ternasky in 1991 under the distribution of World Industries. And by 1992, had cemented itself in skate history with the release of Questionable, the first of many groundbreaking Plan B videos. Ternasky owned and operated Plan B until 1994 when he was killed in a car accident. Danny Way and Colin McKay continued with the company after Mike's death but eventually called it quits in 1998. Then in 2005, Danny and Colin revived Plan B through Syndrome Distribution but have since taken it independently.

name: Rookie Skateboards
description: Rookie Skateboards was founded in the late 1990s as a company owned and run by females. Based out of New York, Rookie embodied street skating in the city and supported a strong team of females and males alike. Rookie team riders included Jaime Reyes, Jessie Van Roechoudt, Kyle Duffy, Lauren Mollica, Amy Caron, Lisa Whitaker, Tino Razo, Sean Kelling, and Jon Klein.

name: Satori Wheels
description: Satori Wheels was founded in Athens, Georgia by a group of Earth friendly individuals seeking a inner, intuitive experience of enlightenment through skateboarding. Satori instantly found their niche through a strong focus on environmentally friendly products and positive vibes. Today, Satori is all about living it up while giving good vibes back to Mother Earth via skateboarding, music, art, and exploration.

name: Scarecrow
description: Scarecrow Skateboards was founded by Russ Pope in 1995 after parting ways with Creature/NHS. Jason Adams followed Pope over from Creature, and along with Barker Barrett, Ben Horton, Tony Cox, Dorian Tucker and Thom Hornung gained a loyal following. Pope established Haunted House Distribution to distribute Scarecrow, and also introduced Stakes Hardware and a Scarecrow Wheels division with Adam McNatt, Josh Kasper, Crazy Eddie Nemeth, Joe Nemeth, Charlie Watts and more. Ultimately Scarecrow met it's end, although a shorter lived version of Scarecrow with Frank Hirata, Charlie Thomas and Ryan Johnson popped up around 2005.

name: Other Level Skateboards
description: Other Level Skateboards was a early 1990s deck brand with team riders that included June Cate, Danny Mayer, Mike Crum and Chris Gentry amongst others.

name: Power Shoes
description: Power Skate Shoes was a skate division of Canadian based Power Athletics Ltd., the makers of men's and women's athletic footwear for running, training, tennis, football, fitness and more. Power introduced their mid-priced skate line in the mid 2000s but due to lack of sales was forced to scrap the skate division in 2008. The Power team consisted of Willy Santos, Jesse Landen, James Craig, Dayne Brummet, Mike Crum, and the late Josh Evin.

name: Pig Wheels
description: Pig Wheels was started in 1996 as a wheel division for Tum Yeto. With Josh Beagle as team manager, original Pig riders included Jamie Thomas, Heath Kirchart, Steve Berra, Ronnie Creager, Brad Staba, Matt Hensley, Jerry Fowler, Mike Manzoori, Jason Maxwell, and Vinnie Ponte amongst others. Pig also launched a short lived Pig Wood division of decks and Pig Brand apparel in the 2000's.

name: Savier Shoes
description: Savier Footwear was a Portland, Oregon based shoe company that was purchased by Nike while still in it's business plan stage. Nike saw Savier as a way to re-enter the skate market after their first effort was scrapped in 1996. Although Savier was an independent subsidiary of Nike, the brand had unlimited access to Nike's footwear materials and production, which lead to some amazing and perplexing designs. Savier specialized in footwear, bags and apparel, but got the plug pulled in 2004 after failing to achieve it's financial goals.

name: Platinum Skateboards
description: Platinum Skateboards was started by Danny Way and Tommy Caudill in 1995 as a board division of their XYZ Skate Shop. Originally named XYZ Platinum, the early team consisted of Chet Thomas, Ben Pappas, Tas Pappas, Henry Sanchez, Justin Bokma and Lance Conklin, but over the years also included Moses Itkonen, Jason Maxwell, Jonas Wray, Arto Saari, Paul Machnau, Neal Mims and Jake Stewart.

name: REN Clothing
description: REN was a t-shirt company that Ted Newsome started as a side project in around 1990 or 1991. The name REN was an acronym for Racial Equality Now and promoted equality for all races. Although REN had no official team riders, they did hook up some noteworthy friends with product from time to time. REN was distributed by Volume Distribution and then later on through Andy Howell's Sophisto.

name: Rush Bearings
description: Rush Bearings are exceptional quality skateboard bearings which are available in Abec 3, Abec 5, Abec 7, Abec 9, All Weather stainless steel, Hybrid (w/ 1 ceramic ball), Ceramic and Swiss ratings. Rush is currently restructuring their team but former riders have included Jon Dickson, Bryant Chapo, Justin Cefia, Kendall Cordova, David Kim, Mike Thompson, Abe Olague and Collin Comito.

name: Randoms Hardware
description: Randoms is a line of self-locking hardware which eliminate the need for an Allen Key or screwdriver. Randoms are available in multiple head designs including skulls, aliens, straight faces, yin-yang and griptek.

name: Royal Trucks
description: Royal Trucks was founded in 1997 by Rudy Johnson and Guy Mariano under the umbrella of Girl Skateboard brands. Royal offers a wide variety of colored and pro model trucks through their various Original Low, Royal 4 and Evolution styles.

name: RVCA
description: RVCA was founded in 2002 on the principle of transcending the boundaries of traditional action sports apparel. RVCA is a collective of various subcultures, as well as an outlet for artists through their Artist Network Program. Having cemented their roots in surfing and skating, the RVCA look remains classic and timeless.

name: Recs Shoes
description: Recs Shoes was a skate footwear company that was based out of Costa Mesa, California from the mid to late 1990s. Recs was headed up by Bill Weiss and had a team which consisted of Fred Gall, Adam McNatt, Mike Crum, Bill Weiss, Pat Duffy, Justin Bokma, Richard Angelides, Corey Sheppard and Robbie Gangemi.

name: Osiris Shoes
description: In 1996, Evol Skateboards re-branded and re-named their Evol Casuals footwear line Osiris in an effort to attract a larger group of customers and riders. Osiris is best known for their Dave Mayhew D3 signature model, which is the best selling skateboard shoe of all time. The brand is also cited as creating the first ever mobile audio backpack with their "G-Bag".

name: Palisades Longboards
description: Born on the streets of Southern California, Palisades Longboards represents a new era in longboard style and design. From Venice to Huntington, Trestles to Old Mans, Palisades Longboards are inspired by the laid back lifestyle of So Cal. Every Palisades longboard is made in America and features the dynamic artwork of local artists.

name: Rogue Status
description: Rogue Status is a streetwear and lifestyle brand which was created by Rex Holloway and Johan Esbensen with additional investments from Rob Dyrdek and Blink 182 drummer Travis Barker. Founded in 2005, Rogue Status rose to unbelievable heights through repeated exposure on MTV's Rob & Big reality show. Rogue Status creates controversial designs in order to extort response and dialogue, and often uses the acronym DTA which stands for Don't Trust Anyone.

name: PTS Shoes
description: PTS Shoes was a late 1990s to early 2000s footwear brand that never really seemed to catch on. I can't recall ever seeing a pair on anyone or in a shop, and am somewhat curious as to how they lasted as long as they did. They had a decent team in Chris Gentry, Adil Dyani, Eric Ricks, Frank Atwater, Erik Villalobos, Cooper Wilt, Billy Marks and a few others, but failed to hit the mark when it came to their shoe design and overall marketing.

name: Roughneck Hardware
description: Roughneck Hardware was established in '97 in San Francisco, California by Johnny Roughneck. Shear determination and the love of skateboarding, is what gave Johnny the drive to create an independent skateboard company.

name: Puzzle Video Magazine
description: Puzzle is an online video magazine and a premium destination to watch and share original worldwide videos about professional skateboarding.

name: Panic Skateboards
description: Panic Skateboards was a European deck company from the mid 1990s. A few Panic team riders included John Rattray, Colin Kennedy, Paul Shier and Matt Pritchard.

name: Ricta Wheels
description: Ricta is a wheel brand out of NHS.

name: Roots Skateboards
description: Roots was a skateboard company out of Minneapolis, MN.

name: Reebok Shoes
description: Reebok, also known as Rbk is a global footwear brand with a strong heritage and authenticity in team sports and fitness. But in 2005, Stevie Williams approached Rbk about doing a skate specific footwear line, which Rbk optimistically agreed to. Stevie not only entered into an athletic agreement for footwear but also licensed the DGK name to Rbk for a line of DGK x Reebok apparel. Although Rbk was endorsed by most of the DGK team, it ultimately failed to meet sales projections and the line was eventually scrapped.

name: Rob & Big
description: Rob & Big was a MTV reality show where professional street skater Rob Dyrdek and his best friend and bodyguard, Christopher "Big Black" Boykin shared a house in the Hollywood Hills, bouncing from one ridiculous moment to the next. Along with their mischievous little bulldog "Meaty" and their minihorse "Minihorse", the unlikely group made the world their playground and hit the streets on a constant quest for adventure and laughs.

name: Poot! Clothing
description: Poot! was a guys and girls clothing line that was founded by Tod Swank's girlfriend Keva Marie Sanders in around 1993. Poot! was designed by Keva but owned by Tod and was distributed through Tum Yeto. In around 1996, Poot! also introduced a line of footwear for both boys and girls. But just as Poot! began gaining momentum, Tod and Keva broke up and Tod dropped the brand.

name: Ramp Logic
description: Ramp Logic was founded by Danny Way in hopes of helping to provide kids more obstacles to skate. With production in China, Ramp Logic was able to elevate the quality level of metal fabricated portable ramps, ledges and grind rails. Ramp Logic obstacles were adjustable and used a universal skate key, but were at a high retail price and proved too expensive for most shops to take a chance on. The Ramp Logic team consisted of Danny Way, Tony Hawk and Eric Koston, with Koston having his own signature ledge.

name: Premier Skateboards
description: Premier was a short lived mid 1990s deck brand that was founded by Bill Weiss. A few of Premier's team riders included Bill Weiss, James Riff, Jason Shelton, Tune Tran, Gene Rosmarin and Peter Jimenez.

name: Riviera Longboards
description: Founded by Solomon Antonell and born from the idea that longboards are not just a surfers delight, Riviera is an alternative to all those existing surf-style companies.

name: Quattro Wheels
description: Quattro was a short lived wheel company which "Quattro Dave" operated in early 2000s. The name Quattro came from them originally having only 4 team riders, which we believe were Eric Koston, Steve Berra, Tony Ferguson and Marc Johnson. In 2003, Chris Roberts invested into Quattro and became a team rider/part owner. Other Quattro team riders included Gino Iannucci, Kenny Anderson, Javier Sarmiento, Jose Rojo, Robbie McKinley, Jereme Rogers, Jimmy Gorecki and Jesus Fernandez.

name: Rolls Racer
description: Rolls Racer was a skateboard deck brand that operated from the late 1980s to early 1990s. Rolls Racer didn't have any riders but rather knocked off iconic graphics of the time with slight changes to the graphic or pro name.

name: Orion Trucks
description: Orion Trucks is a brand that was founded by Larry Balma of Transworld back in 1995 with Rob Dyrdek, Kareem Campbell and Eric Koston as the headlining pros. Additional Orion team riders included Ronnie Bertino, Tom Penny, Josh Kalis, Kris Lambert, Kris Markovich, Steve Berra and Karl Watson amongst others, but eventually called it quits in the early 2000s. But then in 2011, Orion went back into production with slightly updated styles and a team of Pat Duffy, Clint Peterson, Ryan Decenzo, Marty Murawski, Marek Zaprazny and John Hanlon.

name: Roofie's Grip
description: Roofie's was a brand out of NHS which offered a wide variety of printed graphic grip tape including skulls, sexy females, Jack Daniels bottles, marijuana, cigarettes, turntables, money and more. Roofie's grip was unbelievable rough which helped keep the graphic but also wreaked havoc on your fingers while holding your board. These days, Mob has picked up where Roofie's left off but with much more manageable grit.

name: Santa Cruz Skateboards
description: Santa Cruz Skateboards was founded in 1973 by Rich Novak, Doug Haut and Jay Shuirman. Santa Cruz also employed legendary artist Jim Phillips to create most of the brands early graphics, most notably their iconic "Screaming Hand" graphic.

name: Rockstar Energy Drink
description: Rockstar is the world's most powerful energy drink. Enhanced with the potent herbal blend of Guarana, Ginkgo, Ginseng and Milk Thistle, Rockstar is formulated to provide an incredible energy boost for those who lead active and exhausting lifestyles - from athletes to rock stars.

name: Pure Wheels
description: Pure Wheels was a San Francisco based wheel company that started up around 1995. Pure was backed by Roger Davis of Experience, Profile, etc., and boasted a team of Henry Sanchez, Steve Berra, Tim Gavin, Jovontae Turner, Ronnie Creager, Daewon Song and Spencer Fujimoto.

name: Pro-Tec
description: Pro-Tec offers a wide variety of helmets and protection gear for skateboarding, surfing, bmx and water sports.

name: Pound Clothing
description: Pound Clothing was a mid 1990s apparel brand which was based out of Long Beach, CA. and supported the local talents of Eric Ricks, Joe McLellan, Gomez Warren, Carlos Aleman and Yoski Obayashi. Pound Clothing was cut short after a Calvin Klein themed ad landed them in legal trouble.

name: Red Bull Energy Drink
description: Red Bull is the original energy drink whose products now include Red Bull Energy, Red Bull Sugarfree, Red Bull Cola, Red Bull Energy Shot and Red Bull Sugarfree Energy Shot.

name: Premium Skateboards
description: Premium Skateboards is a Canadian based deck company that was founded in 1996. Premium is a skater owned and operated brand with current and former team riders that include Dayne Brummet, Max Dufour, Alex Gavin, Marc Tison and E.T.

name: Pipsqueeks Backpacks
description: Pipsqueeks was a backpack company that Rian Pozzebon started in the late 1990s after receiving a loan from a family member. Based out of Southern California, Pipsqueeks boasted some solid local talent including Daniel Shimizu, Danny Butanda, Guy Hartley, Jason Hernandez, Zack Warren, and Chris Alhambra. Pipsqueeks backpacks were functional, durable and even featured a secret stash pocket which was popular around those times. But after a couple years of breaking even, Rian decided to pay back his loan and call it quits.

name: Revolution Wheels
description: Revolution Wheels was founded by John Lucero around 2001 as a sister wheel brand to Black Label Skateboards. Revolution was originally launched under the banner of Giant Distribution and had a pretty large and insane team. These days, Revolution is devoid of any team riders and operates with help from the fine folks at Blitz Distribution.

name: Progression Video Magazine
description: Progression Video Magazine started as a local-access television show, dubbed Disgusted TV, but grew into a formidable video-magazine series that produced nine issues a year.

name: People Skateboards
description: People Skateboards was started in 1994 as a sister company to 60/40 Skateboards. Mako Urabe, Darrell Vaughn and Felix Unger were the brand's pros, along with amateurs Josh Friedberg, John Igei, Alex Hoffee, Brian Tucci and Charlie Coatney. People lasted only a short while before calling it quits around 1995.

name: Poweredge Magazine
description: Poweredge Magazine was founded in 1987 as an alternative to the established magazines of the 1980s. Poweredge was aimed to present skateboarding from a different angle and was part color but mostly black & white. The magazine was U.S. focused but featured quite a bit of European skateboarding and even introduced a European staff in 1989. The final issue of Poweredge came in the form of their October 1991 issue, but was revived shortly in 2009.

name: Project Hardware
description: Project Hardware was started by Joey Pulsifer with the idea of creating mounting hardware which could be adjusted with either a Phillips screwdriver or Allen key. Originally named Universal Hardware and distributed through Imperial Distribution, Joey later changed the name to Project and took the brand on his own, running it out of the back of Furnace Skate Shop in Seal Beach, CA. Today, Joey manages Project out of Resource Distribution, along with his other brands Paris Trucks and Divine Wheels.

name: Pink Wheels
description: Pink was born from the desire to develop high performance products specifically tailored for female skateboarders. By using state-of-the-art technology and high quality urethane, Pink is able to offer superior products at a reasonable cost for skaters.

name: Profile Skateboards
description: Profile was a deck company founded by Henry Sanchez in 1995 after parting ways with Blind. Profile was backed by Roger Davis of Experience Skateboards and had a solid team of Henry Sanchez, Karl Watson, Spencer Fujimoto, Stevie Williams, and Ahmed Hunt. Lee Smith was also on for a hot second before returning to Menace. Unfortunately, Profile lasted only a few short months before Henry decided to leave for Platinum, after which point the company was basically dissolved.

name: Paris Trucks
description: Paris Trucks was founded by Joey Pulsifer in 2005 after Solomon Antonell of Riviera Skateboards asked Joey to design a truck to go on Riviera completes. Joey accepted the challenge and Paris Trucks were the result. Today, not only do Paris Trucks come equipped on all Riviera completes, but have become the new standard in longboard trucks.

name: Roger Skateboards
description: Roger skateboards was started by Stacy Lowery and Michael Sieben in an effort to bring some fun back into skateboarding.

name: Puma Shoes
description: Puma is one of the world's leading sportlifestyle companies that designs and develops footwear, apparel and accessories. Puma is committed to working in ways that contribute to the world by supporting creativity, sustainability and peace, and by staying true to the principles of being fair, honest, positive and creative in decisions made and actions taken.

name: Public Skateboards
description: Public Skateboards was a deck company founded by Eddie Reategui in around 1991. Eddie along with Chet Thomas were the Public pros, but failed to make much noise and was defunct by 1992.

name: Renaissance
description: Renaissance was a Christian based skateboard, clothing and accessory company that operated from the mid 1990s to early 2000s. Renaissance focused on promoting a positive message to the youth while offering wholesome and religious deck graphics. A young Caswell Berry was the brand's main team rider along with Jon Branch, Willy Bean, Mike Maynard and a few others.

name: Pharmacy Board Shop
description: Pharmacy Boardshop was originally founded in 1997 and has been serving the southern California skate community ever since. The Pharmacy chain of retail stores include locations in Victorville, Palmdale, Lancaster and Las Vegas. In the fall of 2010, longtime Pharmacy rider Bryan Herman opened a Pharmacy location in Hollywood which he is a 50/50 partner in along with Pharmacy owner Donny Damron.

name: Ramptech
description: Ramptech is the world's largest and oldest manufacturer of skateboard ramps, ramp kits and ramp plans for the home user. Ramptech has also built thrilling skateboard courses for the Vans Triple Crown contest series and ESPN.

name: Reflex Bearings
description: Founded in 1998, Reflex was the manufacturer of high performance skateboard bearings, trucks and accessories. Reflex was produced through DNA Distribution, the makers of Alien Workshop & Habitat Skateboards, but fell victim to budget cuts shortly after Rob Drydek acquired DNA in the early 2010s. Over the years, Reflex supported such legendary skaters as Kareem Campbell, Guy Mariano, Josh Kalis, Danny Way, Colin McKay, Rob Dyrdek, Stevie Williams and Bob Burnquist.

name: Vans Syndicate
description: Syndicate is a premium footwear division of Vans that first delivered in the Fall of 2005. The Vans Syndicate line offers classic silhouettes in premium materials with limited quantities, and are available at finer sneaker boutiques worldwide. Syndicate has produced collaborations with John Cardiel, Eric Dressen and Tommy Guerrero, plus iconic brands & artists such as Mr. Cartoon, Grime, W)Taps, Shawn Stussy and Wes Humpston amongst others.

name: Young Guns
description: Young Guns Skateboards was founded by Alex "Trainwreck" Gall in 2004 after parting ways with Bootleg. Young Guns had an old timey western feel and a solid team with Trainwreck, Joey Poirez and Antwuan Dixon, but only lasted until 2005 before the investor shut things down.

name: Zero Skateboards
description: Jamie Thomas started Zero Division in 1996 as a small clothing company, but the brand quickly morphed into Zero Skateboards after Jamie's departure from Toy Machine. Zero was originally distributed through Tum-Yeto until Jamie founded Black Box Distribution in 2000.

name: XYZ Clothing
description: XYZ was founded by Danny Way and Tommy Caudill in the early 1990's as a skate shop and mailorder based out of Carlsbad, CA. Then in the later 1990s, introduced XYZ Clothing as a full apparel and accessory brand. XYZ Clothing team riders included Danny Way, Pat Channita, Pat Duffy, Peter Hewitt, Jason Ellis, Justin Bokma, Ben & Tas Pappas, Chet Thomas, Brian Emmers and a young Trainwreck amongst others. XYZ Clothing eventually called it quits around the year 2000 due to lack of sales.

name: The Driven
description: Started by Jason Jessee in the early 2000s, The Driven was a deck company geared toward the older shredder. In addition to wider & old school shaped decks, The Driven also produced a line of elegant cloth slippers. The Driven team riders included Jason Jessee, Jay Adams and Andy Roy.

name: Volcom
description: Volcom was established in 1991 by Richard Woolcott and Tucker Hall on an idea that would incorporate a major philosophy of the times, "youth against establishment". This energy was an enlightened state to support young creative thinking. Volcom was a family of people not willing to accept the suppression of the established ways.

name: Thrasher Magazine
description: Thrasher Magazine was founded in 1981 by Kevin Thatcher & Fausto Vitello, and is skateboarding's longest running magazine. Over the years, Thrasher has turned out countless issues and videos, and introduced us to CR Stecyk's now iconic Skate and Destroy logo. Thrasher also hosts an annual King of the Road contest which pits teams against each other for a cross-country, street skating, scavenger hunt freak-out extravaganza.

name: Tornado Wheels
description: Tornado Wheels was a '90s wheel brand that was distributed through Atlas Distribution, the makers of Planet Earth, Rhythm, Adio, Mercury and Hawk.

name: Zumiez
description: Zumiez first opened it's doors in 1978 in the Seattle, Washington area under the name "Above the Belt". Since then, they've changed the name to Zumiez and have grown to operate over 400 retail locations across the United States. Zumiez stores are most commonly found in malls and in an attempt to market to teens, are usually purposefully messy.

name: Z Products
description: "Generations Strong" are the best words to describe Z-Flex Products. Originally founded back in 1976 as a home for the legendary Z-Boys, Z-Products have helped pave the way through unique innovations such as the fiberglass board, Z-Roller Trucks and Z-Farrel series wheels. Z-Flex Products has also left their mark through iconic team riders such as Jay Adams, Jimmy Plumer, Marty Grimes and Shogo Kubo amongst others.

name: Tilt Mode Army
description: Tilt Mode Army is a group of friends from in and around the San Jose, CA area.

name: West 49
description: West 49 was started in 1995 as a Canadian based retail store but quickly grew to become Canada's largest skateboard and snowboard retail chain. West 49 offers action sports related hardgoods, apparel and footwear for guys, girls & youth. They also have their own private label clothing line, West 49. In August of 2010, Billabong purchased West 49 in an effort to showcase it's brands and expand it's reach.

name: Zorlac Skateboards
description: Jeff Newton first started Zorlac Skateboards out of his 2 car garage in the early 1980s. Armed with a group of local outsiders, Zorlac embodied the "Skate and Destroy" attitude of the Texas skate scene and was backed up by Pushead's haunting art illustrations. Zorlac also sponsored multiple "Shut Up and Skate" contests which drew skaters from across Texas as well as surrounding states.

name: Wu Tang Skateboards
description: Wu-Tang Hard Goods came about in 1998 when Christian Strike called Jahmal Williams saying that Wu-Tang wanted to do a skateboard company. Christian and Jahmal proceeded to put together the first all-black skate team, but the brand was eventually shut down around 2001 after someone bought the licensing agreement.

name: The Hundreds
description: Co-founded by Ben and Bobby Hundreds in 2003, The Hundreds incorporate a trademark attitude and personal perspective on street subculture. The Hundreds clothing is inspired by Los Angeles lifestyle/California culture and Southern California's skateboarding, surf, punk, and hip-hop cultures.

name: Tuff Skates
description: Tuff Skates was a late 1980s to early 1990s deck company that was started by Christian Hosoi.

name: TSG Pads
description: TSG also known as Technical Safety Gear was founded in Germany in 1988. TSG started with the single idea of protection designed by riders that skateboarders actually would want to wear. Being one of the protection gear pioneers in the skateboard business, TSG revolutionized the industry by developing high performance helmets and pads as well as committing to a marketing and sponsorship.

name: Vita Manufacturing
description: In 1998, Vita Manufacturing began with a vision shared by head honcho Mark Oblow, pro skateboarder Natas Kaupas, and private investor Lance Theis. They set their sights on creating shoes for core skaters and retailing them exclusively in independently owned shops.

name: Zimbabwe
description: Zimbabwe first started out as a skate shop located in Long Beach, California in the late 1980's. In 1990, the shop started a clothing line and by the mid 1990's began producing Zimbabwe Skateboards. Zimbabwe also partnered with Bill Weiss' short lived Balance Skateboards. But in about 1997, Zimbabwe shut the doors on their shop and board company.

name: Zero Two
description: Zero Two Shoes started around 1991, and was introduced as skateboarding's first all vegetarian shoe brand and boasted a team consisting of Brian Lotti, Ed Templeton, Mike Vallely and Sean Sheffey. Outside of being animal friendly, the shoes other big feature was a movable ollie guard that could be placed anywhere on the shoe. But as it turned out, the company owner didn't see his shoes as skateboard shoes and wasn't even vegetarian, causing the team to quit.

name: Wray Bros
description: Wray Bros Skateboards was founded in 2012 by Jeremy & Jonas Wray along with longtime friend Paul Luna. With a focus on top quality products and promoting skateboarding in a positive light, Wray Bros has quickly and organically gained a loyal following. In 2014, Wray Bros further strengthened the brand by bringing longtime pal Pat Channita into the fold.

name: Wounded Knee
description: Wounded Knee Skateboards was founded in 1998 by Jim "Murf" Murphy as a way to remind and educate people on the Wounded Knee massacre of 1890 and it's aftermath.

name: Voice Skateboards
description: Voice Skateboards was founded by Dave Schlossbach in around '95 or '96 but called it quits shortly after in 1997. Voice was the home to several up and coming San Diego rippers including Kanten Russell, Daxter Lussier and Brandon Turner, and was the company that turned Peter Smolik pro.

name: Theeve Trucks
description: In July 2007, Theeve Trucks set out to design the strongest, lightest and best skating truck to date. The progression of skateboarding into big technical tricks has started to demand more from trucks than ever before. Titanium was the obvious choice when it came to taking trucks to the next level.

name: Woodstock Skateboards
description: Woodstock Skateboards was started around 1995 by Simon Woodstock with the financial backing of Rich Metiver. The brand played into Simon's sense of humor but went too far when Woodstock ran an ad and graphic depicting Steve Rocco & a World Industries character in a compromising position. The ad landed Woodstock and Metiver in court where Rocco received an out of court settlement which basically spelled the end of the brand.

name: Town & Country
description: In 1971 Craig Sugihara founded Town & Country Surf Shop. Fueled by an unrestrained passion for surfing, Town & Country evolved into a multifaceted surf company and solidified its position as a worldwide industry icon. In the 1980's Town & Country introduced a skateboard division called Town & Country Skate Designs with Ken Park and Johnee Kop being the faces and focal points for the brand.

name: The Denver Shop
description: The Denver Shop was a skate shop that was located in Denver, Colorado. The Denver Shop was a big supporter of the local skate scene, and produced several team videos from the mid to late 2000s.

name: Volume 4
description: Volume 4 is a clothing and accessory company that was founded by Don "Nuge" Nguyen & Sammy Baca under the banner of Baker Boys Distribution. Volume 4 first delivered for Fall 2013, and found an instant following through a throwback style that's reminiscent of 70s rock n' roll & life on the road.

name: Vestal Watches
description: Vestal collections are watches, softgoods & accessories that fine-tune style and expression for the musically inspired individual. Established in 1997, Vestal is marketed and branded through friends, musicians, artists and athletes who are immersed within music culture. Vestal can be found in specialty stores and finer boutiques in more than forty countries around the world.

name: Vallely Skateboards
description: Mike Vallely founded Vallely Skateboards in 2002 after parting ways with Black Label. Vallely Skateboards was distributed through Giant Dist. and had a team of Mike Vallely, Steffan Attardo, Jesse Fritsch, Alysson Castro and Bobby Stewart, but eventually folded in 2003 due to poor growth.

name: True Skateboards
description: True Skateboards was a Japanese based skateboard company from the mid to late 90's.

name: Yellow Brand
description: Yellow Brand was a short lived deck brand out of High Grade Distribution in the mid 2000s. Yellow team riders included John Buchanan, Dave Abair, Johan Stuckey, Mike Espinosa, Brian Downey and Ryan Nix.

name: The Skateboard Mag
description: The Skateboard Mag was founded in 2003 after several Transworld photographers and employees up and left TWS to create a greener pasture. With The Skateboard Mag, the group hoped to provide a higher quality magazine that was strictly focused on skateboarding. The Skateboard Mag's premiere issue came in March 2004 and has remained skateboarding's best and highest quality magazine ever since.

name: Viking Helmets
description: Viking Helmets was founded in 2003 on the idea that there should be protective gear for kids of all ages. With more and more kids finding skateboarding at an earlier age there was a need for protective gear for little folks that looked cool while giving them the maximum comfort and protection they deserve. Viking was born out of this necessity and quickly expanded into protective pads and helmets for skaters of all ages.

name: Unreel Productions
description: Unreel Productions was a video group from the 1980s which specialized in cutting edge videos for all the major action sports. Unreel's video library was distributed by Vision and included such legendary hits as The Vision Pro, Psycho Skate, Red Hot Skate Rock, Holiday Havoc, Ramp N' Rage, Bmx Xtremes, Freestylin' Fanatics, Blazin' Bmx, World Cup of BMX, Snow Shredders, This is Snowboarding, Surf City and How to Bodyboard.

name: Vans Shoes
description: Vans Shoes was established in 1966 when Paul Van Doren and three partners opened their first store in Anaheim, California. Today, there are over 150 Vans company owned stores, factory outlets and independent retailers in the United States alone.

name: The Firm Skateboards
description: In 1991, Lance Mountain and Ray Barbee both left Powell Peralta to independently start The Firm Skateboards. The Firm had a clean image with plenty of notable riders including Weston Correa, Pat Brennen, Salman Agah, Bob Burnquist, Matt Beach, Frank Gerwer, Javier Sarmiento, and Rodrigo Teixeira amongst others. The Firm later moved under Blitz Distribution but on March 13, 2006, Lance Mountain regrettably announced the end of The Firm.

name: Webb Trucks
description: Webb Trucks was started by Vinnie Lopez out of Newport Beach, California with team riders that included Anthony Carney and Aaron Irvins. Webb Trucks were made in the United States and were guaranteed against defects, but had a somewhat strange design with holes shaved out of the hanger for weight reduction. Webb lasted a couple years, but in the year 2000 decided to change it's truck design and re-brand the company as Omega Trucks.

name: VonZipper
description: VonZipper is in the business of promoting lifestyle and personality in the form of quality sunglasses, goggles, soft goods and accessories.

name: TV Skateboards
