description: TV Skateboards was founded by Mike Vallely and Ed Templeton in 1992 after wanting control over the products they were putting out. The majority of TV graphics were done by Ed Templeton and were often humorous. TV originally started under the backing of Brad Dorfman, although Mike & Ed quickly changed backers and were forced to rebrand the company as Television.

name: Type S Wheels
description: Type-S Wheels was created by Lincoln Ueda and Sergie Ventura in 2002. Their goal was to design a skateboard wheel that had more than looks, applying what they feel really works in a skateboard wheel. Type-S team riders have included Sergie Ventura, Lincoln Ueda, Bastien Salabanzi, Christian Hosoi, Nicky Guerrero, Rodolfo Ramos, Tyler Hendley, Bucky Lasek, Lester Kasai, Lyn-Z Adams Hawkins, Pedro Barros, Ronaldo Gomes and Tom Schaar.

name: Union Wheel Co
description: Union Wheels was a brand from the 1990s that was owned by Rich Metiver. Union team riders included Matt Beach, Steve Olson, Tom Boyle, Ronnie Bertino, Adil Dyani, Tom Krauser, Ryan Kenreich, Brian Young, Paul Sharpe and Eric Koston amongst others. Union caused a bit of a stir when Mark Oblow left Race Wheels to start Color Skateboards with Metiver's backing and tried forcing Color riders to leave their current wheel sponsors for Union as a package deal. Of course this didn't sit well with Fausto Vitello who was the distributor for Race Wheels and resulted in all Color riders receiving a ban from Thrasher Magazine.

name: Zoo York
description: In 1993, OG skateboarders Rodney Smith, Eli Morgan Gessner, and Adam Schatz teamed up to found the East Coast's first true skateboarding-inspired lifestyle brand - Zoo York. Today, Zoo York is a highly evolved, globally recognized brand with unbreakable East Coast attitude and dialect. As it has since day one, Zoo's product line continues to be heavily influenced by skateboarding, graffiti, hip-hop, punk, and everything in between.

name: Tree Fort Skateboards
description: Tree Fort Skateboards was launched in the mid 1990's with the tight knit team of Danny Supa, Jeremy Deglopper, Max Dufour, Vinnie Ponte and Jimmy Chadwick.

name: Western Edition
description: Western Edition also known as WE is a San Francisco based deck company that was founded in 1999. As an FTC subsidiary, Western Edition was afforded the luxury of hand picking some of San Francisco's finest talent. Western Edition team riders have included Brad Johnson, Nikhil Thayer, Alex Klein, Jason Wussler, Pat Washington and John Igei to name just a few.

name: Titan Trucks
description: Titan Trucks was a Southern California based truck company that started around the mid 1990s. Titan saw some success through their Ti-Lite model truck which was marketed as the strongest and lightest truck on the planet. Titan also went on to produce a line of freestyle scooters in the later 1990s to early 2000s.

name: Variflex Skateboards
description: Variflex Skateboards was started by Allen Losi's father, brother, uncle and cousin around 1977, but struggled with an identity as Allen's dad pushed producing quality boards while his uncle pushed going mass market. By 1985, Allen's father had left the company and Allen contemplated leaving to start Team Losi through Santa Cruz/Bullet, but ultimately stayed and launched Team Losi through Variflex.

name: Tracker Trucks
description: Tracker Trucks was founded by Larry Balma in 1975 and went on to introduce the first wide modern skateboard truck. In 2009, Tracker merged with Pure Distribution.

name: Warco
description: Warco Skateboards is an ominous deck company dedicated to the skateboarders who have created and sustained it through years of hard effort. Warco neither endorses nor condemns war; rather, Warco thrives in an environment of warfare. They are not at war with anyone except for the perpetual war they have declared upon ourselves.

name: Traffic Skateboards
description: Traffic Skateboards was founded by East Coast skate legend Ricky Oyola.

name: Vision Skateboards
description: Vision was one of the largest brands of the 1980's with a team consisting of Mark Gonzales, Ken Park, Lee Ralph and Mark "Gator" Rogowski just to name a few.

name: Vision Street Wear
description: From their first year, it was clear that Vision was something different. The Vision team represented some of the sickest most innovative skaters at the time. In addition, Vision was the first brand to understand the natural connection between music and skate culture. It put on a number of music and skate events including the Vision Skate Escape featuring Tony Hawk, Christian Hosoi and the Red Hot Chili Peppers.

name: World Industries
description: World Industries was founded by Steve Rocco in '88 after Skip Engblom convinced him to cash out his credit card, buy some decks and start a company. The result was SMA Rocco Division which later became World Industries. Rocco set out to take down the '80s "Big 4" and convinced both Rodney Mullen and Mike Vallely to quit Powell and become riders/partners in his young brand. Rocco broke every rule in the book and waged war on several companies through print ads, lawsuits, company graphics and rider acquisitions. In '98, World was sold to an outside private equity group and has changed hands a few more times since then. Today, World Industries remains the manufacturer of skateboards, apparel and shoes.

name: Willy's Workshop
description: Willy's Workshop is a skate shop that was founded by Willy Santos in the late 1990s. After partnering with a friend in Willy's Kuts & Fades Etc., which was a barber/skate shop, Willy sold his portion back to his partner and opened Willy's Workshop in Rancho Penesquitos, Ca. Since then, the original Rancho Penesquitos location has closed but still operate a location in San Diego, Ca.

name: Westside Skate Shop
description: Westside Skate Shop was founded in 1997 by former New Deal pro John Montesi, and has proudly been serving the Florida skate community ever since. Westside has been voted the #1 skater owned shop by Transworld Magazine and continues it's growth through their Tarpon Springs & Clearwater, Florida locations.

name: The Berrics
description: The Berrics is a private Los Angeles based skate facility which is owned by Eric Koston and Steve Berra. The Berrics offers daily exclusive skate video content in addition to several ongoing segments including Wednesdays with Reda, Mikey Days, Battle Commander and Battle at the Berrics. In 2011, The Berrics entered into a licensing deal with the La Jolla Group, the makers of Metal Mulisha, O'Neill, Rusty, etc. to produce a line of Berrics clothing which is available at skate shops worldwide as well as through The Berrics website.

name: WeSC
description: WeSC is a street-fashion brand for intellectual slackers which is also known as We are the Superlative Conspiracy. Early in 2000, the founders of WeSC joined forces to deliver a broader selection of street-fashion apparel for men and women alike. Together they took the initiative to formulate the Superlative Conspiracy, and bring you "life after skate", a more developed style targeting people both within, and outside of the skateboard community, while continuing to share and maintain core values.

name: The High Five
description: Todd Bratrud founded The High Five Skateboards in around 2009 in hopes of bringing some fun and humor back into skateboard graphics, and skateboarding in general. Even their name celebrated the universal display of stoke that comes along with a high five. But unfortunately in 2012, The High Five ran into copyright issues and therefore re-booted itself as Send Help Skateboards.

name: Triple 8 Pads
description: Since 1995, Triple 8 has been offering the highest quality protective equipment, covering you from head to toe and allowing you to push the limits while being safe. Whether you are a veteran pro, aspiring amateur or a first timer, Triple 8 will help keep you protected. Triple 8 offers an extensive line of helmets and pads for skate, snow and wake.

name: The Kayo Corp
description: The Kayo Corp was founded in 2002 as the distribution house for DGK Skateboards, Expedition One Skateboards, Organika Skateboards, Gold Wheels and L&K Limited Apparel. Around 2010, The Kayo Corp website added KAYOTV as a video media outlet for it's various brands.

name: Warp Magazine
description: Warp Magazine was a short lived division of Transworld Media which combined elements of skateboarding, snowboarding, surfing, and music all into one magazine.

name: Yocaher
description: Yocaher began as a skateboard manufacturer and distributor at the beginning of the skateboard industry in 1975. Yocaher specializes in decks and pads, as well as in producing price-point parts through their various brands including Punked decks and longboards, Black Widow grip, HD5 trucks, Ritalin bearings, Ironfist pads and Balls wheels.

name: Vanilla
description: Vanilla was a mid 1990's clothing company based out of Lake Forest, California. Vanilla was backed by Joyride Snowboards and had a team of Reese Forbes, Satva Leung, Sean Mullendore, Charlie Coatney, John Coon and Vishaal Khanna, but got it's plug pulled once Joyride began to struggle.

name: Toy Machine
description: Toy Machine Skateboards was founded by Ed Templeton in 1993 after TV(his company with Mike Vallely) folded. Since it's inception, Ed has been Toy Machine's driving creative force, bringing a level of art and humor which has defined the brand. Ed originally launched Toy Machine through Vision before moving the brand over to Foundation(now Tum Yeto) Distribution.

name: Unit
description: Unit Trucks was started in the mid 1990s in hopes of offering a more lightweight truck design. Unit most notably produced the Phantom style truck which eventually became it's own brand, and introduced the ever so popular Unit Skateboard Tool. Today, Unit has ceased truck production, but continues to manufacture the Unit Skateboard Tool in a variety of colors.

name: Uncle Wiggley
description: Uncle Wiggley was a San Diego based deck company that operated in the early 1980s. After testing some boards that a few Del Mar Skate Ranch locals had built, Tony Magnusson came onboard and invested all he had into the company. Uncle Wigley made their own boards and therefore pushed some progressive deck constructions including foam/kevlar and epoxy/glass models. But after a few years of printing boards instead of skating, Tony decided to leave Uncle Wiggley for his own division (Magnusson Designs) at Sure Grip.

name: Theory Skate Shop
description: Theory Skate & Snow Shop was started by childhood skate friends Dan Dziuban and Frank Langone on the notion of a more creative skate shop environment. With locations in Holyoke & West Springfeld, MA, and previous locations in Amherst, MA & Marlborough, CT, Theory has proudly been serving the Northeast skate community since first opening it's doors back in 1998.

name: Thunder Trucks
description: Thunder Trucks was founded in 1986 and are distributed through Deluxe. Thunder Trucks have a lightning quick turning response and are designed to be one of the quickest, most stable, and most durable trucks available today.

name: Venture Trucks
description: Venture is a San Francisco based truck company that was founded in the early 80's by Fausto Vitello and Keith Cochrane. Venture trucks are manufactured by Vitello's Emrico truck foundry and are distributed by Deluxe Distribution.

name: Trust Skateboards
description: Trust Skateboards was started by Kevin Hurtado in the early 1990s. Trust operated out of Northern California but was also distributed through Tum Yeto for a short time along with Trust's sister company Absolute Wheels. A few Trust team riders included Mako Urabe, Jason Clark and William Nguyen.

name: Walker Skateboards
description: Walker Skateboards was co-founded by Bruce Walker in 1972 along with partners Lewis Graves & Ted James. Walker co-owned surf shops and set up Fox Skateboards which would become Walker Skateboards. Walker was one of the first skater owned and operated companies.

name: Tired Skateboards
description: Tired Skateboards was started in 2014 as the brainchild of Dutch artist Parra. Tired utilizes humorous illustrations to reflect the funner side of skateboarding and to celebrate the old and tired who still skate for the love of it. Tired is distributed through Big Time Distribution.

name: Wood Laminates
description: Wood Laminates was a Canadian based deck company that started in the late 1990s. Wood Laminates had a local following but failed to show up on the U.S. radar outside of a few 411VM commercials.

name: Vox Shoes
description: Vox Footwear was founded in 2005, and is the manufacturer of skateboard shoes, apparel and accessories.

name: Transit Skateboards
description: Transit was a deck company founded by Mike Vallely in December of 1997, but died less than a year later in August 1998. Transit was based out of East Brunswick, NJ, where Vallely had moved in hopes of reconnecting with his East Coast roots. The Transit team consisted of pros Mike Vallely, Stacy Lowery, Tom Boyle and Charlie Wilkins plus amateurs J.R. Neves and Rocky Norton.

name: Upful Hardware
description: Upful is a skateboard hardware company that was started in 2002 and is distributed through High Grade Distribution. Upful is a brand which encourages others to shun what is negative and embrace positivity in all aspects of life. Upful offers a wide variety of uniquely colored hardware with a Earthy vibe.

name: XXX Brand
description: XXX Sports was a skatepark/pro-shop from the 1990s that went on to create the short lived XXX Brand Skateboards in around 1998.

name: Skate Rags
description: Skate Rags was a Southern California based clothing company that operated from the mid 1980s to early 1990s. The Skate Rags tagline was "To Fit and Survive" and marketed their apparel as being a bit more durable. But as the skateboard landscape changed in the early 90s, Skate Rags struggled to find their spot in the marketplace and folded. A few Skate Rags team riders included Mike McGill, Tom Groholski, Monty Nolder, Sam Cunningham, Ben Schroeder, Mark Partain and Rob Mertz.

name: Supra Shoes
description: Supra Footwear was founded in 2006 by Jim Greco, Erik Ellington and KR3W's Angel Cabada.

name: Sixteen Skateboards
description: Sixteen Skateboards was started in the mid 1990's with a little help from Invisible team rider Brian Young. Sixteen was backed by Climax Distribution and was geared towards amateurs under the age of 17 looking to make a name for themselves. Not exactly sure what happen to riders once they reached a mature age but Sixteen helped put their fair share of groms on the map including Jordan Hoffart, Spanky, Justin Case and Jeremy Holmes to name a few.

name: Speed Wheels
description: OJ Wheels was established by NHS in the 1970's with the OJ Wheels logo and original art direction coming from legendary skate artist Jim Phillips. In the 1980's, NHS introduced Slime Balls and Bullet series wheels and therefore created Speed Wheels as an umbrella for their various wheel lines.

name: Speed Metal
description: Speed Metal Bearings was founded in 1998 as a bearing division of Destructo Trucks. Originally manufactured under Giant Distribution, Speed Metal had a solid mix of riders and products including Bam Margera & Mike Vallely signature bearings. But once Giant was dissolved in the mid 2000s, Speed Metal was taken independently with a renewed drive and focus.

name: Supernatural Clothing
description: Supernatural was an early 2000s clothing company that was backed by Fobia Skate Shop out of Minneapolis, Minnesota. Supernatural team riders included Ricky Oyola, Steve Olson, Kenny Reed, Emeric Pratt, Seth McCallum, Neal Erickson, Chad Benson, Elijah Collard, Ryan Hansen and Tony Montgomery.

name: Split Clothing
description: Since 1988, Split has pioneered progressive design through rider and artist influences. Taking inspiration from Split's skate and surf team riders, including Corey Duffel and Mikala Jones. Custom fits and fine attention to detail are the Split trademark.

name: Seek Skateboards
description: Seek Skateboards was founded in 2002 by Rob Dyrdek & Josh Kalis under the banner of DNA Distribution. As the Alien Workshop team grew, Dyrdek and Kalis wanted to start something new which reflected more of their hip-hop lifestyle. The Seek team consisted of Rob Dyrdek, Josh Kalis, Colin McKay, Florentine Marfaing, Alex Carolino, Mike Taylor, Ted DeGros, Greg Myers and Bjorn Johnson, while Mike Hill & Don Pendleton provided the art direction. Unfortunately Seek called it quits at the end of 2004 due to marginal sales, at which point most riders migrated over to Alien Workshop.

name: Shake Junt
description: Shake Junt was started by Shane Heyl in the mid 2000s as a grip tape and accessory company. In being centered around a crew of homies, Shake Junt has grown into a top shelf grip brand and gained one of skateboarding's most loyal followings.

name: Supreme Skate Shop
description: In April 1994, Supreme opened its doors on Lafayette Street in downtown Manhattan and became the home of New York City skate culture. At it's core was the gang of rebellious young New York skaters and artists who became the store's staff, crew and customers. While it grew into a downtown institution, Supreme established itself as a brand known for it's quality, style and authenticity.

name: Sk8ology
description: The Sk8ology floating deck display was created after years of experimentation in how to best display the art of skateboarding while minimally impacting your wall. The combination of surgical quality acrylic and aircraft grade steel insures a lifetime of service, while the very precise fit of this system makes the decks appear to be floating off the wall, creating a museum quality aesthetic.

name: Slap Magazine
description: Slap Magazine was founded by Lance Dawes and produced through High Speed Productions as a monthly publication from 1992 through 2008. In 2008, Slap became the first established name in skateboarding to make the leap to online media. Today Slap continues to operate skateboarding's top forum while still providing exclusive interviews, photos and more.

name: Strange Notes
description: Strange Notes was founded in the late 1980s by NHS as a promotional tool to highlight their various brands, products and riders through zines and videos.

name: Sens Shoes
description: Sens was a skate shoe company that popped up for a couple years in the early 2000s. Sens had a solid team of riders and their shoe designs weren't bad for the time, but for whatever reason experienced a hard time getting placement in most shops.

name: Skateboarder Magazine
description: Skateboarder Magazine was founded in 1964 as a quarterly magazine, finally becoming a monthly publication in 1977. Over the years Skateboarder has ceased and resumed publication several times.

name: Termite Skateboards
description: Termite provides skateboards and skateboarding accessories with a focus on the 2-12 year old market. Having been in business since 1998, they operate in over 450 skate shops throughout the USA, as well as over 27 countries around the world. The team at Termite believes that every single child has the ability to make a difference and therefore, they are committed towards helping underprivileged children live the life we would want for our own children. Termite has created a special pricing structure for lower income families so that they too can enjoy the Termite experience.

name: Sk8nuts
description: Sk8nuts was a brand of skateboard hardware that offered thread locking technology.

name: Shut Skateboards
description: Shut Skateboards was started in 1986 by Bruno Musso and Rodney Smith as a reflection of the streets of New York. Bruno and Rodney, along with Alyasha Moore started out hand cutting and spraying boards, and quickly assembled one of the only all-East Coast teams. Shut made some serious noise, but was forced to call it quits in the early 90s after losing their investor. Shut has started back up a few times over the years and continues to support the growth of NYC skateboarding.

name: Skate Works
description: Skate Works is a Northern California based retail store that was started in 1988 by the Strubing family. With deep roots in the skate community, Skate Works has grown to include multiple locations, one of which houses an indoor mini-ramp. Skate Works also offers skate lessons to private individuals, groups and birthday parties.

name: Skate Designs Skateboards
description: Skate Designs Skateboards are not your typical cruisers, they're shorter in length for more practical everyday use and riding. They cruise like longboards, but offer more versatility and control. Whether you're a seasoned skater/surfer, a student in need of a campus cruiser or a suit n' tie professional, Skate Designs Skateboards are made for everyone to enjoy.

name: Shorty's Skateboards
description: Shorty's Skateboards was started in 1996 after Chad Muska left Toy Machine and Tony Buyalos offered him his own brand. Muska jumped at the opportunity, and after hand picking a team of street technicians grew Shorty's into one of the largest brands of the 1990s. Shorty's popularity reached a fevered pitch after the release of it's '98 Fulfill the Dream video, but began to dwindle in the early 2000s once rail skating began to dominate the street scene. Muska eventually left Shorty's in '06 and Tony Buyalos finally pulled the plug on Shorty's Skateboards in 2011 in order to refocus on Shorty's Hardware.

name: Stubbies
description: Stubbies was a clothing brand from the 1980's.

name: Sonic Skateboards
description: Sonic Skateboards was a San Jose, California based company that was started around '93 by 1980s skateboarders Corey O'Brien and his brother Gavin O'Brien. Simon Woodstock quickly became the team manager and rode for the team along with Tom Knox, Kit Erickon, Mike Crabtree, Jason "Wee Man" Acuna, Nanda Zipp, Tony Briseno, Louie Barletta and a few others.

name: Swatch
description: Swatch, kicked off in 1982 by Nicolas G. Hayek, today is a leading Swiss watch and jewellery maker and one of the world's most fashionable brands. The first Swatch watch appeared on the Swiss market in 1983, surprising everyone with its provocative spirit, spirited design and enormous success.

name: Surf One
description: Surf One is the manufacturer and distributor of high performance, surf inspired longboard and cruiser skateboards and wheels.

name: Sector 9 Skateboards
description: Sector 9 is the manufacturer of skateboards and longboard skateboards for the surf, skate, and snowboarding lifestyles. Sector 9's mission is to make the world a greener place through promoting skateboarding, sustainable business practices, alternative forms of transportation, and having a great time doing it.

name: Steadham Designs
description: Steadham Designs, also known as Team Steadham was a deck company started by Steve Steadham in late 1985 after leaving Powell Peralta. Steadham Designs was managed by Steve but was backed by Sure Grip International. The Steadham team included Steve Steadham, Otis Christian, Nate Cavazo, Matt Davis, Dave Hoffman, Jake Piasecki and Dave Messick.

name: Skatebordem Wheels
description: Skatebordem Wheelie Co. was an East Coast wheel brand owned by Rob Erickson in the early 1990's. Team riders included Pat Smith, Bam Margera, Chad Kramer, Kenny Hughes, Brian Seber and Donny Barley.

name: Team BK
description: Team BK is a Huntington Beach, CA. based group of sales reps which is headed by Bill Keller. Over the years, Team BK has taken countless local skaters under their wing and helped launch many a career. Team BK also produced 2 independent videos in 1998s One Small Step and 2000s A New Horizon in hopes of further strengthening their local skate scene.

name: Silverstar Skateboards
description: Silverstar Skateboards was started by Ricky Oyola after the demise of Illuminati. Although Silverstar was backed by ECU, Ricky carried over some of the Illuminati vibe and grew the Silverstar team to include himself, Matt Reason, Sergei Trudnowski, Andrew Currie, Tony Cox, Jesse Fritsch, Sean Mullendore, and Greg Harris. But unfortunately, after the owner of ECU lost all his money gambling, the company quickly ended.

name: Skate Mental
description: Skate Mental is the brainchild of skateboarder Brad Staba.

name: Skaterade
description: Skaterade was started in 2004 by Salman Agah, Scott Weber and Brian Childers as a skateboard-themed energy drink company. The name was a playful spin on the sports-themed Gatorade beverage. Although Skaterade didn't market a team, Duane Peters was an official skater/endorser. Skaterade was the first and last skate specific energy drink, and was available at retailers and skate shops across the United States before going under.

name: Sugar Skateboards
description: Sugar Skateboards, formerly known as Sugar Sports was planted in 1999 in West Los Angeles, California as an independent skateboard brand. Their mission was to create and design a brand from the ground up by skateboarders for skateboarders.

name: Sweet Skateboards
description: Sweet skateboards started in the small Swedish town of Trollhättan as a hobby project. Their idea from the beginning was to make some boards and have fun whilst using them.

name: Simple Shoes
description: Simple was a skate shoe company that was started by Eric Meyer in 1991. The brand had clean-basic silhouettes and team riders included Mark Gonzales, Julien Stranger, Carl Shipman, Gershon Mosley, Frank Hirata, Mike Crabtree, Jonas Wray, Mike Sinclair and Jason Acuna to name a few. Simple never really caught fire but steadily lasted into the early 2000's.

name: Seismic Trucks
description: Founded in 1993 by Daniel Gesmer, Seismic Skate Systems designs and manufactures high-performance boards, wheels and trucks for carving, cruising, racing, and beyond. Seismic's patented spring-loaded truck technology delivers advanced control and superior rebound with precise turning response.

name: Skechers
description: Skechers is a lifestyle footwear brand that tried marketing to skateboarders in the mid-to-late 1990's. Today, Skechers offers more than 3,000 styles and are available in over 100 countries and territories.

name: Surprise Skateboards
description: Surprise Skateboards was founded in around 2013 as a throwback brand to the 1980s, back when skateboard graphics meant something. Surprise offers artwork from various guest artist and honors the time honored tradition of silk screening their decks. Their decks are made in America and are available in a variety of wider sizes and shapes. Surprise team riders include Vince Duran, Red Bryan Whalen, Billy Roper, and Dylan Fulford.

name: Spy Sunglasses
description: Spy Optic was created by a group of action sports and motorsports enthusiasts who immersed themselves in the culture they knew best. Key founders Mark Simo, Brian Simo and Beaver Theodosakis saw what was on the market for eyewear in 1994 and wanted to make sunglasses better.

name: Skatelab
description: Established in 1997, the Skatelab is a 30,000 sq foot indoor/outdoor skatepark. The Skatelab also has a skate museum with over 5,000 vintage pieces on display and is open 7 days a week for your viewing pleasure. Skatelab's mission is to provide skateboarders of the world a great place to roll and to honor the legends, as well as preserve and present the history of skateboarding through their Skateboarding Hall of Fame Museum.

name: Shine Skateboards
description: Shine Skateboards was founded by Kevin Staab and Joe Johnson around 1992. During this time, most all decks were street oriented and Shine was started as a way to provide bigger boards for bigger skaters.

name: Strength Magazine
description: Strength was a magazine from the late 1990s to early 2000s which focused on skateboarding and the culture which surrounds it. Strength primarily featured skateboard related articles, but was infused with a fair amount of music related editorial as well. Strength also kept you up to date with skate related hardgoods, apparel and footwear reviews.

name: Tensor Trucks
description: Rodney Mullen designed and founded Tensor Trucks in 1999 under the umbrella of Dwindle Distribution. Tensor's initial key feature was a polymer baseplate slider which was said to increase slide distance, and could be replaced once worn down. Tensor has since discontinued their slider truck but have added magnesium, response and aluminum models in both basic and signature colorways.

name: Shaolin Skateboards
description: Shaolin was a clothing brand started by Jef Hartsel, but in the late 1990s was brought into the Dwindle fold and added a line of decks named Shaolin Wood. Shaolin was created as an all-amateur deck brand with team riders that included Ryan Kenreich, Daxter Lussier, Luy-Pa Sin, Luis Cruz and Sean Kelling amongst others, but only lasted a few months before being scrapped.

name: SoBe
description: SoBe is a line of Elixirs and Tea and Elixir beverages with unique flavor concoctions and herbal ingredients.

name: Supernaut Skateboards
description: Supernaut was a skateboard brand founded by Paul Sharpe and Mike Ballard around 1996. Ballard handled the majority of Supernaut's photography giving the brand more of a lifestyle and artistic vibe.

name: Sessions Clothing
description: Sessions was started in 1983 by Joel Gomez as the United States first fully dedicated snowboard shop. After growing their roots within the skate, snow, surf & music cultures, Sessions went on to introduce full clothing and outerwear divisions by the 1990s. Today, Sessions apparel is available worldwide while remaining to be a locally owned and operated brand.

name: Skate Warehouse
description: Skate Warehouse was founded in 2002 as a online retailer of action sports related hardgoods, clothing, footwear and accessories for boys, girls and kids.

name: Shorty's Hardware
description: Shorty's Hardware was founded by Tony Buyalos and April Hamrick around 1992. At a time when street skating was taking over and riser pads were no longer necessary, Shorty's stepped in and filled the need for shorter hardware, hence the name Shorty's. The brand first gained momentum after hiring a local girl named Rosa to appear in an ad, which was so well received that Rosa quickly became the Shorty's model of sorts. Over the years, Shorty's grew to include multiple hardware divisions, Shorty's Skateboards and the short lived Shorty's Snowboards. In early 2011, Shorty's ceased production of Shorty's Skateboards in order to refocus on it's hardware division.

name: Skull Skates
description: Skull Skates began in April of 1978 in Regina, Saskatchewan, Canada. The original company was Great North Country Skateboards and used a black and white Yin and Yang symbol as it's logo. Shortly after, the name was abbreviated to G.N.C. Skates, this is when P.D. designed the new logo known as Skull Skates. The original version of the logo included the letters G.N.C. on the left side of the logo, however, skaters looked at the design and immediately called it Skull Skates. It was then that it was decided to drop the G.N.C. and go with Skull.

name: Skull Candy
description: Established in 2003, Skullcandy is the manufactured of high quality headphones for your sports, music and gaming needs. Through a multitude of styles and patterns including team and athlete signature pieces, Skull Candy has the headphones or ear buds to fit your needs.

name: Tech Deck
description: Tech Deck was founded in the 1990s at the beginning of the fingerboard craze and quickly became the leading manufacturer of fingerboard skateboards and accessories. Tech Deck skateboards come equipped with metal trucks, grip tape and real skate company graphics and can be found everywhere from toy stores to grocery stores worldwide. Tech Deck also produced fingerboards for other action sports including surfing, snowboarding and bmx.

name: SuperCush Bushings
description: SuperCush is a bushing company that has been operating out of Deluxe Distribution since the 1980's.

name: Stepson Clothing
description: Stepson was an outerwear and clothing company that started in 1998 as a sister company to Drawls Clothing. Stepson team riders included Adrian Lopez, Vinnie Ponte, Danny Supa and Danny Montoya on the skate side, and had a snowboard team as well.

name: Stacks
description: In 2000, Girl Art Dump artist Michael Leon began making small runs of t-shirts and skateboards in Los Angeles under the name Commonwealth Stacks. And then in 2010, Leon partnered with Reese Forbes to launch Stacks as an authentic deck brand with a new focus on quality, style, attention to detail, and authenticity. This venture was a reunion of sorts, since the two had previously worked together on the original version of Rasa Libre back in 2003. Stacks team riders include Reese Forbes, Dani Lebron, Sebo Walker, Cameo Wilson, Barry Mansfield, Adrian Adrid, Mikey Burton and Ben Fisher.

name: Send Help
description: In 2012, The High Five was forced to change it's name and re-booted as Send Help Skateboards. Send Help is the embodiment of Todd Bratrud's art and humor and offer decks which use Midwest maple and are made in the Midwest. Team riders have included Steve Nesser, Randy Ploesser, Todd Bratrud, Marty Murawski, Horsey, Brian Heck, Steve Fauser, Justin Modica, and Preston Harper.

name: Smith Sunglasses
description: For over forty years Smith Optics has hung its hat on a heritage of authenticity, innovating products for the fresh-air addict who pushes their limits and gear daily.

name: Spitfire Wheels
description: Spitfire Wheels was started back in 1988 under the umbrella of Deluxe Distribution, and over the years has grown into skateboardings #1 wheel brand. The original bighead logo was created by Kevin Ancell and to this day remains one of skateboardings most iconic logos. Spitfire offers the largest selections of wheel sizes and durometers for any and all varieties of terrain.

name: Skate Park of Tampa
description: The Skate Park of Tampa also known as SPoT has been serving the Tampa, Florida skate community since '93 when it first opened it's doors as World Market Skate Shop. Today, SPoT hosts one of skateboarding's largest pro and amateur events with their Tampa Am and Tampa Pro contests. SPoT founder and owner Brian Schaefer also launched SPoTlight Productions as a full service event production company with the help of Rob Meronek, Ryan Clements and Jason Rothmeyer. SPoTlight events include the Damn Am series, Coastal Carnage, Maloof series contests and more.

name: SMP Clothing
description: SMP was a clothing brand from the '90s that marketed to skateboard, surf and snowboard culture. The name SMP was a acromyn for Sex, Money, Power.

name: Slave Skateboards
description: Slave or $lave Skateboards was started in 2007 as the brainchild of artist Ben Horton. The meaning behind Slave alludes to the idea that most people are controlled by or dependent on something within society and to break free of that and keep an eye on the freedoms we are sacrificing. Slave is backed and distributed through Black Box Distribution.

name: SKF Bearings
description: SKF Bearings is the Swedish based manufacturer of ball bearings and precision metal parts. Originally founded in 1907, SKF is the leading global supplier of products, solutions and services within rolling bearings. In the mid 2000s, SKF entered into the skateboard bearing market with Andrew Reynolds as a team rider.

name: Society Skateboards
description: Society was a deck company that Grind King team manager Mario Martinez started in the mid 1990s through Dark Horse Distribution, the makers of Grind King. Society had a solid team of young up-and-comers but lasted just a few years before riders started to leave, and then in an odd move changed their name to Grind King Skateboards. Shortly after the name change, Dark Horse ceased production of Grind King Skateboards to better focus on their trucks.

name: Selfish Skateboards
description: After Jereme Rogers' short-lived retirement from skateboarding in 2009, he returned in 2010 and founded Selfish Skateboards. Jereme quickly enlisted his former Plan B teammate, Brian Wenning as the second pro rider although Wenning wound up leaving the company in late 2011. Other Selfish team riders have included Aquil Brathwaite, Terell Robinson and Kyle Nicholson.

name: Silver Trucks
description: Established in 2003 and inspired by original team rider Rob Dyrdek, Silver Trucks was created to fill a void in skateboarding. A truly innovative truck designed specifically for the style of modern day technical skating with the strength to withstand the harshest treatment. The Silver product line continues to expand with the pioneering A-Class and premium S-Class trucks, top quality accessories and apparel.

name: Stereo Skateboards
description: Founded in 1992 by longtime friends Jason Lee and Chris Pastras, Stereo came as a breath of fresh air during a time that many skaters felt that skateboarding had creatively hit rock bottom. Stereo's unique and highly innovative approach to skating, with emphasis on style, originality and plain old fashion fun, was quickly embraced by the skateboard community. Stereo eventually folded in 2001 due to dwindling sales, but as fate would have it, Chris and Jason joined forces again in 2003 to re-launch Stereo as the Stereo Sound Agency.

name: Skully Bros. Mail Order
description: Skully Bros. was a mail order company from the 1990s which produced a mail order catalog and ran a lot of product heavy ads. They were based out of central California but shipped Internationally as well.

name: Sophisto Clothing
description: Sophisto Clothing, originally called Zero Sophisto was a 1990s clothing company founded by Andy Howell. Over the years, the Sophisto team included Josh Kalis, Jamie Thomas, Vinnie Ponte, Shiloh Greathouse, Karma Tsocheff, John Montesi, Billy Pepper, Pepe Martinez and Kenny Hughes amongst others. Sophisto also had an off-shoot clothing company named Expedition but never really got off the ground.

name: SML. Wheels
description: Small Wheels, also known as SML. Wheels was created by lifelong skateboarders who were friends long before business partners. Small is entirely owned and operated by everyday skateboarders including frontman James Craig. Small is about keeping it fun, simple and top notch. Small isn't concerned with dominating the world, they just want to make quality wheels that skateboarders can ride with pride.

name: Stamina Clothing
description: Stamina was an athletic inspired clothing brand founded by professional skateboarder Julio De La Cruz in the mid to late '90s. Stamina was a sister company to Neighborhood Skateboards and was distributed through Climax Distribution.

name: Superior Hardware
description: Superior Hardware was a southern California based brand from the mid 1990's. Superior was one of the first brands to offer signature hardware by offering Shorty Gonzalez Hardware and Mulder Bolts.

name: Style Eyes
description: Since 1972, Style Eyes continues to be the number one selling popular priced sport and resort eyewear brand. Their mission statement has always been to design the hottest styles, build them with the best raw materials on Earth, insist on the highest manufacturing standard and to market them at an awesome price.

name: SK8MAFIA
description: Josh Priebe and Dan Connelly originally started SK8MAFIA as a t-shirt company but quickly grew into a deck brand. Through a steady diet of technical street skating and SK8MAFIA Saturday videos, the SK8MAFIA crew helped revive tech skating in the early 2000s while simultaneously cementing their legacy. SK8MAFIA is distributed through Blitz Distribution.

name: Super Imperial Wheels
description: Super Imperial was a wheel company that popped up around the year 2000 out of the Toy Machine/Tum Yeto camp.

name: Stussy
description: Stussy was originally founded by Shawn Stussy in 1980 as a surf inspired clothing company. With roots in the surf, skate & music scenes, Stussy gained a loyal following and helped pave the way for what would later become known as "street wear". In the early 2000s, Stussy introduced a skate team, although the program only lasted a few short years. Today, Stussy remains a surf inspired company, but has grown into one of the most sought after brands across the globe.

name: Terror Skateboards
description: Terror Skateboards was a pool shredder deck company founded by Glenn Wagner in the early 2000's. Based out of San Diego, Terror team riders included Slob, Mike Crespino, Justin Hindery, Chris Adams, Jamie Weller, Sleazy Steve, Mike Smolik and Sperm.

name: Street Rod
description: Street Rod was a clothing brand from the 1990's which around 1995 became known as Street Rod Kustom Klothing. Street Rod was backed by Climax Distribution but ventured out into sponsoring snowboarders, surfers, bands and more. Street Rod skaters included Jamie Thomas, Tommy Budjanec, Chad Bartie, Jeff King, Daxter Lussier, Ozzy Alvarez, Jason Bickford, Jeff Hart, Matt Dyck and Rudy Sisson.

name: Speed Clothing
description: Speed Clothing, also known as Speed Wearables and Speed Inc., was a mid 1990s apparel company based just outside of Los Angeles, California. Speed Clothing had a solid team consisting of Eric Ricks, Daewon Song, June Cate, Erik Villalobos and Frankie Mata, but was cut short due to disagreements between the owners Thaddeus and Alberto.

name: Speed Demons
description: Speed Demons is a bearing company that was started by World Industries in the mid 1990s. Speed Demons bearings became an easy option for the riders of World's various companies, but quickly grew to include wheels in addition to bearings, causing issues for some riders. Today, Speed Demons focus on providing quality entry level products including bearings, wheels, decks, trucks and accessories.

name: Struggle Skateboards
description: Struggle Skateboards was founded by Ruben Najera in 2005 as a testament to his many hardships in life. After finding himself homeless, Ruben relied on previous work experience at a skateboard manufacturer and became determined to make something in his life work. And through perseverance, dedication and a positive state of mind, Ruben has pushed Struggle Skateboards above and beyond what many had doubted.

name: Stance Magazine
description: Stance was a magazine from the '90s that mixed skateboarding, snowboarding and music.

name: Shuvit
description: Shuvit was a clothing and deck company that started as a division of Vision Skateboards. Shuvit ran from the 1990s to early 2000s with team riders that included Chris Gentry, Mad Dog, Jamie Smith, Donovan Dresti, Ave Bunachita, Nate McGlone and Jean-Louis Besancon.

name: Sub Zero Skate Shop
description: Sub Zero was a Philadelphia, Pennsylvania based skateboard and snowboard shop that operated throughout the 1990s. Sub Zero first made a name for itself with the release of their 1994 Real Life video and boasted a team that included Ricky Oyola, Fred Gall, Matt Reason, Sergei Trudnowski, AJ Mazzu, Stevie Williams, Eric Ruwadi and Damian Smith.

name: Shaft Wood
description: Shaftwood was a early to mid 1990s deck brand which was founded by Mike McGill and run by Steve Siaz. Known early on as simply Shaft, the brand sponsored the likes of Matt Mumford, Kanten Russell, Mike Rafter and Peter McBride, but around 1995 switched gears with a new team consisting of young up and comers Rob Gonzalez, Mako Urabe, Malcolm Watson, Domingo Vasquez and Rich Colwell.

name: Sheep Shoes
description: Sheep was a playful shoe company founded in 1996 by Sole Technology, the makers of Etnies and eS Footwear. Sheep was geared more toward price points and with an initial team of Ed Templeton, Laban Pheidias and Mike Manzoori found an instant following. And by utilizing synthetic materials, Sheep also discovered the untapped vegan friendly skate shoe market. But due to importing costs, Sheep shoes weren't as cheap as originally intended and therefore the brand was discontinued.

name: Team Pain
description: Team Pain is the only custom design/build company in the industry, specializing in three mediums: concrete skate parks, wood skate parks and specialty structures for professional riders. Team Pain is comprised of skaters who possess extensive design and build knowledge gleaned from years of personal experience. This knowledge allows them to create skate structures that inspire a skater to constantly improve his or her skills.

name: Magnusson Designs
description: Magnusson Designs was a division of Sure Grip that started in around 1986. After leaving Uncle Wiggley, Tony Magnusson contemplated riding for Steadham Designs, but was instead offered his own division through Sure Grip. Magnusson Designs made some noise in '87 with the introduction of it's insanely deep "Hell Concave" and was where Tony Magnusson first worked with Mike Ternasky. Then in 1988, Magnusson and Ternasky left Magnusson Designs to start H-Street Skateboards.

name: Official
description: Founded in 2007, Official is the manufacturer of premium headwear, apparel and accessories. Originally known as Official Crown of Laurel, Official draws their influences from skate, street and DIY fashion to create a line of unique pieces. Official team riders have included Austyn Gillette, John Cardiel, Stefan Janoski, Rodrigo TX, Jose Rojo, Miles Silvas and Marquise Henry.

name: NHS Distribution
description: Based in Northern California, NHS is the manufacturer and distributor of Santa Cruz, Creature, Flip, Independent, Ricta, Mob, Krux, OJ Wheels, Designarium, Bullet, Nor Cal, Bell, Crime and Strange Notes products.

name: Lethol Skateboards
description: Lethol Skateboards also known as Lethol Elements Inc. was a deck company founded by Eli Stella and Zach Smith in 1997. The Lethol team included Brad Hayes, Justin Reynolds, Anthony Carney, Adil Dyani, Guy Hartley, Aaron Yeager, Brent Kronmueller, Jason Masse, Marcus Bandy, Jeremy Patton, Steve Weber, Rich Cooley and Robert Tempraseut but eventually called it quits in 2001. Eli Stella later bought Axion Footwear and helped form Mastermind Distribution.

name: Omega Trucks
description: Omega was a truck company that was launched in the year 2000 out of Newport Beach, California. Omega Trucks were previously known as Webb Trucks, but changed their truck design and name in hopes of jump starting the brand. Omega team riders included Billy Marks and Anthony Carney.

name: Limpies
description: Limpies Clothing was a 1990s apparel brand that was founded by skate photographer Chip Morton. Limpies took the humorous approach through their logo and advertisements, and had some good apparel pieces which rivaled the Ghetto Wear's of the time. The brand didn't have an official team but did hook up a few guys with gear here and there.

name: Liberty Skateboards
description: Liberty Skateboards was a brand started by Mike Smith in the late 1980s, and was one of the earliest brands to be distributed through World Industries. Mike Smith and Todd Congelliere were the company pro's and Chad Fernandez, Erik Villalobos, Ofer Moses, Erik Ricks and Ron Resurreccion were a few of the company ams. Liberty went in and out of business multiple times depending on if Mike had money to run more boards or not, but officially called it quits around the mid 1990s.

name: Motto Grip Tape
description: Motto Grip Tape was started in 2003 as a community based design grip tape company. How this works is, independent artists can submit design ideas which are then evaluated by Motto's skate team and the broader Motto community for conversion into laser cut or printed skateboard grip tape. If an artists design is chosen, they will then receive royalties or can choose to have a percentage of design sales go to a non-profit organization.

name: Link Footwear
description: Link Footwear was a early 2000s shoe company out of France which started advertising in American magazines for a brief time. Link had a solid team and ties to the Cliche camp, but appeared to be pretty short lived.

name: MIA Skate Shop
description: MIA Skate Shop was started by Ed Selego and Chris Williams (a Florida sales rep) as a way to better serve the Miami Beach, Florida skate community. MIA first opened it's doors on July 4th, 2003 in South Beach, and has since added a second Sunny Isles Beach location.

name: Life Extention
description: Life Extention, also known as L.E. Skateboards was founded by Nick Trapasso and Pat Pasquale in early 2012. Trapasso brought in his old Bootleg boss J Strickland to provide art direction, and with the distribution of Blitz hit the ground running. The name Life Extention and abbreviation L.E. comes from the movie Vanilla Sky, although the spelling of extension differs.

name: Local Motion
description: Founded in 1977, Local Motion is a clothing brand with deep roots in the surf community and surfing lifestyle. In the mid 1980s, Local Motion ventured into the skate community with Rob Roskopp as the face of the brand. Today, Local Motion continues to produce an extensive apparel and accessory line for men and women in addition to hand shaped surfboards.

name: Lifeblood Skateboards
description: Lifeblood Skateboards was established in around 2010 with the idea of skating any and all terrain. And with a group of transition rippers including Kevin Kowalski, Cody Lockwood, Mason Merlino, Dalton Dern, and Mark Scott, Lifeblood has carved a niche for itself and gained quite the loyal following.

name: Momentum Wheels
description: Momentum was started back in 1998 as a Canadian based wheel brand, with most of it's artwork and creative coming from artist Andrew Pommier. A few current and former Momentum riders include Chris Haslam, Rick McCrank, Moses Itkonen, Arto Saari, Rob Boyce, Andrew Brophy, Jose Rojo, Brandon Biebel, Willow, Morgan Smith, Keegan Sauder and Magnus Hanson.

name: Lost Enterprises
description: Lost began in 1985 when Matt Biolos and a bunch of school friends were into snowboarding at Mt. Baldy, skateboarding at the Pipeline in Upland, and surfing in Dana Point. They weren't too worried about winning this football game or that contest. They were "Team Lost". Thus the name ...Lost scribbled on books, t-shirts, benches, tables and eventually clothing and more.

name: Nike 6.0
description: The Nike 6.0 brand defines innovation and embodies the creativity of youth, united by action. Nike 6.0 delivers footwear and apparel to support the new generation of action sports athletes who are changing the worlds of surf, snow, ski, BMX, wake and moto. Their unlimited potential and contagious energy deliver the future through performance and lifestyle.

name: Matix
description: Matix was founded by pro skateboarders Daewon Song and Tim Gavin, tired of clothes disintegrating upon contact with concrete. Since 1998, all Matix garments are designed and constructed for durability. Never ones to be closed-minded, Matix has also naturally embraced the likes of surf and snow talent as family members equally dedicated to the cause of progress.

name: Nobyl Skateboards
description: Based out of South Carolina, Nobyl Skateboards is a art driven deck company which offers quality boards at a price point level.

name: Negative One Grip
description: Negative One is professional rider tested and approved grip tape brand that is available in a wide variety of colors and prints. Negative One is formulated with a kinder grip surface and is designed to be tear resistant, wear resistant and will not crack on folding.

name: Media Skateboards
description: Media Skateboards was a Southern California based brand started in '96. Media operated prior to '96 under the name Bike Skateboards.

name: Nash Skateboards
description: Nash Manufacturing first started as a water ski company, but in the 1960s introduced hardwood skateboards once sidewalk surfing began to grow in popularity. Nash Skateboards really took off during the 1980s skateboard boom by offering an extensive line of price-point completes with all the plastic bells and whistles of the time. These boards and component parts were total garbage but were readily available and served as a entry level skateboard for the masses.

name: NSA
description: NSA was a acronym for the National Skateboard Association. The NSA was founded by Frank Hawk in the mid 1980s as a professional counterpart to the California Amateur Skateboard League(CASL). Throughout the 1980s to early 1990s, contests were king and NSA played host to the majority of these high-profile events. But as contests became less and less important, the association began to struggle and eventually called it quits.

name: NMB Bearings
description: NMB Precision Bearings became popular among skateboarders in the early 1980s due to their unbelievably smooth ride and reasonable price. The NMB team was comprised of a who's who of skateboarding with the likes of Christian Hosoi, Allen Losi, Neil Blender, Tony Alva and Mike Smith.

name: New Balance Numeric
description: New Balance Numeric, also known as NB# is the skate division of athletic footwear giant New Balance. Originally launched in 2012 through a licensing agreement with Black Box Distribution, the New Balance Numeric line offers clean silhouettes in a wider array of colors and technical materials. New Balance Numeric team riders have included PJ Ladd, Arto Saari, Levi Brown, Tom Karangelov, Jordan Taylor, Tyler Surrey, Jack Curtin, and more.

name: NSI
description: NSI was an action sports video production company from the 1980s. NSI created videos for most of the bigger NSA contests and more.

name: Life's A Beach
description: Life's a Beach was a clothing brand from the 1980s which was inspired by the surf and skate communities of the time, producing lots of loud prints and graphics. A few Life's a Beach team riders included Mark Gonzales, Bill Danforth, Ron Allen, Dave Crabb, Jamie Mosberg and Mike Vallely. In 1988, Life's a Beach introduced a sub-division deck brand under the name B.B.C., which was a acronym for Bad Boy Club.

name: One West Clothing
description: One West was a 1990s clothing brand which was based out of Southern California's Inland Empire area.

name: Menace Skateboards
description: Kareem Campbell founded Menace Skateboards not long after his appearance in World Industries' 1993 New World Order video. After a brief stint on Blue Skateboards, Kareem returned to the Dwindle fold and launched Menace and later on Axion Shoes. In 1998 Menace was forced to change its name due to a trademark conflict with a jeans brand also named Menace. The brand was then re-named and re-launched as All City Skateboards.

name: NC Board Shop
description: NC Board Shop is a northern California based retail store. NC also had a clothing line in the late 90's to early 2000's called NC Clothing.

name: Maple Skateboards
description: Maple Skateboards was started in 1994 by Charlie Watson of Watson Wood Shop and ex-& team manager Chris Capparo. Maple turned out more than a few amazing videos over the years and launched many a career but eventually went under as riders began leaving and competition increased. The original Maple team consisted of Marc Johnson, Thom Hornung, Joe McClellan, Chad Muska, Paul Smith and Nick Bell, plus Kien Lieu and Jason Carney who both left Planet Earth to help launch Maple. Ed Dominick was the brand's staff photographer which also helped in landing Maple's riders on the pages of countless Transworld's.

name: Mada Clothing
description: Mada Clothing was started in 2004 by Vince De La Pena and Shane La Voie after leaving Ezekiel, a brand in which they both founded in the early 90's. With Vince and Shane being Christian in faith, the name Mada came from the backwards spelling of Adam. Mada was meant to be a bit edgier, along the lines of Volcom, but to not be over distributed like most brands within the surf and lifestyle industry. Mada's foundation was built on using only the best fabrics and fits, but ended up calling it quits around 2008.

name: Milk Skateboards
description: Milk Skateboard Goods or MSG was a deck company that was started by Christian Hosoi in the early 1990s. Milk had their own vibe with deck graphics primarily being done by Christian, Ron Chatman, Mark Gonzales, and Ivan(Christian's dad). Milk team riders included Christian Hosoi, Ron Chatman, Gershon Mosley, Richard Mulder, Jose Cerda, Jake Burns, Tony Briseno, George Morales, Anthony Carney, Ian Hatley, Yoski Obayashi, Dave Griffin, Travis Kolt, Melvin Reynolds, and Danny Highfill.

name: Mad Circle Skateboards
description: Mad Circle was started by Steve Douglas in around 1993 as a sub division of New Deal. Mad Circle was headed creatively by Justin Girard, and released two classic videos in Let The Horns Blow and 5ive Flavors, but had it's plug pulled by Giant Distribution around 1999. Mad Circle team riders included Mike Cao, Scott Johnston, Rob Welsh, Cairo Foster, Bobby Puleo, Tas Pappas and Karl Watson to name a few.

name: Obey
description: Shepard Fairey first started his OBEY sticker campaign in 1989 as an experiment in phenomenology. The OBEY sticker attempts to stimulate curiosity and bring people to question both the sticker and their relationship with their surroundings. Today, OBEY produces limited edition art prints, collectibles and a line of Obey Clothing and accessories.

name: Monster Energy Drink
description: Monster Energy Drink is all about the things you care about, the people at Monster dreamed of being pro athletes, musicians and living the life. They know it takes encouragement and support to make that dream a reality, so they created the Monster Army to back the next generation of pros. Led by it's athletes, musicians, employees, distributors and fans, Monster is...a lifestyle in a can.

name: Molotov Skateboards
description: Molotov was a deck brand out of Minneapolis, MN. that was founded by brothers Matt & Andy Schansberg in 1989. The brand was heavily art driven through simple graphics, ads and zines, and gained instant local support. Molotov had a few fake pro's whose names were picked out of the phone book, but also housed some legit talent including Jahmal Williams, Mike Graham and Darren Navarrette. In 1993, Molotov relocated to California where they joined up with Small Room, but once Small Room folded in '94, Molotov wasn't far behind.

name: Lucky Lucy's
description: Lucky Lucy's was a Carlsbad, California based mail order company which operated during the late 1990s to early 2000s.

name: Natural Skateboards
description: Natural Skateboards was a mid 1990's deck company based out of the midwest. Natural was distributed through Select but only lasted a few short years before calling it quits. Natural team riders included Alphonzo Rawls, Danny Meyer, Bucky Lasek, Jason Rogers and Jeff Chase.

name: Lucero Ltd. Skateboards
description: Lucero Ltd. Skateboards was founded by John Lucero in the mid to late 1980s. The brand was originally known as John Lucero Skates and was distributed through Prime Time Dist., but changed it's name to Lucero Ltd. when it moved over to NHS in 1988. After NHS, Lucero moved the brand again to Vision where it ended. Shortly after, Lucero went to independently start Black Label Skateboards.

name: Nesta Brand Clothing
description: Nesta Brand is a clothing line with a unique blend of street wear and reggae inspiration. The label's purpose is simple and innovative; to create authentic designs through musical inspiration. With strong support from musicians, Nesta is one of the most recognized brands in the reggae industry. Founded in Southern California in 2000, Nesta Brand Clothing has since grown to include flagship stores as far as Japan, as well as, adopted an innovative approach unforeseen in the industry.

name: Nice Skate Shoes
description: Nice Skate Shoes, also known as NSS first started producing shoes back in 1994. With a skate team in tow, NSS set out to make a name for themselves, but for whatever reason never caught on with the core skate audience. In the early 2000s, NSS also launched a short lived sub-division under the name EVOS Footwear. These days, NSS shoes are offered in sizes from toddler to adult for men, women & kids, and are available exclusively through K-Mart and Sears stores.

name: Lowland Kings
description: Lowland Kings is a deck and apparel company that was founded in early 2015 by Sammy Baptista and Andrew Pott. Lowland Kings was created as a reflection of the various skateboarding and street cultures across the world. Lowland Kings team riders include Sammy Baptista, Andrew Pott, Shmatty Chaffin, Richie Amador, Collin Slew, Jacob Walder and Rahn Handcox.

name: Landyachtz
description: Landyachtz was started in the fall of 1997 by Michael  Perreten and Thomas Edstrand. Their goal was to make the best boards on the market through innovative designs and a focus on durable products which they still strive for today. Landyachtz is a leading manufacturer of longboard skateboards for use in downhill racing.

name: Neff Headwear
description: Neff Headwear was born being the first authentic core snow and skate headwear company in the game. Neff is supported by some of the biggest snowboarders and skateboarders in the world as well as key personalities and DJ's across the globe. Neff is about having fun and bringing new vibe and steeze to the game.

name: Nature Hardware
description: Nature is a company based out of Indiana which specializes in skateboard hardware, bearings, grip tape and apparel. Founded in 2008, Nature has an extensive group of team riders in addition to contributing artists including Michael Sieben, Matt Cipov, Patrick Jilbert, Don Pendleton and Todd Bratrud.

name: Navigator Trucks
description: Navigator is a truck brand that specializes in trucks for longboard and downhill skateboarding.

name: Nike SB
description: Nike Skateboarding was launched in 2002 with an initial team of Richard Mulder, Danny Supa, Reese Forbes, and Gino Iannucci. The idea behind Nike SB was to produce limited edition colorways with creative stories behind the shoes. The idea worked, and got sneaker collectors clamoring, and every other shoe company mimicking limited edition colorways. Today, Nike SB still manufacturers limited edition colorways in addition to a full line of footwear, apparel and accessories.

name: Mountain Dew
description: Mountain Dew has been a proud supporter of skateboarding for years through it's Action Sports Dew Tour and Free Flow Amateur Tours. In around 1997, Mountain Dew entered into uncharted territory and signed Paul Rodriguez to become the skateboard face of the brand. Also around this time, Mountain Dew launched Am Force as a group of amateur skateboarders handpicked by Paul Rodriguez himself.

name: Organika Skateboards
description: Organika Skateboards was founded by Karl Watson and Troy Morgan with the vision of promoting the positive sides of skateboarding. Coming from the ground up, Organika is known worldwide as the pulse of the eco-friendly skateboard community. With leaders such as Adelmo Jr, Quim Cardona, Zach Lyons, and Walker Ryan, Organika seeks to bring a positive message through their skateboarding.

name: OJ Wheels
description: OJ Wheels were first introduced in the mid 1980's under Santa Cruz's Speed Wheels banner of brands. OJ II's as they were originally known sponsored some of the times most relevant skaters including Natas Kaupas, Eric Dressen and Christian Hosoi. Hosoi was even give his own line of Hosoi Rockets wheels. Santa Cruz eventually pulled the plug on the OJ line in the late 1980's, but in around 2010 decided to give it another go.

name: MCD Clothing
description: MCD Clothing was started in the late 1980s by surfer Michael Tomson as a subdivision of Gotcha. The name MCD is an acronym for More Core Division and embodies a behavior and attitude without boundaries. MCD has since separated itself from Gotcha, but continues to grow it's roots within the surf, skateboard and snowboard communities.

name: Legion Skateboards
description: Legion Skateboards was a Santa Barbara, California based deck brand that was started in the late 1990s. Legion team riders included Ben Kendall, Frankie Hill, Pablo Favela and Damian Bravo.

name: Neighborhood Skateboards
description: Neighborhood was a deck company founded by Julio De La Cruz after parting ways with New Deal in around 1993. Neighborhood had a heavy Latin vibe and Los Angeles theme, mostly due to the artwork and direction of Mark Gonzales' cousin Ernie Mendoza. In 1996, Neighborhood introduced Especial as a sister deck brand, but was fairly short lived lasting only about a year. In the later 1990's, Neighborhood moved under the umbrella of Climax Distribution where Julio also launched Stamina Clothing. Julio eventually tried operating Neighborhood independently of Climax but went under as the industry shrank.

name: Metropolitan Wheels
description: Metropolitan Wheels was a mid '90s brand out of the Deluxe camp. Metropolitan was more of an East Coast division with the majority of it's team being from the East Coast and their ads featuring the NYC photography of Ari Marcopoulos.

name: Manna Skateboards
description: Manna was a Christian based skateboard brand from the late '90s to early '00s.

name: Nicotine Wheels
description: Nicotine was a 1990s wheel company that was backed by East Coast Urethane. Nicotine supported a ton of East Coast skaters including Ricky Oyola, Andy Stone, Chris Hall, Pepe Martinez, Matt Willigan, Greg Harris, Panama Dan, Bucky Lasek, Brian Howard, Mike Frazier, Paul Zitzer, Troy Chasen, and Derek Krasauskas.

name: Ollie Pop
description: Ollie Pop is a bubble gum company made up of skateboarders, snowboarders, and surfers alike. Ollie Pop is offered in many different flavors and inside Ollie Pop you can find stickers from companies like Volcom, DC, Circa, Independent, Pig, Consolidated, Girl, Ricta and hundreds of others.

name: Monkey Business
description: Monkey Business was founded as a hardware & grip tape company around the year 2000. The company saw early success through their Monkey Grip line of grip tape in which each rider was given a signature monkey silhouette die-cut logo. In addition to Monkey Grip, Monkey Nuts hardware, Monkey Balls bearings, and Monkey Poop wax, the company also went on to launch a short lived deck division under the name Monkey Stix.

name: Mighty Healthy
description: Mighty Healthy is a fresh, modern incarnation of a classic young men's apparel brand. Good, bad and unapologetic, it embraces the tried and true spirit of progressive street. Taking a modern, optimistic approach to basic fabrics and silhouettes, Mighty Healthy t-shirts, jeans, sweatshirts and jackets are outstanding pieces for everyday wear.

name: Monster Skate
description: Monster Skate was a mailorder business from the late 1990s to early 2000s. The Monster Skate website featured lots of skate content including photos, videos, trick tips and more.

name: Loyal Laces
description: Loyal Laces is a skateboard specific shoelace brand which offer quality shoelaces in dozens of colors, styles and patterns. Loyal Laces are made in the U.S.A. and are available at finer skate shops everywhere.

name: Listen Skateboards
description: Listen Skateboards was founded by Danny Montoya and Rob Gonzalez in the early to mid 2000s. The two longtime friends ran Listen out of Montoya's back house for years before taking the brand to Syndrome in 2010, where it was tweaked and re-launched as BLVD Skateboards. Listen pros included Rob Gonzalez, Danny Montoya, Rodrigo Peterson and Brian Brown in addition to a solid team of technical amateurs.

name: Lib Technologies
description: Lib Technologies was started in 1989 as a snowboard company, but by the early 2000s had grown to include a full line of Lib Tech skateboard decks. As with their snowboards, Lib Tech continually experiments with new deck materials and constructions in hopes of creating longer lasting decks. All of Lib Tech's decks are hand made in the USA at Mervin Manufacturing, the world's most environmental board factory.

name: Oakley
description: Oakley, Inc. is a sport and lifestyle brand, driven to ignite the imagination through the fusion of art and science. Building on its legacy of innovative, market-leading optical technology, the company manufactures and distributes high performance sunglasses, prescription lenses and frames, goggles, apparel, footwear, and accessories.

name: New Deal Skateboards
description: New Deal Skateboards was started by Andy Howell, Steve Douglas and Paul Schmitt in 1990 after sensing a street skating revolution was looming. New Deal was fronted by Howell's graffiti inspired graphics, and through multiple groundbreaking videos went on to become one of the early 90s most influential companies. New Deal also gave birth to Giant Distribution, but was forced to call it quits around the end of 2002.

name: Mack Dawg Productions
description: Mack Dawg Productions was formed by Mike McEntire in 1988 as a skateboard video production company. MDP's first production was the video Sick Boys and was seen as one of the most revolutionary videos of it's time. Soon after, McEntire was contacted to help produce the H-Street video Hokus Pokus with the late Mike Ternasky. After that, Mack Dawg Productions shifted its focus to the documentation of snowboarding where it has remained since 1990.

name: Ninja Bearings
description: Only NiNjA Bearings are made in Japan at the world's most advanced bearing manufacturing facility using state of the art materials. NiNjA Bearing engineers have customized the NiNjA line to excel at skateboarding demands including unmatched speed, strength, and superior weight-bearing impact capabilities. NiNjA team riders have included Karl Watson, Ryan Sheckler, Kyle Berard, Shin Okada, Austen Seaholm, Junichi Arahata and Souichiro Nakajima to name a few.

name: Mercury Trucks
description: Mercury was a truck brand which was founded by Chris Miller and Jamie Thomas in the later 1990s out of Atlas Distribution. Atlas launched Mercury around the same time as Tornado Wheels in an effort to attract and sponsor riders outside of the Planet Earth and Rhythm camps. Mercury trucks were ridden and designed by Jamie Thomas, Chany Jeanguenin and Caine Gayle with additional team riders including Adrian Lopez, Charlie Wilkins and Kenny Anderson.

name: Mini Logo Skateboards
description: Mini Logo Skateboards was created as a price point brand for Powell Peralta. Mini Logo manufactures quality decks, wheels, bearings, hardware and grip tape in an effort to keep skateboarding affordable, but without having to sacrifice quality and performance.

name: Lordz Wheels
description: Lordz Wheels was a French wheel company which was founded by Stephane Theng in 1999. The original Lordz team consisted of Luy Pa Sin, Stephane Larance, and J.B. Gillet, but grew to include Alex Carolina, Bastien Salabanzi, William Phan, Florentine Marfaing and Thibaud Fradin amongst others.

name: Lowcard Magazine
description: Lowcard is a San Francisco, California based zine/magazine which was started around 2003. Through their celebration of transition skating and the more hesh aspects of skateboarding, Lowcard was created a cult following of loyal supporters.

name: Ocean Pacific
description: Ocean Pacific was started as a surfboard brand back in the 1960s, but branched out to include Ocean Pacific apparel in 1972. The OP clothing line became instantly popular within the surf community and later gained mainstream acceptance in the 1980s through their bright patterns and relaxed surf vibe. Today, OP clothing is available exclusively at Walmart stores and still embodies the same surf culture it was founded upon.

name: November Clothing
description: November was clothing company from the early 2000s that was geared towards the handrail chomper. November was backed by Projects Distribution(the makers of Apollo Backpacks) and had a team that included Matt Mumford, Erik Ellington, Alex "Trainwreck" Gall, Ben Gilley and Gareth Stehr, but lasted just a few short years.

name: LRG Clothing
description: L-R-G, also known as Lifted Research Group was started in 1999 as a company designed to overthrow the masses by it's influence. Their slogan is simple "underground inventive, overground effective".

name: Liberty Board Shop
description: Liberty Board Shop was a Brea, California based retail store that was founded by Matt Pindroh in 1993. Liberty was one of Southern California's premiere skate shops, with a knowledgeable staff and highly respected team. Liberty also housed quite a bit of skate memorabilia including bricks from Embarcadero/Brooklyn Banks, and more, but unfortunately was forced to close it's doors in 2014.

name: Ol' 84 Clothing
description: Ol' 84 Clothing was a small clothing company with gritty, western image and style.

name: Ogio
description: Michael Pratt fostered the prodigy that is OGIO, and with intuition and a little financial reinforcement spawned the young company's venture into gear bag design. With a die-hard crew and collective insight, OGIO gathered top athletes from across the nation from moto, BMX, skate, snow, and surf to produce Team OGIO. Together OGIO designers and athletes unite to create specific action sports packs. This cutting-edge company has single handedly revolutionized bag design and there is more where that came from.

name: Messiah Skateboards
description: Conceived by 1980s skate legend Steve Steadham, Messiah Skateboards was a Christian based deck, wheel and apparel brand which gave glory to Jesus Christ through religious deck graphics.

name: Life Skateboards
description: Life Skateboards was founded by Ron Allen and Mike Ternasky as a sub division of H-Street once the H-Street brand/team grew out of control. Life was full of heavy hitters and made a mark for itself with the release of it's A Soldier's Story video, but after Ternasky left H-Street to start Plan B in 1991, and Ron Allen left Life to start Fun, the company began to struggle and ultimately crumbled.

name: Loser Machine
description: Loser Machine was founded in 2009 by Adrian Lopez as an apparel brand which could reflect the skate and surf cultures of the 1960s and 1970s. But more importantly, Loser Machine was started as a place where chopper and hot rod fans could find a common ground with today's dirtbag skaters. Loser Machine is the manufacturer of quality motorcycle helmets, gloves, custom apparel, t-shirts, headwear, accessories, and skateboard decks.

name: Monster Trucks
description: Monster Trucks was a short lived brand that launched out of Giant Distribution toward the end of 2000. Around this time, Giant was trying to capitalize on the success they saw with Destructo and introduced both Monster and Destroyer truck brands. Monster was marketed as a more durable truck with specifically designed bushing seats to prevent bushing blowouts, but was scrapped after falling short in sales.

name: Nocturnal Skate Shop
description: Nocturnal Skate Shop is a retail store front that was founded by Kerry Getz in the year 2000. Located in Philadelphia, PA., Getz started Nocturnal along with partner Tim Quinn as a way to further grow and help the skateboard progression in the city.

name: Natural Koncept
description: Natural Koncept is a small skateboarding company based in Los Angeles, with roots in Hawaii. Natural Koncept prides itself in having a well-balanced team from across the country, who all come together to create one diversified family of rippers. The brand's art direction and graphics are by the legendary graffiti artist Katch 1.

name: Nixon Watches
description: Nixon Watches was started as a frustration at a lack of quality watches that simultaneously do the talking for you and deliver what you need in various high stress work and play environments has grown into a network of athletes, rock stars, retailers, and dedicated loyalists that bring Nixon products to market. Nixon hand picks riders that are leaders in their sports and works with this elite group to make sure their perspectives contribute to a single unified expression: team designed, custom built.

name: Network 17 Skate Shop
description: Network 17 was a Costa Mesa, California based skate shop that operated from the late 1990s to early 2000s. Being centrally located in Costa Mesa and just around the corner from Giant Distribution, Network 17 sponsored the who's who of skateboarding and was one of the early skate shops to also operate a website and mailorder business.

name: Omit Apparel
description: Omit Apparel was founded by Chris Cole in 2011 after parting ways with Fallen. Chris decided he'd rather create a brand with his own ideas than seek out a new apparel sponsor. And through attention to detail, Omit offers a unique line that embodies Chris' rock and roll style.

name: Little Paw Skateboards
description: Little Paw is a New York based skateboard brand that was started in the early 2000s. Little Paw amateur and flow team riders include Conner Smallwood, Kevin Chen, Michael Moroch, Mike Wu, Jarrod Grammel, Sky Lai and Kyle Ke among others.

name: Mystery Skateboards
description: Mystery Skateboards was started by Black Box Dist. in the fall of 2003 as a sister company to Zero. Mystery was originally supposed to be Matt Mumford's company, but when that didn't work out, the company was pitched to Adrian Lopez. For years, Mystery had a black & white theme that played through their graphics, ads, and video, but in 2010 introduced color to the company. In 2014, as Black Box began to dissolve, Adrian Lopez decided to take Mystery on his own and operate it independently.

name: Legacy Skateboards
description: Legacy Skateboards was founded by Matt Mumford in around 2004 under the umbrella of Dwindle Distribution. Mumford added well rounded skaters like himself to the Legacy team including Pat Duffy, Justin Strubing, Shane Cross, Andrew Allen, Peter Watkins and Mark Gutterman, but had the plug pulled in 2005 due to budget cuts at Dwindle.

name: Lucky
description: Lucky Bearings was started in the mid 1990s as the manufacturer of removable crown bearings & hardware. Then in around 2002, introduced a Lucky Wheels division as well as a Lucky Skateboards division with team riders Henry Sanchez, Spencer Fujimoto, Alfonso Fernandez, Steve Kindle, Danny Wallace, Jack Curtin and Eric Brockman. Unfortunately, both the wheel and wood divisions were fairly short lived. Today, Lucky Bearings are available through Strange Bird Distribution and remain a trusted source for bearings, hardware and grip tape.

name: Madrid Skateboards
description: Jerry and Jeff Madrid formed their company, Madrid Skateboards in 1976, which became incorporated in 1984. Madrid skateboards has since become Madrid Pro Designs, and has done nothing but achieve a well-respected and well-deserved name in the skateboard and surf industry. Madrid Pro Designs still uses their traditional recipe for making skateboards, with a few modern improvements here and there.

name: New School Skateboards
description: New School was a skateboard brand from the mid 90's.

name: New Era
description: New Era Cap Company Inc., the largest and fastest growing headwear manufacturer in the United States, has an 88-year-old tradition of creating quality products that transcend time, culture, sport and fashion.
