Although New Era is rooted in sports heritage as the official on-field cap of Major League Baseball, they have evolved into a brand that can be seen on the runways of Paris during Fashion Week and in hundreds of music videos on MTV. New Era is seen as an iconic brand that celebrities, entertainers, musicians and athletes are seen wearing today.

name: Mob Grip
description: Mob Grip is grip tape with hundreds of barely visible perforations which allow air to escape for bubble proof application. Mob Grip also has a super sticky adhesive that will not peel up in extreme heat or cold and is available in dozens of printed and co-branded graphics.

name: Nation Skateboards
description: Nation Skateboards was started in 1996 as a board brand for Strength Magazine. Steve Saiz was the brand manager and Jason Rothmeyer was the brand's pro/team manager. Nation had a solid squad and was first to bring Jake Brown to the United States, but closed up shop after just two short years.

name: Hurricane Trucks
description: Hurricane Alloy was a late 1990s to early 2000s truck brand that was a subsidiary of Gullwing Trucks. With Gullwing's long history in vert skating, Hurricane was introduced as being primarily street based and boasted a team of Willy Santos, Dayne Brummet, Dave Coyne, Alphonzo Rawls, Chad Knight, Toebee Parkhurst, Buster Halterman and Frank Hirata to name a few.

name: Jimmy'z Clothing
description: Jimmy'z Clothing was started in 1984 by Jim Ganzer as a surf inspired men's apparel brand. Jimmy'z saw tremendous success from the start after being embraced by the surf and skate communities of the 1980s, and by 1986 grew to include clothing for men, women and children alike. Jimmy'z was widely known for it's loud/wild prints and unique adjustable velcro waistband. But as the times and styles began to change, Jimmy'z lost it's relevancy in the marketplace and eventually called it quits. Then in 2011, Ganzer decided to start things back up and give the brand a second chance.

name: K-Swiss
description: Since it's inception in Van Nuys, CA. in 1966, K-Swiss has rooted itself in California sports with hopes of becoming the most inspiring brand on the market. K-Swiss' heritage is in tennis footwear but has grown into a lifestyle, running, training, nautical, and free-running footwear brand. In 2009, K-Swiss signed Greg Lutzka as it's first endorsed skateboarder.

name: Ice Cream Shoes
description: In 2005, Pharrell Williams of The Neptunes, along with his manager partnered with Japanese fashion icon Nigo of A Bathing Ape/BAPE to launch Ice Cream Shoes and Billionaire Boys Club Apparel. Ice Cream shoes and apparel were produced through Reebok and marketed as more of a luxury brand with distribution in finer footwear and apparel boutiques worldwide. The Ice Cream skate team included Terry Kennedy, Jacob Walder, Cato Williams, Jimmy Gorecki and Kevin Booker, but the brand booted it's team in the later 2000s.

name: JFA Skateboards
description: JFA Skateboards was an extension of J.F.A. (Jodie Foster's Army), a hardcore punk band that was pivotal to the skate punk and skate rock scene of the 1980s. JFA Skateboards were distributed through Placebo, which was the band's record label.

name: Individual Clothing
description: Individual was a clothing company that started out of San Diego, California in around 1997. Individual apparel utilized a variety of materials and was targeted at a more mature customer with an eye for detail. The brand was somewhat of an early version of what L-R-G has become, and used the tagline Make Your Own Path. A few Individual team riders included Karl Watson, Kanten Russell, Dayne Brummet, Mike Rafter and Brandon Carabajal.

name: JSLV Clothing
description: JSLV, also known as Jus Liv was founded in 2007 as an apparel brand for the skate, snow, music and graffiti cultures. Over the years, JSLV has carved out quite a niche for themselves through increased exposure from recording artists to skateboarders. And with a ageless logo and innovative pieces, it's safe to say JSLV will stand the test of time.

name: Grind King Trucks
description: Grind King Trucks, also known as Grind King Truck Co. was founded by Donald Cassel in the late 1980's.

name: Lakai
description: Lakai Limited Footwear was launched in the year 2000 by Mike Carroll & Rick Howard through Podium Distribution. Over the years, Lakai has continually grown through solid marketing & designs, an unparalleled team, and a 100% commitment to skateboarding. Today, Lakai is under the Crailtap roof where it strives to progress the shoes we skate.

name: Insight Clothing
description: In the late 1990s, Australian based Insight Surfboards launched a surf/skate clothing line to complement the laid back lifestyle it supports. This Internationally renowned clothing label was named Insight Clothing, after its parent company. Then in 2010, Black Box Distribution became the United States licensee to further strengthen and grow the brands presence within the United States.

name: Hype! Skateboards
description: Hype! Skateboards was started in 2008 by Mike Hiskey who took over the art direction at Popwar after Yogi Proctor's departure. Basically picking up where Popwar left off, Hype! looks to challenge the unrealistic pop culture phenomenon's we are constantly bombarded with on a daily basis. With humorous undertones, Hype! promote itself as being "Committed to the Superficial", and proudly supports team riders Mike Barker, Jeremy Holmes, David Perry, Tyler Price, Kurt Winter and Justin Cefai.

name: GTO Clothing
description: Good Times Operation or GTO Clothing as it was also known was a San Diego based apparel brand from the early to mid 1990s. A few GTO Clothing team riders included John Reeves and Brad Hayes.

name: Kewday Skateboards
description: Kewday Skateboards was an Australian deck brand that was founded in around 2007 by Chad Bartie's brother, Jamie Bartie. Although Kewday team rides included Chad Bartie, Andrew Currie, Joe Pease, Scott Standley and Karl Bayldon amongst others, the brand was pretty short lived.

name: Halos Bearings
description: Halos Bearings is a brand which offers precision skateboard bearings in Abec 3, Abec 5 & Abec 7 ratings. Halos was based out of San Jose, therefore their team primarily consisted of Nor Cal skaters including Tim Brauch, Justin Strubing, Hanzy Driscoll, Gershon Mosley, Jason Adams, Crazy Eddie Nemeth, Kenny Reed, Mike Crabtree and Joe Hutchison.

name: Judah Skateboards
description: Judah Skateboards was a deck company founded by Satva Leung and David Flores in the early 2000s. The name Judah was in reference to San Francisco's N Judah Metro line which runs from Pac Bell Park to the ocean, and features quite a few skate spots along the way. The Judah team consisted of Satva Leung, German Nieves, Andy Bautista, Joel Meinholz, Dustin Charlton, Adam Crew and Mike Barker. Originally based out of Imperial Distribution, Judah moved over to Select Distribution in 2002.

name: Hella Clips
description: Hella Clips was started by Josh Kalis and Colin McKay in 2011 as a media hub for the latest video clips and content. Hella Clips keeps you to date on the most current videos and can be sorted by day, week, month or year.

name: Gravis Footwear
description: Gravis Footwear was launched in 1999 as a shoe division of Burton Snowboards. Specializing in footwear and apparel, Gravis set out to design "after riding" silhouettes although their initial designs were perceived as a bit too fashionable and ultimately fell short. Today, Gravis has found their stride and continues to remain rooted in the four elements of skate, snow, surf and art.

name: Kryptonics
description: From the parking lots of Santa Monica to the original Burnside Skatepark, Kryptonics has been fueling the skateboard scene since 1965 with authentic wheels and decks.

name: Half Life Organic
description: Half Life Organic was a clothing brand started by Matt Field in 1996. Half Life products were constructed of Earth friendly materials such as organic cotton, hemp and recycled fleece. The Half Life team consisted of Bob Burnquist, Keith Hufnagel, Fred Gall, Ricky Oyola, Barker Barrett, Matt Pailes, Tony Cox, Serge Trudnowski and Quim & Mike Cardona just to name a few.

name: Invisible Skateboards
description: Invisible Skateboards was launched by Dave Bergthold around 1994 as a re-branding of Blockhead Skateboards. As the skateboard landscape changed through the early 1990s, Dave thought Blockhead had become stagnant and felt a change needed to be made. Quite a few Blockhead riders came over as well as some new faces including Jamie Thomas, John Reeves, Matt Mumford, Josh Kalis and Kristian Svitak to name a few. Invisible eventually called it quits around 1998.

name: Heetrz Skateboards
description: Heetrz Skateboards was a short lived deck brand that operated around the year 2000. Heetrz was created at the Much2much Media Lab with Ron Allen as the brands headlining pro.

name: HUF
description: HUF was founded by Keith Hufnagel in 2002 as a San Francisco, California based retail store front. Keith's goal with HUF was to combine the best companies that skateboarding, footwear and streetwear had to offer under one roof. HUF quickly became a premiere location for hard to find goods and has since introduced their own line of HUF footwear, apparel and accessories. HUF team riders have included Keith Hufnagel, Joey Pepper, Peter Ramondetta, Dylan Rieder, Austyn Gillette, Dan Plunkett, Brad Cromer and Kevin Terpening amongst others.

name: House of Kasai
description: House of Kasai was founded by Lester Kasai back in the mid 1980s as a board division of Tracker Trucks. House of Kasai had a solid team consisting of Lester, Adrian Demain, Jon Jon Bryant, Scott Clemenes, Matt Goldsby and Jason Dill but called it quits in the early 1990s once the skateboarding landscape began to change. Then in 2007, House of Kasai was revived with new products and a new team but after just a few short years was forced to call it quits again.

name: Iron Horse Grip
description: Iron Horse is a grip tape brand that started in 1998, and is distributed through ATM Click. Iron Horse was originally offered with hundreds of tiny perforations to avoid air bubbles, but once Mob Grip claimed the patent was forced to discontinue the use of perforations. Iron Horse team riders have included Pat Duffy, Richard Angelides, Corey Duffel, Clint Peterson, Andrew Reynolds, Jim Greco, Al Partanen, Trainwreck, Ronnie Bertino, Jake Brown, Omar Salazar, Ed Devera, Stefan Janoski, Chris Senn, Jub, Rob Carlyon, Kyle Leeper, Mako Urabe and Alikai Lee to name a few.

name: Hoodlum Skateboards
description: Hoodlum Skateboards also known as HDLM is an East Coast skateboard brand that's been in the game since 2001. Hoodlum team pros include Toebee Parkhurst and Gary Smith in addition to amateurs Matt Fenell, Hurvey Haskins, Ki Realer, Jeff Burke, Dyllon Horne and Ryan Boblits.

name: Innes Clothing
description: Innes is a clothing brand which was founded by brothers Matt and Chris Hensley in 1996. The name Innes comes from the Scottish clan name of Matt and Chris' late mother, who the company was named in honor of. Innes was briefly distributed through Black Box after Jamie Thomas joined the team around 2000, but has since returned to it's independent roots with the Hensley brothers. Innes creates timeless pieces which are inspired by the skateboard, music and tattoo lifestyles.

name: Hoven
description: Hoven is the manufacturer of quality sunglasses, goggles and apparel with a vintage look and style. Hoven is based out of Southern California and has a skate team which includes Corey Duffel, Matt Ball, Scott Bourne and Jason Jessee.

name: Human Skateboards
description: Human Skateboards was a brand from the mid 1990s that also distributed Enemy and Farm Skateboards. Human had an indoor vert ramp which received some coverage from various San Diego vert skaters. But apparently the backers or management were up to some shady business, because the company ended around 1997 after months of F.B.I. surveillance.

name: Hook-Ups Skateboards
description: Hook-Ups was founded by Jeremy Klein in 1994 under the umbrella of Blitz Distribution. Hook-Ups started as a deck company but grew to include Hook-Ups Clothing as well as a line of Hook-Ups Shoes with team riders Jeremy Klein, Geoff Rowley, Heath Kirchart, Willy Santos, Dan Rogers and Jim Greco. Hook-Ups is widely known for it's Japanese animation style female characters and monsters, and has filled a niche that no other skate brand noticed was empty.

name: Harbinger Pads
description: Harbinger was the manufacturer of quality skateboard pads, guards and accessories during the 1990s. The Harbinger tagline was "Wear it Out".

name: Gravity Skateboards
description: Gravity Skateboards has been a dedicated manufacturer of high performance, quality longboard skateboards and specialty skateboards since 1994. Gravity does it's best to provide a wide range of skateboards, wheels and accessories to stoke out skateboarders of all different styles. So whatever you are into, Gravity has the setup for you.

name: Hot Rod Skate Shop
description: Hot Rod Skate Shop was established in 1995, and since then has become one of L.A.'s premiere skate shops and lifestyle brands. Hot Rod has also made some noise through their Cease and Desist line, in which they reproduce rare and controversial decks from the '80s and '90s in limited, hand numbered quantities.

name: Hoon Skateboards
description: Hoon was founded by Andrew Currie in 2006 as a Australian based wheel company which was distributed through Cliche. The original Hoon team consisted of Matt Mumford, Chet Childress, Javier Mendizabal, Jake Duncombe and Dorfus. These days, Hoon has grown to produces decks in addition to wheels and accessories.

name: Hawaiian Island Creations
description: Hawaiian Island Creations also known as H.I.C. is a Hawaiian based company that started in 1972 as the retailer of surfboard supplies and bicycles. Shortly after, H.I.C. introduced a private label line of apparel and added a skateboarding department with Steve Caballero as the face of the brand. Today, H.I.C. is the manufacturer of surfboards & surfwear and has expanded to include multiple retail locations across the Hawaiian Islands and Japan.

name: Landshark Wheels
description: Landshark Wheels was founded by Kristian Svitak in the late 2000s as a wheel brand with a throwback punk rock vide. Landshark Wheels are available in a wide assortment of sizes & colors and offer a "No Flat Spot" guarantee. Current and former Landshark team riders include Kristian Svitak, Bill Danforth, Kris Markovich, Dan Nepscha, Ben Raybourn, Mike Vallely and Danny Tumia.

name: Grizzly Grip
description: Torey Pudwill first started making Grizzly Griptape in 2001 by stamping out the Bear Logo for himself and local friends. This was a short lived endeavor, but in 2010 Torey teamed up with Diamond Supply Co. to handle the production and distribution of Grizzly Griptape, in addition to a full line of Grizzly Griptape apparel & accessories.

name: Jart Skateboards
description: Jart Skateboards was started back in 2001 in Irun (the Basque Country) as a business project led by the Iraola brothers. At present, Jart is a brands with one of the greatest presences in the European skateboard scene. A few Jart team riders include Bastien Salabanzi, Jan Kliewer, Mathieu Dupuy, Orlando Acosta, Mark Frolich, Ivan Rivado and Ricky Webb amongst others.

name: Hoopla Skateboards
description: Hoopla was created by professional skateboarders Mimi Knoop and Cara-Beth Burnside with the intent of encouraging both girl's participation and progression in skateboarding, while simultaneously offering fun graphics for all skaters. Hoopla has deep roots in skateboarding and is centered around having fun and being creative.

name: Goodtimes Skateboards
description: GIA was a deck company started by Gregg Witt & Dave Leroux in the mid 1990s. The name GIA was an acronym for Goodtimes Intelligence Agency, but after a few years shortened the name to just Goodtimes. Goodtimes team riders included Jordan Richter, Joe Pino, Eric Mercier, Gregg Witt, John Muldoon, Dave Leroux, Peter Hewitt, Brian Seber, Eddy Alioto, Jen O'Brien, Dorian Tucker, Matt Moffett, Adil Dyani, Jason Masse, Gary Robinson, Sam Hitz, Hans Claessens, Carl Carpentier, Tim Tino, Sean Andrew, and Chris Larson.

name: Krux Trucks
description: Krux is a truck brand that was originally started in the early 1990s out of NHS Distribution. Krux is all about having fun and employs a humorous approach when it comes to its products and advertisements. Krux trucks are available in a wide variety of prints and patterns, with select styles offering a unique Allen wrench kingpin design which is less likely of becoming stripped.

name: Gordon and Smith
description: Gordon and Smith, also known as G&S was founded by Larry Gordon and Floyd Smith as a surfboard company in the mid 1950's. During the late 60's early 70's, Gordon and Smith also become one of the largest, most successful skateboard companies and one of the first to sponsor professional teamriders. Skateboarding exploded as the company sold 500 Fibreflex skateboards per day with a 6 month backlog and skaters became overnight superstars.

name: Independent Trucks
description: The Independent Truck Company was co-founded by Richard Novak, Jay Shiurman, Fausto Vitello, and Eric Swenson in 1978. Independent trucks are manufactured at the Ermico trucks foundry and are distributed through NHS Distribution. The brand has produced multiple truck stages throughout the years, but has become a staple of skateboarding through their highly recognizable logo and commitment to quality. Today, Independent trucks are available in an array of colors and signature styles from sizes 129mm-215mm.

name: Iota Skateboards
description: Iota Skateboards was started in the early 2000s as a deck division of Fobia Skate Shop. Located in Minneapolis, Minnesota, Iota had a solid team of local & Midwest rippers including Steve Nesser, Emeric Pratt, Chad Benson, Brian Heck, Elijah Collard, Neal Erickson, Jeremy Reeves, Nate Compher, and Jamiel Nowparvar, but unfortunately lasted no more than a few short years.

name: Grind For Life
description: Grind For Life, Inc. was founded by life-long skateboarder Mike Rogers in 2003, after his second battle with sarcoma cancer. Mike's first battle with cancer came as a pre-teen and then again 25 years later in the form of a tumor behind his right eye and nasal cavity. Through positive thinking and an excellent medical staff, Mike beat the odds and is skateboarding competitive again. The mission of the Grind For Life organization is to provide financial assistance to cancer patients and their families when traveling long distances to doctors and hospitals, as well as to educate and inspire patients on cancer survival and recovery.

name: High Grade Distribution
description: High Grade Distribution was created in 2004 as the distribution home for Creation Skateboards, Satori Wheels, Upful Hardware, Paradox Grip, Red I Eyewear and the now defunct Yellow Brand Skateboards. The goal of High Grade Distribution is to produce the highest quality products for eco-conscious consumers.

name: Hi-Fi Wheels
description: Hi-Fi Wheels was founded by Chris Pastras in the 2000s as a wheel division of the Stereo Sound Agency. Hi-Fi has carved out a niche for themselves through a team of smooth operators and a superior wheel formula which is guaranteed against flatspots. Hi-Fi offers a wide range of wheel shapes and sizes through their various Streethane, Parkthane and Waves wheel designs.

name: I&I Skateboards
description: I&I Skateboards was a rasta inspired deck company that was founded by Nyjah Huston and his father in 2009. This came after Element severed their ties with Nyjah due to his fathers questionable management. The I&I team consisted of Nyjah Huston, Richard Jefferson and Anthony Williams, until January 2011 when Nyjah's mother gained custody of Nyjah and Element welcomed him back to the team. This event resulted in the end of I&I Skateboards.

name: Infamous Skateboards
description: Infamous Skateboards was a deck company that was started by Ben Liversedge, Ryan Hickey and Mike Hernandez in around 1999. Based out of New York, Infamous had a solid team consisting of Ben Liversedge, Ryan Hickey, Mike Hernandez, Jahmal Williams, Bobby Puleo, Geo Moya and Nikhil Thayer, but called it quits in 2001 after it's financial backer failed to see the brand's potential.

name: Industrial
description: Industrial is the manufacturer of high-quality price point skateboard parts and accessories which are guaranteed for life.

name: Heroin Skateboards
description: Heroin Skateboards was founded in England in 1998 by skateboarder and artist Mark "Fos" Foster. As the years passed, Heroin created a loyal customer base through Fos' unique artwork, marketing and band of delinquent team riders. Then in 2011, Heroin was welcomed into Baker Boys Distribution in an effort to further grow the brand and create a stronger presence within the United States.

name: Gouge Clothing
description: In 1987, Gouge Clothing was started out of a Southern California garage as an apparel line for all those who ignore the uniforms of hype. Gouge has deep roots and pays homage to the punk rock, skateboarding, surfing, and snowboarding communities of yesterday and today.

name: Kronik Energy Drink
description: Kronik Energy Drink was started several years ago and has stood the test of time, even with some of the biggest corporations on Earth trying to kick them down. Kronik is an underdog brand which proudly supports athletes within the motorsports, skateboarding, bmx freestyle and wakeboarding communities.

name: Kools
description: Kools Incorporated was a clothing brand founded by Mark Gonzales in the mid 1990s. Kools was definitely Gonz inspired with most of their logos and advertisements featuring some form of Gonz doodles and scribbled text. And although Kools featured quite a few non-skate related people in ads, their team list included the likes of Weston Correa, James Qua, Gino Perez, Mark Gonzales, George Morales, Eric Koston, Rudy Johnson, Paulo Diaz, Josh Beagle, Mike Vallely and Jason Jessee. Kools was fairly short lived, but in 2002 Gonz went on to create Krooked Skateboards, another brand which he misspelled with a K rather than C.

name: Hot Skates Co.
description: Hot Skates Company was an Orange County, California based skate shop that operated from the very late 1980s through 2000s under the leadership of Rudy Fahel. In it's early stages, Hot Skates was one of So Cal's premiere skateboard/snowboard shops and grew to include locations in Orange and Yorba Linda as well as a snowboard shop in the local Wrightwood Mountains. But once Hot Skates opened a rollerblade shop in their old Orange location, they began losing the stranglehold on their territory and eventually called it quits.

name: Habitat Skateboards
description: Habitat Skateboards was founded by Joe Castrucci back in 2000 as a sister company to Alien Workshop. With an Earthy vibe, Habitat has produced several Eco-friendly products including bamboo, hemp & cork ply decks, plus the use of water based glue, ink & clear coats, and even a line of organic apparel. Habitat also introduced a shoe line in 2010, but ceased production in 2014 before making a move over to Tum-Yeto.

name: Heel Bruise
description: Heel Bruise is a southern California based brand founded by Richard Mulder and childhood friend Thomas Yu. Their intent is to represent to the future timeless graphics & apparel that genuinely portray their upbringings, recollections, and skateboard heritage.

name: Grape Network
description: Grape Network was a skateboard company started by skater and artist Ron Cameron in 1994. Kyle Yanagamoto left Prime to help Ron get things going, but unfortunately the brand quickly folded.

name: Hosoi Skateboards
description: Hosoi Skateboards was founded by Christian Hosoi in 1984, first being distributed through Skull Skates and then through NHS/Santa Cruz. In the 1980's, Christian Hosoi reached legendary status as a professional skateboarder with his fluid style and big airs. Hosoi Skateboards released his signature and iconic Hammerhead model which proved to be so popular that it was counterfeited. The brand eventually folded in the 1990's but was revived by Hosoi in the mid 2000's and is now a Christian based skateboard company.

name: Hawk Clothing
description: Tony Hawk and his family founded Hawk Clothing in 1998 as a kids specific clothing company. The brand saw instant success due to Tony's increasing popularity, and in the year 2000 was acquired by Quiksilver. Hawk Clothing later added a team of up and coming kids including Mike Anderson, David Gonzalez, Tyler Bledsoe, Danny Cerezini, Marius Syvanen, Lamare Hemmings, John White and Evan Mirschel, but was short lived. Today, Hawk Clothing is available exclusively at Kohl's department stores in boys and teen sizing.

name: Krooked
description: Krooked Skateboards was founded by Mark Gonzales in 2002. Krooked is noted for it's "Guest Boards", where they release limited runs of pro decks for riders of other companies. Krooked is distributed by Deluxe Distribution.

name: In4mation
description: In4mation is a Hawaiian based clothing company which was founded in 2002 by four partners, Ryan Arakaki, Todd Shimabuku, Jun Jo and Rhandy Tambio. The concept behind the In4mation name comes from the 1980s cartoon VOLTRON, in which unique characters assembled to become one indestructible machine. In4mation was initially geared toward the surf and skate lifestyles, but over time has become a force to be reckoned with in today's streetwear culture.

name: Hubba Wheels
description: Hubba is a wheel company that was founded in the 2000s under the banner of Street Corner Distribution, but is now distributed through Strange Bird. Hubba came out promoting a solid cast of riders but after a couple years, switched gears and began to promote their products through the use of alluring female models. A few Hubba team riders include Zered Bassett, Braydon Szafranski, Brandon Westgate, Furby, Manny Santiago, Jesus Fernandez, Russ Milligan, Cody McEntire and Devine Calloway.

name: KR3W
description: KR3W Clothing was started in 2002 by Angel Cabada as a skate specific apparel brand. Angel was the creative force behind TSA and through similar marketing has grown KR3W into one of skateboarding and streetwear culture's premiere clothing companies. KR3W was first propelled to new heights with the introduction of it's K Slim denim which simultaneously revolutionized the industry and established KR3W as a brand known for innovation and unique vision.

name: Goodwood Skateboards
description: Goodwood Skateboards was started in the mid 2000s as a Southern California based deck company. Goodwood decks were manufactured using 100% North American hard rock maple and bamboo constructions for increased strength but were offered at a price point which appealed to a broad customer base. The company also operated a short lived sub-division called Transmission.

name: Hurley
description: Hurley was established in 1979 as a surfboard brand with Bob Hurley shaping all of it's boards personally. Then in the mid 1980s, Bob Hurley launched a surf clothing line through a licensing agreement with Billabong USA. But in 1998 after the licensing agreement was up, Bob and his group decided to take the Hurley brand on their own and re-brand it as an apparel line for the surf, music, girls, art and skate cultures. This transition was tough yet successful, and in 2002 Hurley was purchased by Nike, Inc.

name: Grn Apple Tree
description: Grn Apple Tree is a clothing brand which was founded in downtown Los Angeles, CA. back in 2001. Grn Apple Tree focuses on men's contemporary fashion but has also found a following within today's streetwear culture.

name: Gotcha
description: Gotcha was founded in 1978 by pro surfer Michael Tomson and Joel Cooper out of a garage in Laguna Beach, California. The brand started out selling swim trunks but struck retail gold in the early 1980s with the introduction of their longer Bermuda-style shorts in a range of neon colors and wild prints. Gotcha became the industry leader for much of the 1980s, and was the first brand to introduce year-round surf lifestyle apparel, developing the collection into jeans, jackets and accessories.

name: Kre-per Trucks
description: Kre-per was a truck brand from the early to mid 2000s which produced one of the strangest looking trucks skateboarding has ever seen. Marketed as the anti-truck, the Invader truck silhouette had a hanger designed to resemble a spider web and featured a skull on it's base plate, but had a decent team so they must not have performed all that bad. Kre-per team riders included Chris Swanson, Dave Reul, JJ Mace, Pee Wee, Kyle Hagerty, Brigham Edwards, Ryan Carpenter and Seth Dunk to name a few.

name: Kastel Shoes
description: Kastel was a footwear brand from the mid to late 1990s that was produced by Capital Distribution, the makers of Ezekiel Clothing & Blond Outerwear. Alphonze Rawls was one of Kastel's first riders and helped with some early shoe designs before Dustin Deardorff took over the design aspects. Kastel packaged quite a few Ezekiel riders as well as bringing in some new faces including Steve Olson, Chad Fernandez, Ricky Oyola and Rob Gonzalez.

name: JNCO Jeans
description: JNCO Jeans was started in 1985, but somehow achieved overnight success in the mid 1990s by offering denim pants and shorts with ultra-wide leg openings and ridiculously oversized back pockets. The name JNCO was an acronym for Judge None, Choose One. Although JNCO's primary focus was always on jeans and apparel, the company introduced a short lived footwear line in the late 1990s.

name: Landspeed Wheels
description: Landspeed Wheels was a wheel company founded by and distributed through Tum Yeto from 1998 to 2000. Landspeed is mostly remembered for bringing us CKY, the first film in the CKY series, which was released in March of 1999.

name: Illenium Skateboards
description: Al Partanen and a few friends started Illenium Skateboards back in 1999 after the untimely demise of Creature. Illenium team riders included Al Partanen, Christian Brox and Mike Peterson in addition to young up-and-comers Greg Lutzka, Tony Cervantes, Jon Goemann, Steve Forstner, Peter Watkins and Austen Seaholm. Behind a raw team and the art direction of Nate Reifke, Illenium began to establish a loyal following but it's financial backers failed to see the potential and pulled the plug in 2003.

name: ILL Clothing
description: The League was started in 1989 by Chris "Slappy" Sutherland after growing tired of the clothing being offered in shops. The League became known as ILL in 1992 and eventually grew to include a custom cut-and-sew line designed for skaters, at a time when others were simply relabeling products. ILL team riders were a raw bunch including Ricky Oyola, Chad Muska, Paul Sharpe, Mike Crabtree, Gershon Mosley, Alan Petersen, Billy Valdes, Sergei Trudnowski, Mike Frazier, Salman Agah, Tim Brauch and Jason Adams.

name: Hopps Skateboards
description: Jahmal Williams started Hopps Skateboards back in 2007 as a skater owned and operated brand that is inspired by skateboarding and underground street culture. In being Hopps' driving force, Williams handles all of the brand's graphics, art direction and promos, in addition to being a team rider. Other Hopps team riders include Joel Meinholz, Jerry Fowler and Steve Brandi. At it's very core, Hopps is all about having fun at skateboarding and promotes the tag line "Keep it Moving!".

name: Incase
description: Incase Designs was founded in 1997 by four longtime friends as a carrying solution for today's technology driven lifestyle. If you're the owner of an Apple product, chances are Incase has a functional case to help you protect it. Incase created the first iPod case for Apple, and today Incase products are available in nearly all of Apple's retail stores. Incase is also the manufacturer of quality guitar cases.

name: Hell Rose Skateboards
description: Hell Rose was a deck company started in 2004 when Don Nguyen, Justin Roy, James Atkin, Richie Belton & DJ Chavez left Hollywood Skateboards. We believe Hell Rose was backed by Syndrome Distribution, but can't recall for sure. Hell Rose had a rock n' roll vibe but only last a short year or two before calling it quits.

name: Khiro
description: Khiro is a brand known for producing some of skateboarding's highest quality bushings, hardware and accessories. Khiro uses the most advanced manufacturing techniques combined with the best materials to produce superior products for pool, street, longboard and freestyle skateboarding. Khiro proudly makes all it's products in the U.S.A.

name: King Rails
description: Jeff King and his friend Andy first started making flatbars toward the end of 2000. Together they rented a Lincoln welder, bought some metal from the outside rack at Escondido Metal Supply, used Jeff's dad's skill saw to cut it up, and started Kingrails. Today, Jeff King still has the original rails he and Andy built back in 2000 as a reminder of their humble beginnings.

name: Jones Soda
description: Jones Soda was started in 1987 under the name Urban Juice and Soda Company Ltd., and was originally founded as an alternative for the beverage industry. Urban Juice and Soda Company Ltd. introduced Jones Soda in 6 flavors in 1996, and after tremendous success officially changed the company name to Jones Soda Co. in 2000. Today, Jones Soda continues to produces flavored beverages in addition to energy supplements, candy, apparel and accessories.

name: Golden State Wheel Co
description: Golden State Wheel Company was a mid to late 1990s wheel brand which was produced and distributed under the umbrella of Giant Distribution. Golden State also produced a bearing line under the name Smokie Bandits. Team Riders of Golden State Wheel Co included Colin McKay, Pontus Alv, Pat Duffy, Tony Cox and Cairo Foster to name a few.

name: Gullwing Trucks
description: Gullwing Trucks was founded in 1976 and was the first company to introduce a split axle design, offering faster turning and stability at high speeds. Since then, Gullwing has produced such iconic designs as the Phoenix, PRO Model, PRO III, Mach IV, Street Shadow, Little G, Spectra, Charger and Stalker model trucks to name a few. These days, Gullwing focuses a little more on longboard and downhill trucks, making them the only truck company to offer products that compliment all forms of skateboarding.

name: Hessenmob Skateboards
description: In 1999, Hessenmob was started in Germany and expanded to the shores of California in 2005. The production quality is by all means the most important aspect of Hessenmob. Hessenmob team riders include Valentin Cafuk, Danny Sommerfeld, Johannes Schon, Malte Krahe, Laif Draasch, Alex Denkiewicz, Iwan Martaller and Kerem Elver amongst others.

name: Gold Wheels
description: Gold Wheels is a technical wheel brand that was founded back in 1999 and is distributed through The Kayo Corp. Gold is a brand that embodies and celebrates the "hood" lifestyle through their various designs, advertisements and team riders. Gold's current and former team riders include Stevie Williams, Josh Kalis, Ryan Gallant, J.B. Gillet, Marcus McBride, Spencer Fujimoto, Rodrigo TX, Matt Miller, Brandon Biebel, Forrest Kirby, Lee Smith, Lenny Rivas and Jack Curtin to name a few.

name: Hollywood Skateboards
description: Hollywood Skateboards was a deck company founded by Kris Markovich in around 2001. Markovich split from Foundation to start Hollywood under the Tum Yeto umbrella, but left Tum Yeto completely by the end of '03 for a spot on the Blind team. Rather than give up on Hollywood, Tod Swank and the team decided to continue along, that is until '04 when a majority of the team left to start Hell Rose Skateboards. Hollywood tried continuing with the remaining riders of Charlie Thomas, Phil Ladjanski and Dorian Tucker, but didn't last long before calling it quits.

name: Jacobs
description: Jacobs was either a skate shop or skateboard & snowboard company from the mid 1990s, completely unsure of which it was.  Jacobs ran a couple 411VM commercials in 1994-1995.

name: Joint 109
description: Joint 109 Skateboards was a early 1990s deck company that was based out of Boston, Massachusetts. Joint 109 had quite a bit of local talent including Jon Budinoff and Pete Lugo.

name: Killing Machine
description: Killing Machine was a skateboard hardware company that seemed geared more toward transition or more raw type skaters. A few of Killing Machine's riders included Jason Adams, Chet Childress, Bam Margera, Alan Petersen, Chris Senn, Eric J, Tino Razo, Nate Jones, Aaron Suski, Chad Bartie, Patrick Melcher, Dorian Tucker, and Kristian Svitak.

name: H-Street Skateboards
description: H-Street was started by Tony Magnusson and Mike Ternasky after leaving Magnusson Designs in 1988. H-Street quickly became one of skateboarding's largest and most popular brands through it's groundbreaking videos and riders. H-Street also created a sister brand in Life Skateboards around 1990 once the H-Street team began to grow out of control. In 1991 however, Mike Ternasky left H-Street to start Plan B through World Industries and took several riders with him. Then in 1993, Tony Magnusson also left H-Street behind after it's financial backer demanded an unreasonable sum, at which point Tony re-branded and re-launched the company as Evol Skateboards.

name: Grind Inc.
description: Grind Inc. was a short lived deck, wheel and apparel company from the mid 1990s. Grind Inc. was located in Huntington Beach, Ca. and manufactured all their products in the U.S.A.

name: Jessup
description: Original founded back in 1975, Jessup was the first brand to bring silicon carbide grip tape to the skateboard industry. Jessup grip tape offers the perfect blend of grip and grit, and thanks to it's rock-solid bonding agent will stick to your board no matter what.

name: Hawk Shoes
description: Hawk Shoes was founded by Tony Hawk in the year 2000 as an offshoot of Adio Footwear. Hawk Shoes hoped to appeal to general Tony Hawk fans and targeted a younger demographic of kids who were maybe just starting out in skateboarding. Tony also brought Alex Chalmers and Shaun White on board to add some youth, and to tap into the crossover snowboard community. But by 2003, after dwindling sales, Hawk Shoes became available in kids sizes only and the team of Tony Hawk, Shaun White and Alex Chalmers was absorbed into Adio.

name: Kingdom Skateboards
description: Kingdom Skateboards was founded by Chris Gentry and his wife Ricca in 1996. Chris and Ricca Gentry were one of skateboarding's husband and wife teams, with most Kingdom ads typically featuring both Chris and Ricca in some sort of outer space scene. The original Kingdom team consisted of Chris Gentry, George Nagai, Jason Womack and Wayne Patrick, with Ricca in the role of team manager. Kingdom was also an outlet for Chris to promote his attempt at a rap career.

name: Kontrol Wheels
description: Kontrol Wheels is a Southern California based wheel brand which utilizes their patented urethane and processes to create some of the most superior wheels available. Kontrol Wheels are 100% USA made with almost zero waste and are one of the most eco-friendly wheel brands in the world. Kontrol constantly quality tests their wheels through their extensive skate team which includes Ronson Lambert, Andrew Pott, Jed Shooter, Kurtis Colamonico and Jason Wussler to name a few.

name: Harold Hunter Foundation
description: In his short lifetime, Harold Hunter became an international ambassador of the Lower East Side, sharing his passion and spirit for skateboarding and living life to the fullest as he traveled the world. The mission of the Harold Hunter Foundation(HHF) is to provide inner-city youth with valuable life experiences and opportunities for personal and professional growth by encouraging and sponsoring their interest in skateboarding. It is the goal of the HHF to continue Harold's legacy because put simply, legends never die.

name: Jugs Attire
description: Jugs Attire was a skate/snow clothing company from the early to mid 1990s, and was a sister brand to Clout Skateboards. The Jugs team consisted of Karma Tsocheff, Jesse Paez, Brad Johnson and Mat O'Brien.

name: i-Level Skateboards
description: i-Level Skateboards was a brand from the early to late 1990s which was based out of Tennessee. The brand is mostly remembered for it's i-Level Skateboards case, in which the company owner was convicted of indecent acts with minors at the skatepark he owned. A few i-Level team riders included Billy Lane, Phil Hajal, Alastair Brown, Jason Austin, Devan Todd, Toebee Parkhurst, Phil Kent, Dusty Jones, and R.J. Martin.

name: Fuct
description: Fuct Clothing was founded in Los Angeles, CA. as the brainchild of graffiti artist Erik Brunetti, also known as DEN ONE. The brand started around 1991 out of Brunetti's Venice Beach bedroom, but grew to become one of the largest brands of the early streetwear scene. In 1993, Fuct collaborated with X-Large on a Los Angeles retail space which they appropriately named X-Fuct. Fuct is also known for producing a short lived line of skateboards in the late 1990s.

name: Foundation Skateboards
description: With a little help from Steve Rocco, Tod Swank was able to start Foundation Skateboards in 1989. The brand was distributed through World Industries for it's first 2 years before Tod took the brand to San Diego to do on his own.

name: Given Skateboards
description: Given Skateboards was founded by Kris Markovich as a 100% skateboarder owned and operated company based out of Atlanta, GA. Given is very much driven by the design and artwork of Kris Markovich and includes team riders James Atkin, Emeric Pratt, Stephen Criger, Joey Pellegrino, Solomon Mosley and Danny Scher.

name: EVOS Footwear
description: EVOS Footwear was started in the early 2000s as a sub-division of Nice Skate Shoes(NSS). The name EV.O.S. was an acronym for Evolution Of Skate and was promoted as "Next Level Footwear" but struggled in a turbulent marketplace before calling it quits. EVOS team riders included Adam McNatt, Ron Whaley, Gary Smith, Justin Reynolds, Dan Pageau, Mike Santarossa, and Alex Bland amongst others.

name: Funhouse Skateboards
description: Funhouse Skateboards was formed in 2006 as the brainchild of owner/artist JJ Rudisill. Rudisill created Funhouse as a way to blend 1980s old school design and illustrations with today's modern construction techniques.

name: Germ Skateboards
description: Germ Skateboards was started in 2002 by Tyrone Olson, and we think was possibly backed by Osiris Footwear. Tyrone assembled a solid team of mostly San Diego skaters and began filming for a Germ video, although the brand called it quits before the video was finished. Germ team riders included Tyrone Olson, Brian Emmers, Tyler Moore, Dave Coyne, Matt Brode and Cody Branin.

name: Eppic Skateboards
description: Eppic was a deck company from the late 1980s which was started by Louis Carleton who went on to do Small Room Skateboards. Eppic had some amazing talent in Sal Barbier, Kris Markovich, Brian Pennington, Dave Donalson and Alan Petersen amongst others, but never really caught on and was scrapped after a few short years. Eppic also operated a retail shop in the Los Osos, California area.

name: GAS Skateboards
description: GAS also known as Great American Skateboards was a brand from the 1990's.

name: Furnace Skate Shop
description: Furnace is a southern California based shop which has supported skateboarding since the 1990s. In being central to Orange County and most beach cities, Furnace is known for it's heavy hitting team and chill shopping atmosphere.

name: Drop Bags
description: Originally started in 1998, Drop is a snowboard accessory company which specializes in gloves. But in the early 2000s, when every bag company came creeping into skateboarding, Drop was no exception. Although short lived, the Drop skate team consisted of Ricky Oyola, Eric Mercier, Satva Leung, Van Wastell, Alex Gavin, Etienne Tanguay and Joe Buffalo. Today, Drop continues to produce snowboard gloves and accessories.

name: Ergo Clothing
description: Founded in 2005, Ergo offers a collection of high quality surf and skate apparel. Ergo is committed to creating core, quality products for consumers who live a lifestyle marked by originality and distinction.

name: Edward Sebastian
description: Edward Sebastian was a clothing & accessory company from the mid to late 1990's. The brand was managed by Carl Hyndman and was funded by and distributed through Plan B Skateboards. Edward Sebastian team riders included Matt Hensley, Jake Stewart, Marc Johnson, Chad Knight and Ben Pappas amongst others. Edward Sebastian also had a short lived women's line which operated under the names Yoni Yum, Y Yum, and Yum.

name: Dogtown Skateboards
description: Dogtown Skateboards was originally founded back in 1976 by Jim "Red Dog" Muir and Wes Humpston. The name Dogtown came from the nickname given to a portion of Santa Monica, California where the legendary "Z-Boys" pioneered a never before seen aggressive approach to skateboarding. In it's early days, Dogtown boards were invariably hand made, hand drawn, custom one-off decks made by Wes Humpston and Jim Muir themselves. Over the years, Dogtown riders have come and gone, but the company hasn't faltered in exemplifying the hardcore mystique it was built upon.

name: Devlin Clothing
description: Devlin was a clothing brand from the mid to late 1990s that operated out of Carlsbad, California. Devlin Clothing team riders included Aaron Harrison, Ave Bunachita, Jesse Reed and Edgar Vasquez.

name: Duffs Shoes
description: DuFFS was originally founded back in 1993 as the brainchild of Steve Rocco and Rodney Mullen. DuFFS was the first shoe brand to be produced through World Industries although it was later sold by Rocco. DuFFS has changed hands a few more times over the years, but remains a highly respected manufacturer of skate footwear and apparel.

name: Elephant Brand
description: Elephant Brand Skateboards was founded by Mike Vallely at the end of 2011 after parting ways with Powell. With shapes and graphics which are reminiscent of the 1980s, Elephant Brand has found a loyal following amongst skaters and collectors alike. A few Elephant Brand team riders have included Mike Vallely, Jason Adams, Kris Markovich, Neal Hendrix and Kyle Berard.

name: Flip Skateboards
description: Flip Skateboards was started in England by Jeremy Fox and Ian Deacon as a re-branding of Bash, a division of Fox's Death Box Skateboards. In 1993, Death Box and Flip merged with the plan to eventually move the company to the USA. In 1993, Fox, Deacon, Tom Penny, Geoff Rowley, Rune Glifberg and Andy Scott moved the brand to Huntington Beach, CA. where it joined Blitz Distribution and began to take the skateboard world by storm. In 2008, Flip left Blitz and relocated to NHS where it still operates today under the ownership of Fox, Deacon and Rowley.

name: Fit Skateboards
description: Fit Skateboards was a San Francisco based brand from the mid to late 1990's.

name: Evol Skateboards
description: Evol was a deck company started by Tony Magnusson and Niko Achtipes in 1993 after leaving H-Street behind. Evol grew to include skateboards, clothing, snowboards, outerwear, boots, and in '95 introduced a Evol Casuals line of footwear. Footwear quickly became Evol's most profitable category but had a hard time getting non Evol riders due to conflict with other deck & clothing sponsors. So in 1996, the shoe division was re-branded as Osiris Footwear with the original team of Adam McNatt, Gershon Mosley, Tyrone Olson and Dave Mayhew. Evol Skateboards continued a while longer but eventually folded in 1998.

name: Gallaz
description: Gallaz was started as a skate footwear line made specifically for girls. As a division of Globe Shoes, Gallaz produced quality shoes with narrower and lighter silhouettes in hopes of cornering the female skater market. Gallaz team riders included Jaime Reyes, Vanessa Torres, Lauren Mollica, Monica Shaw, Ianire Elorriaga, Violet Kimble, Amy Caron, Lisa Whitaker and Lyn-Z Adams Hawkins to name a few. But as luck would have it the female skate market proved to be too small, and once sales fell short Gallaz switched gears and became a lifestyle footwear and apparel brand for the mainstream.

name: Element Skateboards
description: The first incarnation of Element came in the form of a collaborative company called Underworld Element, most often referred to as U.E. or Underworld. The company used a mixture of different styles and reflected a raw vibe, but was plagued with inner turmoil and things quickly started going downhill. After Underworld's original crew had moved on Johnny Schillereff took the struggling brand under his wing, immediately dropped Underworld, and turned the entire company around into something completely different. Element was born; the negative was turned into positive, and the journey began.

name: Especial Skateboards
description: Especial Skateboards was founded by Julio De La Cruz in the mid 1990s as a sister brand to Neighborhood Skateboards. Especial was distributed through Climax and launched with team riders Julio De La Cruz, Eluid "Shorty" Gonzalez, Dylan Gardner and Robert Douglas, but was fairly short lived.

name: Epik Footwear
description: Epik Footwear was a short lived skate shoe company from the early 2000s. The Epik team included Laban Pheidias, Jason "Wee Man" Acuna, Gary Smith and Mark Hart, but never seemed to break into many skate shops. Epik shoes had decent designs but their ads always gave off a weird discount outlet type vibe.

name: Global Skateboards
description: Global Skateboard was a mid 1990s deck brand that operated out of Orange County, CA. Don't remember much of anything about this brand but Chris Gentry, George Nagai and Wayne Patrick were a few of the brand's team riders.

name: Experience Skateboards
description: Experience Skateboards was a early to mid '90s deck company that was backed by Roger Davis. Based out of San Francisco, Experience had a solid team that included Sean Young, James Kelch, Chris Hall, Eben Jahnke, Daniel Powell, Simon Evans, Pat Washington, Ed Loftus and Matt Robeson, and was the first to turn Drake Jones and Jamie Thomas pro. Roger Davis also backed Henry Sanchez' short lived Profile Skateboards and distributed it out of Experience.

name: Fury Trucks
description: Fury Truck Co. was founded in 1998 on the idea of offering a unique ballpoint turning design where the hangars ball joint sits in a socket in the base plate. This innovative design maximized responsiveness, stability and control while still offering a smooth ride. Fury Trucks were created by and are distributed through Blitz Distribution.

name: DGK
description: DGK Skateboards was founded by Stevie Williams in 2002 after parting ways with Chocolate. DGK is an acronym for Dirty Ghetto Kids, which was the name of Stevie's skate crew growing up in Philadelphia. In 2004, Stevie entered into a contract with Reebok which included the licensing of DGK shoes and clothing, but lasted no more than a couple years. Today, DGK continues to produce quality decks, apparel and accessories under the umbrella of The Kayo Corp.

name: Fourstar Clothing
description: Fourstar Clothing was founded by Guy Mariano and Eric Koston in 1996 under the Girl Skateboard family umbrella of brands. Originally inspired by the Polo, Hilfiger and Nautica's of the time, Fourstar set out to provide an authentic brand for and by skaters. Over the years, Fourstar has learned a lot and changed quite a bit, but seems to have finally found it's identity and stride while remaining true to the foundation it was built upon.

name: Freedumb Clothing
description: Freedumb was a clothing company that was started by Dan Drehobl in 1996. Dan did most of the company graphics, all of which were aimed to be a bit more humorous. Freedumb team riders included Dan Drehobl, Phil Shao, Tim Upson, Ed Templeton, Danny Gonzalez, Brian Seber, Jim Greco, Jake Palu and more. But after getting burnt out, Dan shut Freedumb down in 2002. Then in 2013, Dan re-launched the company as Freedumb Airlines with new designs and a whole new team.

name: Dub Outerwear
description: Dub Brand was a snowboard outerwear company started by DC Shoe Co. in the mid 1990s. But as more and more skaters started wearing Dub jackets a skate team was quickly added and Dub re-labeled itself as an outerwear/streetwear brand. At the end of 1998, World Industries purchased both Dub and Droors Clothing from DC Shoe Co. in an effort to bring clothing into the Dwindle fold. Unfortunately, both brands called it quits within a few short years of being with Dwindle.

name: Ghetto Child
description: Ghetto Child was started in 1997 as a wheel sub-division of Shorty's Skateboards. The original Ghetto Child team consisted of Tom Penny, Sean Sheffey and Chad Muska who also made up the brand's logo. Ghetto Child was able to ride the Shorty's wave of success for a few years, but eventually called it quits by the mid 2000's.

name: Elwood Clothing
description: Elwood Clothing released its first collection of jeans, woven shirts, knits and tees in 1996. Founded by Sal Barbier and Palmer Brown, Elwood set out to represent a higher standard of clothing for skateboarders. But as the years passed, mounting conflict between Sal and Palmer ultimately caused Sal to leave Elwood behind. Palmer continued on with the company, but then in 2011 announced the release of it's entire skate team in order to focus all efforts on apparel design.

name: Force Trucks
description: Force Trucks is a San Francisco based truck company which was founded in 2006 by Greg Carroll and Justin Williams. Distributed through Empire Distribution, Force makes several references to the U.S. Air Force through their name, logo and the use of aircraft Grad A aluminum in their trucks. Force's current and former team riders have included Devine Calloway, Walker Ryan, Zered Bassett, Javier Nunez, Ian Twa, Darrell Stanton, Anthony Williams, Eli Reed, Torey Pudwill, Marquise Henry, Mike Taylor, Josh Anderson and Ricky Webb.

name: Eastern Skateboard Supply
description: Eastern Skateboard Supply was established in 1985 by professional skateboarder Reggie Barnes and has grown to become the largest skateboard distributor in the United States. Reggie's goal with Eastern Skate Supply has always remained the same, to give the wholesale customer everything they need under one roof and to ensure low freight charges and quick service.

name: Fuel TV
description: Fuel TV is the only action sports cable and satellite network in the United States. Fuel TV's programming covers the lifestyle and culture of skateboarding, snowboarding, surfing, BMX, freestyle motocross, and wakeboarding. The channel features original and commissioned series and specials, short-form content, films, and prestigious event coverage. Signature original shows include The Daily Habit, The Weekly Update with Boost Mobile, and Firsthand.

name: Drawls
description: Drawls Clothing was a streetwear company founded in Los Angeles, California in 1991 by Ryan Rush. Drawls was an outlet for the creative ideas and people that were emerging from the underground fashion, hip hop and skate worlds during the golden days of streetwear. Over the years Drawls team riders included Armando Barajas, Julio De La Cruz, Rob Gonzalez and Jason Odell, but called it quits in 1999.

name: Ebony Grip
description: Ebony was a grip tape company that produced quality grip tape at a reasonable price. Ebony grip tape was available in a wide array of colors.

name: Direction Wheels
description: Direction was a mid 1990s wheel company that was started by Jeff Kendall and was distributed through NHS. Direction team riders included Marc Johnson, Jason Rothmeyer, Dave Mayhew, John Reeves, Darren Navarrette, Dennis Bellew, Tyrone Olson, Jason Carney, Jeff Taylor, Kris Markovich and Tony Tieu amongst others.

name: Dickies
description: Dickies is a workwear inspired clothing company that was founded all the way back in 1922. Dickies briefly entered into the skate market in the late 1990s and then gave it a more serious go in the early 2010s. Dickies team riders have included Vincent Alvarez, Peter Hewitt, Jim Greco, Dan Plunkett, Stevie Perez, Tom Remillard and Kevin Terpening.

name: Ezekiel Clothing
description: Ezekiel is a clothing brand that was founded in 1992 by Vince De La Pena and Shane La Voie. Ezekiel offers a wide variety of quality men's and women's apparel which appeal to the surf, skate, snowboard and fashion sub-cultures of today.

name: FTC Skate Shop
description: Established in 1986, FTC(For the City) first began as a small collection of skate gear buried in the back of a ski and tennis shop. Then in 1994, opened the doors of it's first FTC Skate Shop located in San Francisco's historic Haight-Ashbury area. At a time when skateboarding was evolving, FTC became San Francisco's premier retail store and central meeting point for the area's talent. Today, FTC has grown to include a full apparel line and retail locations Worldwide.

name: Girly Things
description: Girly Things was a female specific clothing brand from the mid to late 1990s which was founded and art directed by Andy Howell. Girls Things was produced and distributed through Howell's Sophisto Clothing.

name: G-Shock
description: G-Shock is a sports and lifestyle division of Casio Watches which specializes in manufacturing some of the toughest, most shock resistant watches on the market. G-Shock first started aggressively marketing towards skateboarders around 1998 with the introduction of team riders and a Eric Koston signature watch. Today, G-Shock still sponsors skateboarders Pedro Barros and Stevie Williams among their group of athletes and produces collaboration watches with some of skateboarding's top brands.

name: Fairman's Skate Shop
description: Fairman's Skate Shop was founded in 1977 and is one of the East Coast's oldest and most respected skate, snow and surf shops. Fairman's is a single-location, family owned business located in West Chester, PA.

name: Enjoi
description: Enjoi Skateboards was founded by Marc Johnson after A-Team was dissolved in 2000 and found an instant fan base through it's humorous deck graphics and ads. The original Enjoi team consisted of Marc Johnson, Rodney Mullen, Dave Mayhew, Jerry Hsu, Louie Barletta and Jose Rojo. Marc initially produced most of Enjoi's art and brand direction but after his departure to Chocolate, Matt Eversole assumed the role of head honcho.

name: Fobia Skate Shop
description: Fobia was a skate shop that was started in the Minneapolis, Minnesota area in 1994. Through the 1990s, Fobia grew to include multiple retail locations and cast a light on local Twin Cities talent through several late 1990s videos, but eventually closed it's doors around 2005. Fobia also had a few side projects over the years in Supernatural Clothing, Iota Skateboards and Roots Skateboards.

name: Etnies
description: Established in 1986, etnies was the first skateboarder-owned and operated global action sports footwear and apparel company. Etnies not only pushed the envelope by creating the first pro model skate shoe, but it pioneered technological advances and has changed the face of skateboard footwear forever.

name: Etcetera Project
description: The Etcetera Project was founded by Ronnie Creager in hopes of creating innovative products which make certain aspects of skateboarding more comfortable and convenient. One of Etcetera's premiere products are their Primo Insoles which feature impact support gels in the heel and forefoot plus a center TPU primo pad for added protection against dreaded primo landings. And with other products including an Ankle Stabilizer with figure six heel locking straps and a Wall Ride skateboard holder, it looks as though Etcetera is on the right path to making Ronnie's hopes a reality.

name: Formula One
description: Formula One was started in the early 1990s as a wheel division of Acme Skateboards. Formula One team riders included Simon Woodstock, Willy Santos, Clyde Singleton, Donger, Omar Hassan and Remy Stratton amongst others. Then in 1996, under the leadership of Omar Hassan introduced a line of Formula One decks. Acme owner Jim Gray funded Formula One although it operated independently from Acme, that is until 1998 when Omar Hassan quit the brand to skate for Black Label.

name: Dukes Shoes
description: Dukes Shoes was founded by Jeremy Wray in 1995 as a footwear division of Plan B Skateboards. Jeremy was the creative force behind Dukes, but after Mike Ternasky's death watched Steve Rocco take ownership and later sell the company to the Canadian investment group Gen-X Equipment, Inc., without giving Jeremy a dime in return. With a team consisting of Jeremy Wray, Pat Channita, Matt Hensley, Frank Hirata, Rick Jaramillo and Jerry Fowler, you can't help but think what Dukes could have been under different circumstances.

name: Fyasko
description: Fyasko is a fashion forward apparel brand which manufacturers menswear and accessories. In being based out of Southern California, Fyasko naturally caters to and draws inspiration from the surf, skate, music and art communities.

name: Fun Skateboards
description: Fun Skateboards was a deck company that Ron Allen operated out of Deluxe from the early to mid 1990s. Ron started Fun along with Jesse Neuhaus and John Reeves, plus a cast of up and coming amateurs. Fun made some noise for a few years and even released a video, but was eventually forced to call it quits.

name: Famous Stars and Straps
description: Famous Stars and Straps, also known as FSAS was created in 1999 by Blink-182 drummer Travis Barker. Famous Stars and Straps are the manufacturers of finer streetwear apparel, footwear and accessories. Famous Stars and Straps is widely popular amongst a variety of recording artists in addition to sponsoring skateboarders, freestyle motocross riders, mixed martial artists, and vmx riders.

name: Emergency Skateboards
description: Emergency Skateboards was founded by John Lucero as a veterans division of Black Label Skateboards. Emergency originally started under the name Red Kross in 2002, but after receiving multiple Cease & Desist letters from the Geneva Convention, was forced to change it's name to Emergency to avoid further litigation. Emergency offers a variety of larger shape decks for the older guys who are trying to keep it moving.

name: Elenex Clothing
description: Elenex was a clothing company that Kanten Russell and Dave Mayhew started in around 2001. Elenex was backed by Osiris, and therefore mostly sponsored other Osiris or San Diego based riders including Brandon Turner, Chris Dobstaff and Dan Heassler. Elenex was athletically inspired like much of the clothing at that time, featuring lots of rip-stop/nylon pants, mesh jerseys/tops, etc.

name: Familia Skate Shop
description: Familia was founded by Steve Nesser as a Minneapolis, MN. based retail store front. Steve saw Familia as a way of giving back to the Minneapolis skate scene which he grew up in, and is active in maintaining the scenes continued growth. Familia doesn't have a team of riders, but instead has a family of friends who support each other.

name: Digital Skateboarding
description: Digital Skateboarding was started in 1999 by Bill Weiss, Rune Glifberg, Mike Crum and Donny Diederich. Digital Skateboarding's series of videos included full parts, montage sections, hi-jinx, and contest coverage from the day's top pros and ams. In 2009 however, Digital ceased production of physical videos and launched the Digital Skateboarding website as a platform for additional video parts, interviews and more.

name: Fogtown
description: Fogtown was a San Francisco based skate shop that operated in the late 1980s.

name: Essentials
description: Essentials is the manufacturer of price point skateboard parts, pads and accessories.

name: Finesse Skateboards
description: Founded in 2000 by Steve & Rod James, Finesse Skateboards is a San Diego based deck brand that exists to spread hope, inspiration and a love for skateboarding. Steve, Rod and the Finesse crew spends countless hours each year performing demos & skate clinics, in addition to teaching the youth of today about life choices and reaching their goals in life.

name: Giant Distribution
description: Giant Distribution was started in the early 1990s, and with the help of Steve Douglas grew to start and house some of the hottest brands of it's day. Giant brands included New Deal, Element, Mad Circle, 411 Video Magazine, Popwar, Bueno, Black Label, Vallely, Monster Trucks, Destructo and Golden State Wheel Co. to name a few.

name: Endless Grind
description: Endless Grind is a Naleigh, NC based skateboard shop that was founded by Reggie Barnes in 1986. Since then, Endless Grind has remained at the same location in downtown Raleigh where it supports and promotes the local skate community.

name: Far East Skateboards
description: Far East was a skateboard company that started out of Tampa, Florida in 1998. Original Far East team riders included Paul Zitzer, Mike Daher, Paul Urich, Mike Bouchard, Chris Williams, Jerry Gardina and Alan Russell.

name: Droors
description: Droors Clothing was a urban inspired apparel brand founded by Ken Block. Block started the brand in 1991 under the name Eightball but changed it to Droors in early 1992. In 1993, Ken Block and Damon Way co-founded a shoe division of Droors Clothing but shortened the name to simply DC as the company shifted it's focus towards footwear. At the end of 1998, DC sold Droors Clothing along with Dub Brand Outerwear to World Industries but the brand eventually folded in 2002.

name: Focus Skateboards
description: Focus was an early 1990s skateboard & snowboard company that was founded by Christian Hosoi, Eddie Reategui, Dave Duncan and Barret "Chicken" Deck in around 1993. Based out of Huntington Beach, California, Focus team riders included Christian Hosoi, Brian Patch, Chris Gentry, Andy Roy, George Morales and Mikey Chin to name a few. Focus riders also enjoyed Chicken's backyard pool as a local training ground.

name: DVS Shoes
description: DVS Shoes was started back in 1995 by the owners of 118 Boardshop and pro skater Tim Gavin. Their vision with DVS was to create a footwear brand dedicated to and designed specifically for skateboarding. Over the years, DVS has become a globally recognized force in the footwear market and has broadened it's reach into other action sports including surf, snow and moto. In the 2000s, DVS launched Original Intent as a division of skate shoes which are only available to "core" skate shops.

name: Escapist
description: Escapist is a Kansas City, Kansas based skate shop that was started in 2000 by three lifelong skateboarders. Their hopes with Escapist was to strengthen the Kansas City skateboard scene for future generations. Today Escapist is Kansas City's premier skater owned and skateboard focused shop in the metro area.

name: Expedition Skateboards
description: Expedition-One was founded back in 1997 by Chris Lambert, Alphonzo Rawls, Richard Angelides and Chany Jeanguenin. Over the years, Expedition-One has grown to become one of skateboarding's most respected brands through a special blend of smooth technical skating. Expedition-One also created The Kayo Corp in 2002 as distribution for the expanding brands.

name: Globe Shoes
description: Globe Shoes is a manufacturer of surf and skateboard footwear and apparel, formed in Melbourne, Australia in 1994 by former Australian professional skateboarders Matt, Steven, and Peter Hill. Globe's goal is to make better shoes to skate in, make better trunks to surf in, make lifestyle products that are cool, make films that inspire people, and produce events that bring like-minded people together to have some fun.

name: Emerica
description: Emerica is a skate specific footwear brand that was launched in 1996 as a division of Sole Technology. Over the years, Emerica has grown to embody the more hesh side of skateboarding, and therefore has amassed an almost cult-like following. Emerica is also responsible for the Wild in the Streets event, in which skateboards unite by the thousands to skate down city streets worldwide.

name: Entity Skateboards
description: Entity Skateboards was started in the early 1990's as a deck division for Gullwing Trucks and was managed by former Powell pro Steve Saiz. Entity team riders included June Cate, Rob Gonzalez, Donny Barley, Adrian Lopez, Paul Zitzer, Oscar Jordan, Andrew Currie, Steffan Attardo, Jason Carney, Scott Yamamura, Malcolm Watson, Rodd Marks, Rob Welsh, Rob Beesley, Ave Bunachita, Jason Carter, Jason Sides and Greg Janess.

name: Generation Skateboards
description: Generation Skateboards was a mid '90s deck brand with team riders that included Kit Erickson, Aaron Astorga, Joey Pulsifer and Oscar Jordan. In being based out of Huntington Beach, CA., Generation also had a sister surf/snowboard brand called Grind Inc. and a clothing company by the name of G1 Brand.

name: Formation Skateboards
description: Formation Skateboards is a Philadelphia based skateboard company that was started back in 2004. Formation is an art driven brand which offers extremely limited production decks from a global network of uniquely talented artists.

name: Electric Sunglasses
description: Founded in 2000 by Kip Arnette, Electric is a premium sunglasses, snow goggle, and accessories company that reflects the attitude and personalities of today's youth culture. Electric is defined by its iconic volt logo and has deep roots in action sports, music and fashion. In 2009, Electric was purchased by Volcom Clothing where it continues to grow with unlimited potential.

name: FKD Bearings
description: FKD Bearings was started back in 1989, and has since become one of skateboarding's leading bearing companies. Through extensive team rider testing, FKD strives to continually offer the highest level of speed, precision and durability possible. In addition to a large bearing line, FKD is also the manufacturer of high quality grip tape and hardware.

name: Focus Magazine
description: Focus Magazine was started in the mid 2000s by two friends looking to do something they love, be involved with skateboarding. With a focus on East Coast skateboarding and culture, this photographer/editor and graphic designer set out to shine a light on the scene and streets they hold so dear. Focus is produced bi-monthly and is available at finer skate shops everywhere.

name: dNA Skateboards
description: dNA Skateboards was a late 1990s to early 2000s deck company which had a science theme through the majority of their ads and graphics. dNA team riders included Jahmal Williams, Jerry Fowler, Matt Milligan, Jason Maxwell, John Buchanan, Jimmy Chadwick, Chris Livingston, Richie Belton and Paul Rodriguez amongst others.

name: Fillmore Wheels
description: Fillmore Wheels was started by Greg Carroll and Nick Tershay in the early 2000s out of Greg's Street Corner Distribution. The Fillmore name and funky 1970s aesthetic was inspired by a historic area of San Francisco known as the Fillmore. Fillmore Wheels later moved to the Girl family of brands during Greg's tenure there, and then again to Empire Distribution upon Greg's departure from Girl, but wound up calling it quits in the later 2000s.

name: Fallen Shoes
description: Fallen Footwear was started by Jamie Thomas in 2003 under a licensing and distribution deal with DC Shoes, but in 2004 was moved in-house to Jamie's Black Box Distribution for full control over Fallen's direction and identity. Fallen was geared more toward the underdog and adopted the tagline Rise With The Fallen. Fallen also grew to include a full clothing line by 2006, and began packaging many of their footwear riders to help strengthen and grow the brand. But unfortunately, Fallen was forced to call it quits in 2016 due to dwindling sales.

name: Genetic Shoes
description: Genetic Shoes was a footwear sub-division of Airwalk which was launched around 1999 or 2000. Genetic was created in an attempt to reach "core" skateboarders and skate shops, but ultimately fell short in sales and eventually got the plug pulled in 2003. The Genetic team was Jesse Paez, Bucky Lasek, Chad Bartie, Pat Channita, Danny Fuenzalida, Micah Hollinger, Alysson Castro, Jerry Smyth, Eric Shelley and Nick Jojola.

name: Fishlips Skateboards
description: Fishlips Skateboards was a Canadian based deck brand that first started selling decks in 1989. The company originally sponsored only local Canadian amateurs but grew to eventually sponsor a few pro's including Ray Underhill and most notably Mark "Gator" Rogowski, and released Gator's last ever pro deck before he was sent to jail for rape/murder in 1992.

name: Diakka Watches
description: Diakka Watches was founded by Steve Black around 1998 under the umbrella of Cyrus Industries, the manufacturers of TSA Clothing. Diakka was endorsed by Chad Muska, Clyde Singleton, Mark Appleyard and Rune Glifberg, but in being a higher end watch brand struggled to find their spot in the marketplace. Diakka only lasted a few short years before calling it quits in the early 2000s.

name: Front Clothing
description: Front Clothing was a mid 1990's apparel brand that was based out of Dayton, Ohio. We never heard for sure, but with Fred Gall, Scott Conklin, Lenny Kirk, Josh Kalis and Bo Turner involved and being located in Dayton, always assumed Front was linked to Alien Workshop or someone involved with Alien Workshop.

name: Eternal Skateboards
description: Eternal Skateboards was originally founded back in 1992. It all started as a hobby but demand grew and the brand was licensed to Trinity Distribution in 2004. What used to be a garage is now a warehouse with their own heat transfer machine. Eternal also produces boards for shops and other brands all over Australia and New Zealand.

name: Fresh Jive
description: "Freshjive was founded in 1989, originally intended to reflect the varied influences of my California lifestyle. The company became known as one of the originators of streetwear culture, both innovating and experimenting with progressive style and marketing, never afraid of doing the unexpected. In later years, a dissolution with the facade of street style and fashion in general lead the company into commercial statements about politics and the culture at large, culminating with an abrupt action against branded culture." - Rick Klotz

name: Freedom Skateboards
description: Freedom Skateboards was a deck company that operated in the early to mid 1990s. Freedom could have been a logo board company, as we can't recall the brand having any team riders.

name: Diamond Supply Co.
description: Diamond Supply Co. was started in the late 90s as the manufacturer of skateboard hardware and accessories. But in the early 2000s, Diamond began to carve a niche for itself by offering limited edition t-shirts which appealed to skaters, recording artists and street wear fans alike. These days, Diamond offers a full line of footwear & apparel, in addition to operating multiple retail stores across the United States.

name: Este Clothing
description: Este was a clothing company that was founded by Tim Brauch and Salman Agah in the mid 1990s as a sub-division of Sessions Skate Shop/Mail Order. The Este name came from a playful spin on the first name initials of Salman Agah and Tim Brauch. Este had an amazing team of all-terrain rippers but was forced to call it quits around 1998, at which point most of the remaining riders were absorbed into the Sessions Clothing team.

name: Forties Clothing
description: Forties Clothing was founded by Tommy Guerrero in the early 1990s and operated up until late 2002. Based out of Deluxe, and produced locally in San Francisco, Forties offered work-wear inspired apparel that was geared toward the skate, art, and tattoo cultures of it's day. Forties team riders included Tommy Guerrero, John Cardiel, Ray Barbee, Karma Tsocheff, Reese Forbes, Bobby Puleo, Jerry Hsu, Julien Stranger, Frank Gerwer, Ethan Fowler, and Jackson Taylor amongst others.

name: Dregs Skateboards
description: Dregs is the manufacturer of quality skateboards and longboards with fun and speed in mind. Dregs riders and owners have won numerous gold medals in the X-Games and Gravity Games in addition to setting numerous world records. But at the end of the day, fun and friends are what Dregs Skateboards are all about.

name: Dynasty Skateboards
description: Dynasty Skateboards was started in the late 1990s under the umbrella of Imperial Distribution, the makers of Maple and 151 Skateboards. The company employed an Asian kung fu style of graphics and marketing which set them apart, but also probably pigeon holed them to a certain degree. Dynasty team riders included Dan Connelly, Kien Lieu, John Reeves, Satva Leung, Spencer Fujimoto, Vinnie Ponte, Steve Nardone and Robert Lim.

name: Gatorade
description: Gatorade was created in 1965 as a drink that would replenish and revitalize athletes being affected by heat and heat related illnesses. Today, Gatorade continues to help athletes improve performance by facilitating proper hydration and nutrition through their G Series, G Series Fit, G Series Pro and G Natural beverage lines. In around 2008, Gatorade added skateboarders to their team of athletes with the signings of Sean Malto and Chaz Ortiz.

name: Forest Skateboards
description: Forest was started in 2007 when Fabrizio Santos came into contact with a financial backer who's son had a interest in skateboarding. Forest had a earthy vibe and solid team but was slow at introducing new products and became somewhat stale in the marketplace because of it. Issues like this led to mounting conflict between Fabrizio and the backer and eventually resulted in Fabrizio and the rest of the team leaving. Forest still has a website and social media which gets updated but hasn't introduced any new products since '09 so it's hard to say if they are still in business or not.

name: Girl Skateboards
description: Girl Skateboards has been home to skateboarding's elite since it's inception in 1993. Girl was founded by Rick Howard, Mike Carroll, Spike Jonze and Megan Baltimore after Rick and Mike felt World Industries was only in it for the money and was lying to it's riders about royalties. Girl quickly brought in Andy Jenkins whose artistic direction of the brand and later of The Art Dump defined the brand through art and humor.

name: Embassy Skateboards
description: Embassy Skateboards is a Texas based deck brand that is the brainchild of skateboard legend John "Tex" Gibson and his Bark Hard bandmate Lee Leal. In being a Texas owned and operated brand, Embassy's pride for the lone star state shows through in the majority of their deck designs. Embassy team riders include John "Tex" Gibson, Craig Johnson, Ken Fillion, Todd Prince, Troy Chasen, Max Peterson, Edward Sanchez and Ben Johnson amongst others.

name: eS Shoes
description: eS Footwear is a Sole Technology shoe brand that was established back in 1995.
