The name eS came from the first and last letters of their parent company Etnies. eS quickly became the gold standard for technical skate shoes, and always had the team to back it up. eS promoted skateboarding in a positive and fun light, and in 2003 introduced a hugely popular eS Game of SKATE tournament. In 2011, eS was forced to take a short hiatus, but came back with a renewed focus and strong as ever.

name: Cockroach Wheels
description: Cockroach Wheels was an Australian wheel brand that was known for printing cockroaches all over their wheels and t-shirts.

name: C1 Denim
description: C1 Denim was a clothing division of Circa Footwear which first launched around 2003. The C1 team included high profile riders such as Jamie Thomas, Adrian Lopez, Chad Muska, Chris Cole, Peter Ramondetta and Sierra Fellers but lasted no more than a year or two before calling it quits.

name: Boks Shoes
description: Boks Shoes was Reebok's futile 90s attempt at introducing a skate specific line of footwear. Boks had a few team riders with Neal Hendrix being the brand's main focus, but pulled the plug once sales didn't reach projections. Reebok eventually re-entered the market in 2005 after signing Stevie Williams as a rider and entering into a licensing contract with DGK for a line of Reebok x DGK footwear and apparel. This second coming of Reebok lasted longer than Boks did, but after a few short years folded for the same reasons.

name: Dekline
description: Dekline is a footwear line which was started in 2004 under the Tum Yeto umbrella of brands. In a short amount of time, Dekline carved out a niche for itself by creating timeless designs which draw inspiration from the skate, music, art and motorcycle cultures. Today, Dekline offers an extensive line of footwear, apparel & accessories while promoting the company tagline "Enjoy the Ride".

name: By The Sword
description: By The Sword Skateboards was formed in 2010 by Mike Vallely and Jason Filipow, with the phrase "DIY or Die" as their slogan. The company was meant to embody the toughness of Mike Vallely but dissolved less than 6 months later when Vallely returned to Powell Peralta. By The Sword was produced and distributed through Kristian Svitak's Regulator Distribution.

name: Counter Culture
description: Counter Culture was a mens clothing company which operated from the 1990s-2000s. Being based out of Huntington Beach, California, Counter Culture drew much of it's inspiration from Southern California's roots within the skate, surf and snowboard communities. A few Counter Culture riders included Mike Frazier, Adam McNatt, Scott Pazelt, Jake Stewart, Anthony Furlong and Billy Rohan.

name: Creation Skateboards
description: Creation Skateboards was started in 2004 by the founders of Satori Wheels with an initial team of Todd Jordan, Matt Pailes, Lucian Moon, Brian Delatorre & Guru Khalsa. Their intention with Creation was to offer positive vibes and eco-friendly products such as Recycled (reclaimed) wood & bamboo deck constructions, in addition to hemp/organic cotton apparel. Creation also created a unique line of longboards and cruiser boards with truly visionary graphics.

name: Blockhead Skateboards
description: Blockhead Skateboards started in 1984 and was considered by most to be a brand ahead of it's time. Blockhead was founded by Dave Bergthold who also employed Ron Cameron to create most of the brands graphics. Blockhead eventually folded in the mid '90s after helping launch many a career. Dave Bergthold recently revived the brand and has re-issued some classic Blockhead decks and t-shirts.

name: Bummer High
description: Bummer High is a deck company that celebrates heavy music and all things trippy. Originally launched in the late 2000s, Bummer High took a short hiatus before deciding to give the brand another chance in late 2014. Bummer High team riders have included Ethan Fowler and Daniel Shimizu.

name: Designarium
description: In 2004, Natas Kaupas started a new board company, Designarium under the manufacturing and distribution of NHS. Natas' art background led him to focus Designarium on artists rather than pro skaters. He has commissioned artists to interpret his original Santa Monica Airlines Panther graphic into their own vision. Each board is produced in limited edition, single production runs.

name: Capital Skateboards
description: Capital Skateboards was started in 1995 by Andy Stone and Pepe Martinez after leaving Underworld Element. Capital was backed by East Coast Urethane and in addition to Andy & Pepe included Chris Keefe, Kevin Taylor, Jim Menscer, Sean Mullendore, Ryan Hickey, Carlos Kenner and John Igei.

name: Consolidated Skateboards
description: Consolidated Skateboards was started by Steve "Birdo" Guisinger and photographer Steve Keenan after both quit their jobs at Santa Cruz in 1992. Consolidated marches to their own drum and utilizes a twisted sense of humor in their graphics. Consolidated also went on to launch their much publicized "Don't Do It" campaign against Nike in 1996, and again in 2001, and even sponsored a blanket team around 2004.

name: Camp Woodward
description: Founded in 1970 in Woodward, Pennsylvania, Camp Woodward hosts thousands of aspiring action sports, gymnastics and cheer athletes from around the world. Camp Woodward offers weekly summer camp programs in skateboarding, BMX freestyle, inline skating, snowboarding, freeski, gymnastics, cheer, and digital arts for kids 7 to 17. Other Woodward locations include Cable, WI., Copper Mountain, CO., Beiging, China, and Tehachapi & Soda Springs, CA.

name: Circa Footwear
description: C1RCA Footwear was started back in 1999 after signing Chad Muska, who had just left eS. C1RCA's first shoe, the CM901 created an instant demand but fell short after the wire meshing on the toe and side panels began to break and unravel, creating a returns nightmare for the brand. Jamie Thomas joined Muska later that year after quitting Adio, but the two both ended up leaving in '04. Today, C1RCA has a new squad and is going strong. Divisions of the C1RCA brand include Circa Combat, a "core" skate shop line and Circa Select, a boutique line with fashionable silhouettes.

name: Brick Harbor
description: Brick Harbor is an online retailer which specializes in "lifestyle" and hard to find brands relevant to and within skateboarding. Brick Harbor was launched in 2012 by online fashion retailer Karmaloop as a way for them to break into the skate market. Brick Harbor team riders have included PJ Ladd, Gino Iannucci, Stevie Williams, Jack Curtin, Dennis Busenitz, Ishod Wair, Daewon Song and Jake Johnson.

name: Color Skateboards
description: Color Skateboards was founded by Mark Oblow and Kris Markovich in the early 1990s and was backed by Rich Metiver. The Color team consisted of Kris Markovich, Jeremy Wray, Kyle Yanagimoto, Quy Nguyen, Jason Dill, Caine Gayle, Nate Lyons and Mike Santarossa. After releasing the self titled Color video in 1993, most all the team up and quit due to differences with Metiver, at which point most of them relocated to Prime.

name: Built To Shred
description: Built To Shred is the world's first build-and-ride sports show featuring top skateboarders and action sports riders. Each Built To Shred episode features host Jeff King working closely with the pros to design, build, and shred the sickest, most original obstacles ever made. Far-fetched ideas become shreddable realities as riders create legendary terrain and throw down tricks that have never before been done.

name: Crimson Skateboards
description: Crimson Skateboards was founded by Kris Markovich and Sam Uisprapassorn in around 2007. But after disagreements developed over the operations and direction of the company, Kris and Sam decided to part ways in 2008 under amicable terms. Kris took the team with him and went on to launch Given Skateboards independently.

name: Clean Skateboards
description: Clean Skateboards was a short lived deck brand from the mid 1990s. Clean team riders included Ricky Higgins, Sean Mullendore, Karl Watson, Jonas Wray and Barry Walsh amongst others.

name: Crailtap
description: Crailtap is the distribution and online media hub for the Girl Skateboards family of brands. Crailtap offers cheap thrills, and is responsible for bringing us countless Top 5's, Crail Couch interviews, and exclusive video/photo content with today and yesteryear's favorite skaters. Crailtap also hosts a shop finder to help locate a shop near you, or Crailstore where you can buy direct.

name: Black Magic Grip
description: Black Magic is a brand of grip tape that was created by Shorty's in the mid 1990s under their Shorty's Hardware umbrella of brands. Black Magic sponsored a slew of riders and quickly became the grip tape of choice for most skaters through the late 1990s to early 2000s.

name: Bustin Boards
description: Bustin Boards is a grassroots company designed by skaters and run by skaters. At Bustin Boards' Brooklyn longboard store and company headquarters they give customers friendly, personal service and helpful advice on choosing a longboard and/or longboarding product. Their longboards are pressed individually in a small, East Coast woodshop and hand printed and finished in their Brooklyn shop.

name: Camino Trucks
description: Camino Trucks are a San Clemente, California based manufacturer of super-carving, super-affordable longboard/cruiser trucks.

name: Coliseum Skate Shop
description: Coliseum was a Melrose, MA. based skate shop which operated through the 2000s, but ultimately was forced to close it's doors in 2009. Coliseum was largely responsible for helping launch the careers of PJ Ladd, Ryan Gallant, Jereme Rogers and Colin Fiske through the release of their widely successful PJ Ladd's Wonderful, Horrible, Life video in 2002.

name: Bootleg Skateboards
description: Bootleg Skateboards was originally conceived as a sister company to Baker, but found distributed through NHS rather than Blitz. J Strickland was the Bootleg brand manager and after leaving Baker due to mounting friction, often called out Baker and it's riders through Bootleg ads & graphics. Strickland built Bootleg through the same creative direction he had infused into Baker, but in the end struggled to gain the same momentum. Then in 2004, after Bootleg's 3 year partnership with NHS expired, NHS ceased production of all Bootleg products. Strickland tried shopping Bootleg around but failed to find a new home for the brand.

name: Broadcast Wheels
description: Broadcast is an independent wheel brand that was founded by Kelly D Williams in 2009. Broadcast offers premium urethane wheels with custom shapes and an artistic aesthetic. Current and former team riders have included Ethan Fowler, Paul Shier, Gareth Stehr, Shiloh Greathouse, Kevin Coakley, Brian Lotti, Danny Falla, Matt Ball, Lou Benton, Patrick Melcher, Jeremy Holmes, and Shane Cox.

name: Bueno Skateboards
description: Backed by Giant Dist., Bueno Skateboards was founded in 2005 by Stacy Lowery and Michael Sieben. Both were pretty sick of the ridiculous targetmarketing going on in skateboarding and wanted to spread the word that it's totally OK to be your own brand of weirdo. Stacy came up with the name and Michael gave the company an identity through his humor and art direction. Bueno eventually called it quits in 2007, but Stacy and Michael later reunited to form Roger Skateboards.

name: Bones Bearings
description: Bones Bearings has been the manufacturer & distributor of high performance and competition skateboard bearings since 1983, and is the standard by which all other bearings are measured. Bones offer bearings for all ability levels through a variety of styles including Bones Swiss Ceramics, Bones Swiss Labyrinth, Bones Super Swiss 6, Bones Swiss, Bones REDS, Bones Super REDS and Bones Ceramic Super REDS.

name: Death Skateboards
description: Death Skateboards is an independently owned and operated brand which is by and for skateboarders. With an Internationally renowned team, Death has gained global support and helped to launch the careers of several skaters including Patrick Melcher, Richie Jackson and Scott "Horsey" Walker to name a few.

name: Destructo Trucks
description: Destructo was formed in 1996 under Giant Distribution but began operating independently once Giant dissolved. Destructo trucks use weapon grade aluminum for strength, hollow kingpins for weight reduction, and come with a lifetime guarantee. Destructo's current and former team riders include Reese Forbes, Donny Barley, Arto Saari, Rodney Mullen, Jeremy Wray, Tony Cervantes, Chris Senn, David Loy, Ricky Oyola and Jake Johnson to name a few.

name: Channel One
description: Channel One Skateboards was a deck company founded by Marty "Jinx" Jimenez out of Costa Mesa, California. In 1991, Marty reached an agreement with Jim Gray of Acme where Jim would distribute Channel One's products, and Marty would do the majority of Acme's art in return. That agreement lasted until 1996 when the two companies parted ways.

name: Cali4nia Skatexpress
description: Cali4nia SKATExpress was a Fresno, California based mail order company which operated from the late 1980's to late 1990's. Cali4nia SKATExpress specialized in everything skate related including hardgoods, shoes, stickers and even punk rock music cd's.

name: Chocolate Skateboards
description: Chocolate was started in 1994 as a sister company to Girl with the original team of Chico Brenes, Daniel Castillo, Paulo Diaz, Richard Mulder, Shamil Randle, Gabriel Rodriguez and Ben Sanchez. Through a technical team of riders and outstanding art direction, Chocolate has grown into one of skateboarding's premiere companies.

name: Deca Skateboards
description: Deca Skateboards was started by Daewon Song in 1999 after 9 years with World Industries. This was a time when Flame Boy & Wet Willy were outselling every pro model and felt World could use a re-boot, and that re-boot came in the form of Deca. Daewon brought along Marcus McBride, Enrique Lorenzo, Shiloh Greathouse & J.B. Gillet, added a few new faces, and introduced Deca in the Rodney Mullen vs. Daewon Song: Round 2 video. In 2002 however, Deca decided to call it quits and re-booted itself again in the form of Artafact Skateboards.

name: Blacktop Grip
description: Blacktop Grip was a skateboard grip tape brand which offered more of a grittier surface.

name: Black Panthers
description: Black Panthers are a line of bearings which started under the umbrella of Quickies, a bearing division of Shorty's Hardware. Black Panthers were first introduced in 1996, around the time Chad Muska was joining Shorty's, and once Muska got on board Black Panthers became the must have bearings for every young skater. Black Panthers also sponsored most of the Shorty's Skateboards team and a handful of others. Today, Black Panthers are available in Abec 3, Abec 5, Abec 7, Ceramic and Swiss ratings.

name: Black Widow Grip
description: Black Widow is a grip tape brand which produces quality grip tape at a reasonable price, and is available in a wide array of colors.

name: Blue Skateboards
description: Blue Skateboards was started by Jason Lee, Chris Pastras and Kareem Campbell in 1992 after wanting more say in their graphics and marketing. Blue was backed by Brad Dorfman and grew a team that included Jason Lee, Chris Pastras, Kareem Campbell, Paulo Diaz, Steven Cales, and Sean Christopher, although Kareem quickly returned to World to launch Menace. In the end, Blue lasted less than a year, at which point Jason and Chris went on to launch Stereo through Deluxe Distribution.

name: Carolina Urethane
description: Carolina Urethane was a wheel company that operated out of Charlotte, North Carolina in the late 1990s. Carolina Urethane was a division of Queen City Skateboards and included team riders Stormy Pruett and Dan Pensyl.

name: Cream Skateboards
description: Cream Skateboards was founded by Rick Ibaseta, and with the help of Peter Huynh's art direction brought the brand to life around 1994. Cream was based out of San Francisco and was the manufacturer of decks and apparel. The Cream team was Rick Ibaseta, Jefferson Pang, Peter Huynh and Joey Alvarez, but was a bit ahead of it's time and lasted just a little over 2 years.

name: Black Label Skateboards
description: Black Label Skateboards was founded by John Lucero on the same punk rock principles and "Never be bought, never be sold" tagline it operates under today. Through Lucero's artwork and a motley collection of riders, Black Label has become one of skateboarding's longest running and most iconic brands. Black Label has also spawned a few sub-divisions over the years in the defunct Sixgun and their current veterans division Emergency.

name: Deathwish Skateboards
description: Deathwish Skateboards was founded by Erik Ellington and Jim Greco in 2008 under Baker Boys Distribution. Their plan was to create a sister brand for Baker under a new distribution, then bring Baker over once it's contract with Blitz expired, which they did in 2011. Deathwish created an instant fan base for itself through their raw graphics and team of misfit riders. The Deathwish name and logo comes from the Charles Bronson series of movies of the same name.

name: Destroyer Trucks
description: Destroyer was a truck brand that launched out of Giant Distribution in the early 2000s. Destroyer claimed to produce the toughest truck built and was marketed mostly toward handrail and stair skaters, but quickly called it quits once sales fell short. There was also much confusion between Destroyer and Destructo trucks, both of which operated out of Giant at the same time.

name: Bullet
description: Bullet was started out of NHS in the mid 1980s as a skateboard deck company. But it wasn't until Bullet introduced a line of wheels under the Santa Cruz banner of Speed Wheels that the brand really began to find it's stride. Bullet Wheels became wildly popular and boasted a team of heavy hitters including Steve Alba, Jason Jessee, Rick "Spidey" Demontrond, Jeff Grosso, Steve Godoy, Eddie "El Gato" Elguera, Corey O'Brien, Ken Fillion and Dave Donalson. Today, Bullet is the manufacturer of price point decks, trucks, wheels, hardware and safety gear.

name: Deadbolt Trucks
description: Dead Bolt Trucks was an early 90s truck company that was backed by Airbourne Skateboards. The Dead Bolt truck design used an upside-down hexhead king pin that sat a bit lower and was guaranteed unbreakable. A few Dead Bolt team riders included Oscar Jordan, Chris Griffiths, Ozzy Alvarez, Dan Tag, Ben Horton, Mike Denton, Jak Barnett and Ty Gilbert.

name: BLVD Skateboards
description: BLVD Skateboards was launched in 2010 by Rob Gonzalez and Danny Montoya. BLVD is somewhat of a re-branding of Listen Skateboards, but rather than continue the brand independently found a home at Syndrome Distribution. BLVD supports a team of technical skaters including Rob Gonzalez, Danny Montoya, Danny Supa, Rodrigo Peterson, Nate Fantasia, Jose Pereyra, Billy Davenport and Jordan Sanchez.

name: Boost Mobile
description: Boost Mobile is a division of the Sprint Corporation which offers wireless phones and services with no contracts, credit checks or activation fees. Boost is among the most popular prepaid wireless brands in the U.S. and has approximately four million customers.

name: Cash Skateboards
description: Cash Skateboards was a short lived 90s deck company which was based out of the Huntington Beach, California area. Cash team riders included Jeremy Corley, Mario Dauz, Raul Lizarraga, Charlie Spowl and Juan Carlos Montero amongst others.

name: Bones Wheels
description: Bones Wheels was started 25 years ago as a wheel division of Powell Peralta, but has grown to stand as it's own brand behind a commitment to produce the highest quality urethane's available. Through continued improvements on present technologies, Bones Wheels is available to offer a diverse line of specific formulations for all terrain types. Bones Wheels is also the manufacturer of soft goods, high performance bushings, hardware, and accessories.

name: Brixton Headwear
description: Brixton was founded in 2004 by Transworld Skateboarding employee David Stoddard as a headwear brand inspired by music, culture, and the people who surround them. Brixton's timeless and clean designs are hard to duplicate and come in a variety of styles that appeal to the individual in a modern yet traditional way. Today, Brixton produces finer headwear as well as a collection of tees, tops and jackets. Each piece is constructed with the commitment to bringing the customer a high quality and limited product that they'll want to hold onto forever.

name: Death Box Skateboards
description: Death Box was founded by Jeremy Fox in 1987 and was Europe's number one skate brand during it's existence. The name Death Box related to the term used for the swimming pool overflow channel and was originally aimed toward old school backyard pool skaters. Death Box also had a sister company named Bash which eventually evolved into Flip Skateboards. In 1993, Death Box merged with Flip and shortly after relocated to the USA.

name: Brand X Skateboards
description: Brand X was a skateboard brand that existed between approximately 1982, to about 1989. Brand X's team captain was Jeremy Fox (Death Box/Flip Owner) and their riders included Ken Sigafoos, Dave Crabb, Bob Schmeltzer, Ed Gein, and Sean Goff to name a few.

name: Carhartt
description: Carhartt Inc. was established in 1889 in Detroit, Michigan USA by Hamilton Carhartt. For over 120 years Carhartt has been dedicated to its mission of providing Best In Class apparel for the active worker. Today, Carhartt is known for a supreme collection and its dedicated support of upcoming artists, musicians, skateboarders and BMX riders.

name: Cappeline
description: Cappeline is a Los Angeles based headwear company which provides stylish caps for your dome piece. Cappeline was established in 2008 by former Liberty Skateboards and Channel One amateur Ron Resurreccion.

name: Darkside Grip
description: Darkside is a grip tape brand which is manufactured through Core Distribution. In addition to grip tape, Darkside has also begun to produce decks, wheels, apparel and accessories.

name: Converse
description: Converse Footwear was founded in 1908 by Marquis Mills Converse after deciding to start a rubber shoe company. Converse is most widely known for their Chuck Taylor sneaker which they've been producing since the 1940s. Converse first started marketing to skateboarders in the 1980s but it wasn't until the 1990s that they first introduced a skate team and skate specific shoes. That initial skate program was eventually dissolved but decided to give it another go in the late 2000s under the name Cons.

name: City Stars Skateboards
description: City Stars was founded by Kareem Campbell in 1999 under the umbrella of Dwindle Distribution. The brand was originally named Menace and then All City before becoming City Stars in '99. In 2000, Kareem moved City Stars out of Dwindle and founded KSL Distribution as the distributor of City Stars Skateboards, Aerial Wheels, Velocity Bearings and Cotton Mouth Clothing. There were also talks of a City Stars shoes line since Dwindle forced Kareem to leave Axion behind, but nothing ever materialized. Today Kareem still operates the brand and distributes it through Push Distribution which he started along with Mike Crum and Texas skate pioneer Al Coker.

name: Clive Backpacks
description: Clive was a backpack and specialty travel gear company from the late 1990s to early 2000s which marketed to the surf, skate and snowboard communities. Clive offered an extensive line of comfortable yet durable packs with skate specific features, and was one of the first brands to offer pro model backpacks. Clive also offered a full lifetime warranty on all their bags, but once they folded in the early 2000s we assume said warranty became null in void. The Clive skate team consisted of Bam Margera, Stevie Williams, Bucky Lasek, Kerry Getz, Neal Mims and Colt Cannon.

name: Blackout Skateboards
description: Blackout was the manufacturer of quality price point skateboard decks, trucks and wheels. Although Blackout had more of a punk rock image, the brand was strictly focused on entry level pricing in effort to keep skateboarding affordable.

name: Bulldog Skates
description: Wes "Bulldog" Humpston founded Bulldog Skates as an extension of nearly thirty years of experience in the world of art and board making. Wes first began making boards for his friends in the mid 1970s in a garage in Santa Monica, California and later went on to help start Dogtown Skates with Jim Muir. In 2002, Wes started Bulldog Skates along with Rich Fosmire where they continue to redesign and develop new designs and constructions while paying homage to skateboarding's past. The Bulldog crew also consists of legendary photographers Daniel Harold Sturt and Chris Olden who photograph all of Bulldog's advertising materials.

name: Chrome Bags
description: Chrome first started making bags in 1995 with the goal of producing a functional yet durable messenger bag that could withstand the abuse that comes with living and riding in the city. Today, Chrome continues to produce military grade material bags which are built to withstand whatever abuse the streets can dish out. All Chrome bags are made by hand and come with a lifetime guarantee.

name: Darkstar
description: Darkstar Wheels was started by Chet Thomas in 1997 under the World Industries umbrella of brands. Darkstar carved out an instant niche through medieval art direction and a push toward dual durometer wheels. Then in 2000 after A-Team was dissolved, Chet Thomas added a Darkstar Wood division consisting of himself, Ryan Kenreich and amateur Guy Kampfen. Today, Darkstar continues to produce quality decks and wheels in addition to price point completes, apparel and accessories.

name: Deville
description: Deville is the manufacturer of quality longboard decks, wheels, apparel and accessories. Deville wheels are made in the U.S.A. by Creative Urethanes and offer a guarantee against flatspots.

name: Coffee Clothing
description: Coffee Clothing was a female apparel line from the mid 1990s. Quite a few female clothing lines popped up around this time for the "skater chick" although none lasted more than a year or two. We're not sure is Coffee was on it's own or was distributed through another skate brand.

name: Cadillac Trucks
description: Cadillac was a truck brand which was started in the late 1990s as a sub-division of Madrid Skateboards. In being based out of Huntington Beach, California, Cadillac sponsored quite a few local skaters including Jose Cerda and Austen Seaholm.

name: Blind Skateboards
description: Blind Skateboards was started by Mark Gonzales in '89 after parting ways with Vision. At the time, Mark was contemplating retirement because he didn't like the way Vision operated and felt skateboarding was no longer fun. Steve Rocco convinced Mark not to quit and to instead start a company with him where he could do whatever he wanted. Mark eventually left Blind due to the same frustrations he had with Vision and started ATM Click.

name: Clout Skateboards
description: Clout was an early to mid 1990s skateboard company that was based just outside of San Francisco, California. Clout team riders included Danny Minnick, Brad Johnson, Pat Washington, Nikhil Thayer and Erik Ellington. Clout also had a sister clothing company named Jugs Attire which sponsored both skaters as well as snowboarders.

name: Blueprint Skateboards
description: Blueprint Skateboards is a brand operated in the UK by Paul Shier and Dan Magee.

name: Concrete Jungle
description: Concrete Jungle was a San Francisco, California based skate shop and deck company from the late 1980s. Concrete Jungle had a team of solid local talent and helped to launch the careers of such legendary skateboarders as Danny Sargent, Micke Reyes, Noah Salasnek, Aaron Vincent and Mike Archimedes to name a few. In addition to decks, Concrete Jungle also produced Borgy Copers with a few cross over team riders in addition to a couple outside riders including Tommy Guerrero, Bryce Kanights and Eric Dressen.

name: City Skateboards
description: City Skateboards is a San Francisco based brand out of Street Corner Distribution.

name: Church of Skatan
description: Church of Skatan is a Santa Barbara, Ca. based skate shop that was founded by Tony Buyalos of Shorty's. Church of Skatan has been in a long standing feud with Powell after feeling Powell stole their idea with Powell's Rat Nuts hardware. Over the years, this feud has caused Church of Skatan to stop carrying Powell products, spurred an advertising war and lead to Church of Skatan's now infamous Dragon Slayer graphic.

name: Carveboard
description: Brad Gerlach and his father Joe came up with the idea for Carveboard in the late 1990s. The main objective was to create a board which enabled beginners to pros, the ability to work on their surfing or snowboarding when the snow melts or the surf is flat.

name: Change Skateboards
description: Bill Weiss founded Change Skateboards in 1993 after returning to the U.S. The Change team consisted of Bill Weiss, Lance Conklin, Justin Bokma and Bucky Lasek, but only made it a few short years before it's financial backer pulled out due to dwindling sales.

name: Clockwork Skateboards
description: Clockwork Skateboards was a short lived brand founded by Brian Patch in the late 1990s. Clockwork operated out of an extra office at Channel One in Huntington Beach, CA., but didn't see much in the way of sales and ended up folding fairly quickly. Clockwork and had a solid team of local rippers including Brian Patch, Stacy Lowery, Jason Odell, Anthony Acosta and a young Ryan Sheckler.

name: Chapman Skateboards
description: Chapman is a New York based skateboard manufacturer that was founded in 1991 by longtime skater Gregg Chapman. Over the years Chapman has earned the respect as one of skateboarding's premiere wood shops through it's quality and craftsmanship. In 1999, Chapman launched it's own board brand Chapman Skateboards with pros Billy Rohan, Mathias Ringstrom and Danny Gonzalez. Today Chapman continues manufacturing decks for skateboarding's top brands while also operating a Factory Warehouse Outlet in Deer Park, NY.

name: Deluxe Distribution
description: Deluxe Distribution is the San Francisco based distributor of Real Skateboards, Spitfire Wheels, Anti-Hero Skateboards, Krooked Skateboards, Thunder Trucks, Venture Trucks and SuperCush Bushings. Deluxe also has a local retail outlet which they've operated since around 1993. A few of Deluxe's previous and defunct brands have included Rasa Libre Skateboards, Stereo Skateboards, Metropolitan Wheels and Forties Clothing.

name: Bro Style
description: Bro Style is a grip tape and accessory company that jokingly started around a New Mexico campfire in 2012. Founded by Leo Romero and Griffin Collins, Bro Style never takes itself seriously but instead celebrates the time spent and positive vibes of skating with your bros. Bro Style team riders include Leo Romero, Chima Ferguson, Daniel Lutheran, Jaws, Brandon Westgate, and Matt Bennett to name a few.

name: CCS
description: CCS, originally known as California Cheap Skates is skateboarding's original mailorder company. CCS has been sold several times over the years with the latest acquisition coming in 2008 when the company was purchased by mega retailer Foot Locker.

name: Capix
description: Founded in 2000, Capix was started with the objective of improving on the helmet designs which were available at the time. As public skate parks with helmet laws started popping up across the U.S., Capix found instant success through their offering of thinner hat shaped helmets. Capix was also one of the first to offer pro model helmets, with signature models from Danny Way, Colin McKay, Chet Thomas and Gershon Mosley. Today, the Capix line has expanded to not only include helmets, but also safety equipment and accessories for skate, snow, wake and bike.

name: Crime Skateboards
description: Crime Skateboards was a price point deck line which promoted the long standing phrase "Skateboarding Is Not A Crime". Skateboarding Is Not A Crime stickers and t-shirts were first introduced by NHS Distribution in the 1980s, and by the 2000s had launched a full line of Crime Skateboard decks. NHS has since ceased production of Crime decks, although Skateboarding Is Not A Crime stickers are still available, and always should be.

name: Deathbox Skateboards
description: Deathbox Skateboards is a deck brand made for the blue collar worker who's still looking to carve up some pools. The name Deathbox comes from a term used for the swimming pool overflow channel. Deathbox aims to respect as well as honor skateboarding's forefathers, and also to respect and honor the determination and loyalty of those who still skate for the purity of it all.

name: Circuit Wheels
description: Circuit was a wheel company that started out of Think in late 1995. I believe Circuit was run by Lance Conklin and included team riders Danny Way, Tom Penny, Caine Gayle, Bill Weiss, Mike Crum, Pat Duffy, Ron Whaley, Diego Bucchieri and Daewon Song.

name: CBS Skateboards
description: CBS, also known as Creative Board Specialists was a skateboard deck and wheel company which was started in the later 1990s. CBS was based out of Baltimore, Maryland and was headed by Jason Chapman. CBS also operated a short lived sub-division brand named Big Company.

name: Crail Trucks
description: Crail Trucks is a Brazilian based company that was created to overcome the non-friendly streets of Sao Paulo and feed the Brazilian skaters a high-quality product. Crail trucks are manufactured at their own foundry.

name: DC Shoes
description: DC Shoe Co. was founded in 1993 by Ken Block and Damon Way as a footwear extension of Droors Clothing, hence the name DC Shoes. DC Shoes established itself early through their progressive styles and an elite skate team. But as years passed, DC became more of a mainstream brand for the masses and in 2004 was acquired by Quiksilver. Today, DC's line of products include men's, women's and kids' footwear, apparel, snowboard boots, outerwear, snowboards, accessories and more.

name: Celtic Skateboards
description: Celtic Skateboards is an East Coast skateboard company that merged with Origin Skate Trucks back in 2008. A few Celtic team riders include Clay Kreiner, Miles Canevello and Zach Gillespy.

name: Comune
description: Comune Clothing was formed from the idea that there will always be people out there who not only embrace the rawness and imperfections of everyday life but use it to creatively push the boundaries of what's possible in skateboarding, fashion, art, and music their own way, with complete disregard of the consequences. Comune's goal is to provide clothing that reflects this lifestyle of carefree idealism and to support the people that choose to live it.

name: DaKine
description: Originally founded back in 1979, DaKine is the manufacturer of high quality backpacks, luggage, apparel and accessories. The name DaKine comes from the Hawaiian Pidgin word "da kine" meaning "the kind" or "the best". With deep roots in action sports communities, DaKine proudly supports riders within the surf, skate, snowboard, ski, bike, windsurf, kite and girls cultures.

name: Cliche Skateboards
description: Cliche Skateboards was founded by Jeremie Daclin in the summer of 1997 in Lyon, France. Since then, Cliche has assembled one of the most diverse International teams and has released multiple critically acclaimed videos. In 2001, Cliche was acquired by Solomon and then again in 2009 by Dwindle Distribution, although Jeremie Daclin along with Al Boglio continue the brand direction and marketing. Cliche team riders have included JB Gillet, Lucas Puig, Jeremie Daclin, Andrew Brophy, Joey Brezinski, Pete Eldridge, Cale Nuske, Lem Villemin, and Pontus Alv to name a few.

name: Circle-A Skateboards
description: Circle-A was a '80s brand founded by professional skateboarder Bob Schmeltzer. Circle-A team riders included Ricky Winsor, Duane Peters, Bob Schmeltzer, Steve Godoy, Joe Lopes, Todd Prince and a few others. Circle-A folded around 1990 but has recently been revived with a new team and direction.

name: Creature Skateboards
description: Creature Skateboards was started out of NHS in 1994 by SMA team manager Russ Pope. Jason Adams, Barker Barrett and Darren Navarrette were the early riders although Adams left fairly quickly to help Pope start Scarecrow. NHS was forced to put Creature on the shelf in the late 1990s but revived the company in the mid 2000s with Darren Navarette and Lee Charron sharing in the duties of running the team and creative direction of the company.

name: Brigada Eyewear
description: The idea of Brigada eyewear was first conceived in early 2006 by Jim Greco, Andrew Reynolds, Terry Kennedy and Erik Ellington. Together they came up with the name Brigada, meaning a brigade or crew, sketched up a logo at the local diner and gathered ideas for things they'd like to see made. Brigada took off fairly quickly but after a couple years began to sit idly by as the group got busy with other projects. Then in 2012, Brigada looked to re-launch the brand with team riders Andrew Reynolds, Terry Kennedy, Paul Rodriguez and Mike "Lizard King" Plumb.

name: BRNO  Skate Ind. Co.
description: BRNO Skate Ind. Co. was a deck brand which was based out of the U.K. in the late 1990s.

name: American Nomad
description: American Nomad was founded in 2003 by Jay Kelly and Bill Danforth as a deck company geared toward pool and transition skating. American Nomad decks are made in the USA and feature some great artwork that's reminiscent of the 1980s. A few American Nomad team riders have included Abe Towery, Bill Danforth, Chris Hamilton, Dave Slivers, Fred Smith, Bill Tocco, Jay Kelly, John Hinkle, John Schultes, Justin Harter, Monty Nolder, Nick Bratko, Tom Popp, Ward Cramer and Zack Gagnon.

name: Airbourne Skateboards
description: Airbourne was a brand that lasted from the late '80s to early '90s and whose line of products included Airbourne skateboards, Losi Skate Designs skateboards, Dead Bolt trucks and Flyaway helmets.

name: Aeon Footwear
description: Aeon Footwear was a French shoe company that started around 2002. Aeon was backed by the guys at Lordz Wheels & Square Skateboards, and therefore had a pretty heavy hitting team right out of the gates. Aeon team riders included Alex Carolino, Florentine Marfaing, Bastien Salabanzi, William Phan, Franck Barattiero, Luy-Pa Sin and Baptiste Myzor.

name: Arsenal Skateboards
description: Arsenal Skateboards was a Southern California based deck brand from the later 1990s. Arsenal had a solid team in Tom Boyle, Mike Rafter, Aric Hondel, Jon Miner, Adam Beltz, Judd Hertzler, Jayme Fortune, Tony Dasilva and Abiram Bathgate, but for whatever reason never really took off.

name: 3DM Wheels
description: 3DM Wheels are the premier skateboard wheel brand for longboard, cruiser, giant slalom, and downhill riding. 3DM Wheels are available in several styles including their iconic Avila and Cambria shapes as well as a wide variety of sizes and hardnesses for all types of terrain.

name: Basic Skateboards
description: Basic Skateboards was founded in around 1990 by Greg Castle and Buddy Carr in Huntington Beach, California. Basic produced decent boards, and around 1993 introduced Wax Wood which was the process of bonding wax to the bottom of the board, creating a similar surface to slick bottoms. By the mid 1990s, Basic also introduced a line of snowboards but in 1996 changed their name to Basic International.

name: Adidas Skateboarding
description: Adidas was formed back in August of 1949 as the manufacturer of athletic footwear and apparel. Over the years, Adidas has grown to encompass all major sports and by the mid 1990s introduced a line of skateboard footwear with a diverse group of team riders. This original skate division lasted into the early 2000s, but was re-booted in the mid 2000s under the name Adidas Skateboarding with a condensed team consisting of Mark Gonzales, Tim O'Connor and Dennis Busenitz.

name: Beer City Skateboards
description: Beer City Skateboards was started in 1993 with the goal of making high quality products that could hold up to hardcore skating. At the same time, Beer City also saw the need for a record label that could put out real HXC/punk music and founded Beer City Records. The name Beer City is in reference to the company being based out of Milwaukee, Wisconsin, the beer capital of the world. Nowadays Beer City is a full on skateboard company and record label which also produces a line of hardware under the name Beer Nutz.

name: Airwalk Shoes
description: Airwalk was founded in 1986 and was one of the first brands to offer skate specific features such as lace saver flaps and rubber ollie pads.

name: Armourdillo
description: Armourdillo was launched in Melbourne, Australia in 2003 by a group of guys who weren't satisfied with the accessories available at the time. In establishing Armourdillo, they decided to never compromise on the things that matter most; design, color, leathers, and build quality. Armourdillo is marketed toward the action sports lifestyle and proudly supports riders within the skate, surf, snow, bmx and fmx communities.

name: Aesthetics Skateboards
description: Aesthetics was founded by Sal Barbier and Palmer Brown after the demise of 23 Skateboards. Aesthetics had a good run but began to unravel due to internal conflicts between Sal and Palmer. Sal offered to buy Aesthetics from Palmer multiple times, but Palmer demanded an unrealistic amount so the brand was ultimately purchased by Ecko Unlimited, the makers of Zoo York. After the acquisition, Aesthetics was quickly dissolved and it's riders were absorbed by Zoo York and given 2 year Zoo contracts.

name: ATM Click
description: ATM Click was founded by Mark Gonzales after leaving Blind Skateboards in the mid 1990's. Mark left ATM Click fairly quickly to start 60/40 Skateboards, at which point the company changed their name to ATM under which they still operate today. ATM was also known as ATM Sport for a short period in the late 1990's.

name: Alien Workshop
description: Alien Workshop Skateboards was formed by Mike Hill and Chris Carter after leaving G&S in 1990, and with some help from Neil Blender shaped an identity filled with paranoid and paranormal themes. From it's eccentric, high caliber team riders to their individualistic approach to products and audio/visual projects, Alien Workshop is driven to rewrite the skateboard company definition. In 2008, Alien Workshop was acquired by Burton Snowboards, but in 2012 was purchased back by original Alien Workshop team rider Rob Dyrdek.

name: & Skateboards
description: G&S updated their image in the early 1990s, dropping the "G" and "S" to become & Skateboards. The company ran along for a few years but was disbanded in 1993, when Jason Carney, Donger, and Thom Hornung left to join Maple Skateboards.

name: Antix
description: Antix was a early 2000s website which covered the topics of skateboarding, music, entertainment and mischief. We never checked it out, but did notice antix.com in more than a few Dwindle company ads around that time and always assumed it was associated with, or out of the Dwindle fold.

name: Anarchy Eyewear
description: Anarchy Eyewear was started in the 1990s as an extension of Quantum Optics, Inc. Quantum launched both Anarchy and Angel Eyewear in hopes of marketing to the angst youth of the day with influences from the core music and action sports scenes. Anarchy team riders included Simon Woodstock, Stu Graham, Ronson Lambert, Josh Zickert, Arturo Sanchez, and Donovan Dresti.

name: Balance Skateboards
description: Balance was a deck company started by Bill Weiss in around 1996 after the demise of Premier Skateboards. Balance was based out of Huntington Beach, California and was partnered with Zimbabwe Skateboards. The Balance team consisted of Bill Weiss, Troy O'Mahoney, Matt Milligan, Corey Sheppard, Erik Ellington, Scott Copalman, Jason Searcy, Mike Bell, Aaron Pearcey and Jason Shelton.

name: A-Team Skateboards
description: A-Team Skateboards was founded by Rodney Mullen in 1997 as skateboarding's next super team. A-Team came at just the right time and helped spawn the Rodney Mullen vs Daewon Song video series which featured competing rider and team segments. Ultimately, A-Team struggled with poor art direction which many believe led to it's demise in 2000. After A-Team was dissolved, Marc Johnson started Enjoi and brought Rodney Mullen and Dave Mayhew along, Gershon Mosley found a home at Blind and Chet Thomas went on to add a deck division to Darkstar Wheels.

name: Axion Footwear
description: Axion Footwear was the brainchild of Kareem Campbell, who founded and co-owned the brand in the mid 1990s. But Kareem was forced to leave Axion behind when he fled the Dwindle camp in 2000 to independently run City Stars Skateboards. After Kareem's departure the brand lost much of it's direction and began to struggle, eventually folding in the early 2000s. In 2009, the Axion name was purchased and revived with new designs and team riders including Kevin Taylor, Mike Maldonado, Manny Santiago and Kyle Nicholson.

name: 23 Skateboards
description: 23 Skateboards was founded in 1996 by Sal Barbier under the umbrella of Bounty Hunter Distribution. Sal received help from Jason Dill & former Birdhouse team manager Tom Drake and put 23 on the map with a team of Sal, Jason Dill, Drake Jones, Ronnie Bertino, Clyde Singleton and Anthony Van Engelen. But after Dill and AVE were abducted by Alien Workshop the brand was never really the same, and Sal eventually pulled the plug in 1998 to start Aesthetics.

name: 55DSL
description: 55DSL was a skate oriented division of denim giant Diesel Jeans that operated in the early 2000s. 55DSL supported a few skaters including Tony Hawk, Steve Berra and Mathias Ringstrom, and sponsored a ton of International skate contests, but never quite caught on in the United States as well as it did overseas.

name: Antisocial Skate Shop
description: Anti-Social is a Vancouver, Canada based retail store that was founded by Rick McCrank in the early 2000s. Anti-Social is one of Vancouver's premiere skate shops and has had an active hand in the continued growth of it's local skate and art scenes.

name: AWH
description: Founded in 1976, AWH is one of the United States's largest distributors of skateboarding hardgoods and apparel.

name: Bacon Skateboards
description: Originally from the small coastal town of Cayucos, CA. and now from Portland, OR., Bacon Skateboards consists of skateboarders who ride their skateboards because they enjoy to do so.

name: 118 Board Shop
description: 118 Board Shop is a skateboard and snowboard retailer located in Granada Hills, California. Founded in the early 1990s by the Dunlap family, 118 became the most legit core shop in the area, but more importantly a place where like-minded friends could call home. The owners of 118 also went on to start DVS Shoes in 1995 and Matix Clothing in 1998.

name: 48 Blocks
description: 48 Blocks was started in 2006 as a San Francisco, California based skateboard blog and media outlet which offers rare and exclusive interviews with current and former top pro/amateur skaters. The name 48 Blocks is in reference to the journey through Golden Gate park, and how you've gotta make it through those 48 Blocks to get where you wanna be, but you should also be enjoying the ride.

name: Awesome Sports Skate Shop
description: Awesome Sports was a southern California based skate shop and mail order business which operated during the 1990s.

name: Aurora Wheels
description: Started in the early 2000s, Aurora was a short lived wheel company that was based out of Southern California's Orange County. Aurora team riders included Ron Whaley, Mike Santarossa, Jake Stewart, Anthony Carney, Austen Seaholm and Jud Heald.

name: Asphalt Yacht Club
description: Asphalt Yacht Club is a clothing company that Stevie Williams launched in 2013. With attention to quality and design, Asphalt Yacht Club offers a collection with unique style and personality. AYC team riders have included Stevie Williams, Stefan Janoski, Nyjah Huston, Justin Figueroa, Riley Hawk, Ben Nordberg, Derrick Wilson and Blake Carpenter.

name: Becker Skate Shop
description: Becker Surf Shop was founded in 1980 by surfboard shaper Phil Becker. Becker opened it's first location in Hermosa Beach, California, but over time grew to include 4 retail locations and an online store. Becker had a solid skate team through the 1990s, but has since returned their focus to surfing and longboard skating.

name: Arnette
description: Founded in 1992, Arnette Eyewear is the manufacturer of finer sunglasses and goggles. What started in a Orange County garage quickly carved out a niche for themselves within the surf, skate and snow communities of the time. Arnette is dedicated to the continued pursuit of progressive design, maximum functionality and unparalleled quality.

name: 26 Redtred
description: 26 Redtred was a random shoe brand that popped up in the mid-to-late 1990's.

name: Ace Trucks
description: Founded in 2006, Ace Truck Mfg. is the producer of high quality skateboard trucks and accessories. Ace trucks are available in a wide range of sizes and colors and are the only truly independent skateboard truck brand on the market today. A few Ace team riders include Donny Barley, Lavar McBride, Matt Rodriguez, Matt Miller, Chris Pastras, Mike Peterson, Ryan Lay, Sergie Ventura, Bennett Harada, Joey Tershay, Max Barrera, Rodney Jones and Raven Tershy.

name: Biltin Bearings
description: Biltin Bearings was born from the desire to develop high performance products for street skaters and longboarders alike. By using state-of-the-art technology and high quality materials, Biltin is able to deliver superior products at a reasonable cost for skaters.

name: Avera Skateboards
description: Avera was a Canadian based company that produced decks, wheels, clothing and accessories. Avera products were primarily at the price point level in an effort to keep skateboarding affordable and target skaters who were maybe just starting out.

name: Alphanumeric Clothing
description: Originally launched in 1998, Alphanumeric Clothing also known as A# was a San Diego, Ca. based clothing company managed by Mikro Mangum and Sal Masekela along with designer Alyasha Owerka-Moore. Alphanumeric promoted itself as an EnvironMental Protection Company while utilizing educational-based ad campaigns. As one of the early streetwear brands, Alphanumeric's technical apparel had a skate influence but also crossed over into surfing, snowboarding, car culture and music. Alphanumeric called it quits in the early 2000s but resurfaced around 2008 to give the brand a second chance.

name: Axis Shoes
description: Axis Shoes was a short lived footwear brand that started in the early 2000s. A few Axis team riders included Gary Smith, Dan Pageau and Jim Bates.

name: Acme Skateboards
description: Acme Skateboards was founded by Jim Gray in 1991 after leaving Blockhead. Acme had a good run through the majority of the '90s and even grew to introduce Formula One as a sub-division of decks and wheels. But in the end, it was Steve Rocco who brought down Acme after the company printed multiple ads mocking  World's trademarked characters.

name: Big Brother Magazine
description: Steve Rocco founded Big Brother in 1992 after Transworld refused to run one of his ads. With little emphasis on skateboarding, Big Brother became another one of Rocco's vehicles to push buttons and boundaries with. Mark McKee also invested in Big Brother and assumed it's role of Editor. In 1997, Big Brother was purchased by Larry Flynt Publishing, Inc., the publishers of Hustler Magazine who were looking for new magazines. In 2000, LFP, Inc. accidentally mixed the subscriber lists for the June issue of Big Brother with Taboo, a hardcore porn magazine. An apology letter was sent once the mistake was realized, but imagine that didn't go far with angry skateboard parents who's mailboxes received Taboo.

name: AZPX
description: AZPX is a Arizona based deck company that was founded in 2002 by Rob Locker. The name AZPX comes from an abbreviation of the term Arizona Punx. AZPX also had a zine called Rubber Toe which came shrink wrapped in most of their boards. AZPX team riders included Chris Gobber, Rich Zuccarello, Drake Hendrix, Tony Christopher, Casey Cooper, Hippie Steve, Omar Guerrero, Brian Pino, Dan McCabe and Bucky Meinerz, plus a ton more local Arizona talent.

name: 777 Skateboards
description: 777 Skateboards was a short lived deck brand from the early 1990s. Can't say we recall much about 777 other than that Ricky Oyola, Kien Lieu and Ben Liversedge were a few of the team riders.

name: 187 Killer Pads
description: 187 Killer Pads was founded by Vinton Pacetti in 1999 out of a family owned upholstery shop. Since then, 187 Killer Pads has been designing and constructing pads for the top pool and vert skaters, and has become the preferred choice of skaters worldwide.

name: All City Skateboards
description: In 1998, Menace Skateboards was forced to change it's name due to a trademark conflict and was re-named and re-branded as All City Skateboards. And then in 1999, All City changed it's name again to City Stars Skateboards for the same reason.

name: 411VM
description: 411 Video Magazine was founded by skateboarder/videographer Josh Friedberg and Steve Douglas as skateboarding's first ever video magazine. With segments which included branded industry spotlights, metrospective's, spot checks, contest highlights, amateur/pro sections, and more, this quarterly and later bi-monthly video magazine became an instant hit and forever changed the landscape of skateboard video formats.

name: Airspeed Shoes
description: Airspeed is a skate lifestyle footwear brand that was founded in 2002 by Bill Mann, who also created Airwalk Shoes. Bill founded Airspeed as a value-based brand after feeling that skate shoes were becoming too expensive for the average consumer. Airspeed's former and current list of team riders include Mike McGill, Brian Sumner, Kristian Svitak, Pat Washington, Rodd Marks and Nate Sherwood among others and is always growing. Airspeed shoes are available at Wal-Mart locations and the Airspeed online store.

name: Alpha Trucks
description: Alpha Trucks were created as the only skateboard trucks to include an anti wheel bite mechanism. Alpha found a way to eliminate wheel bite once and for all through a set of nylon locking screws set in the hanger.

name: Billabong
description: Billabong was founded on Australia's Gold Coast in 1973 by surfer and surfboard shaper Gordon Merchant and his partner. The business found immediate traction, with surfers drawn to the superior functionality of the Billabong boardshorts. In the 1990s, the company followed its core customers into other boardsports markets, including skate and snow, where it replicated its proven business model.

name: Animal Skateboards
description: ANIMAL Skateboards was founded in late 2012 by John Drake and two childhood friends. With John at the helm of art director, and by offering USA made decks, ANIMAL set out to create a company the Midwest and East Coast could represent and rally behind. And with a team of up-and-coming ams including Zay Belton, Jackson Davis and Ryan Strader, they are well on their way.

name: BBC Skateboards
description: BBC, originally known as Bad Bay Club (a division of Life's a Beach surfwear) and later known as Better Board Company was a skateboard company from the mid '80s to early '90s. BBC team riders included Jason Parkes, Monty Nolder, Jeff Phillips, Bill Danforth, Reese Simpson, Bryan Pennington and Jamie Mosberg to name a few.

name: ATF Clothing
description: ATF Clothing was a southern California based apparel brand which operated from the late 1990s to early 2000s. The name ATF was an acronym for All The Fundamentals. The brand primarily consisted of t-shirts but also produced cargo pants, nylon pants and other athletically inspired pieces which were popular in those days. Although ATF had a decent team the brand only lasted a few short years before closing up shop.

name: Adio Shoes
description: Adio Footwear was founded in 1998 by Chris Miller with an original superteam consisting of Tony Hawk, Steve Berra, Jamie Thomas and Jeremy Wray. Adio was operated by and distributed through Atlas Distribution, the makers of Planet Earth, Rhythm, Mercury, Tornado and Hawk, but at some time in the 2000s was sold to K2 Sports and licensed to the makers of Levi's and Polo footwear. And although Adio continues to produce shoes designed for skateboarding, in 2010 announced it would no longer endorse any team riders.

name: Autobahn Wheels
description: Autobahn Wheels was started by Doug Johnson and Jason Rogers in 2001 under the backing of Osiris. Named after the speed-limitless German freeways, Autobahn has kept peak performance at the heart of it's wheel designs. From their distinctive clear-cored duals to no flat-spot formulas, Autobahn's approach to wheel design is to create a more controlled experience.

name: A1 Meats
description: A-1 Meats was a wheel company that started in the late 1980s and was backed by Tracker Trucks. A-1 Meats made a little noise with the release of multiple early 90s videos, but was forced to throw in the towel around 1995. A-1 Meats team riders included Matt Hensley, Kris Markovich, Bo Ikeda, Laban Pheidias, Jeff King, Robert Douglas, Adrian Demain, Anthony Oglesby, John Sonner, Jason Dill, Chuck Wampler, Bo Ikeda, and Brandon Carabajal to name a few.

name: 101 Skateboards
description: In 1991, Natas Kaupas left SMA and co-founded 101 Skateboards along with Steve Rocco. 101 became an outlet for Natas to employ his graphic and artistic talents while still actively skating. 101 dropped some of the most groundbreaking videos of the early 1990s with team riders that included Natas Kaupas, Eric Koston, Adam McNatt, Clyde Singleton, Gino Iannucci, Jason Dill, Gabriel Rodriguez, Kris Markovich, Andy Stone, Leigh Peterson and Marcus McBride but eventually called it quits around 1997.

name: Arcade Skateboards
description: Arcade Skateboards was founded by Jason Rogers in the late 1990s under the financial backing of Osiris. Arcade went on to produce a few solid videos over the years, and in 2001 launched a sister company in Autobahn Wheels. But after the economy took a dive in around 2003 and Osiris began demanding budget cuts, Rogers took Arcade independently and formed The Egg Distribution. Unfortunately Rogers was forced to pull the plug on Arcade shortly after, but in 2010 decided to give the brand another chance.

name: 3D Skateboards
description: 3D Skateboards is a deck company that was founded by Brian Anderson in 2013. After over a decade with Girl, Brian saw 3D as a vehicle for his art/humor and as something he could call his very own. Brian brought along Austyn Gillette and also teamed up with his old friend Brad Staba to form Big Time Distribution.

name: 5boro Skateboards
description: Steve Rodriguez founded 5boro Skateboards in '96 as a NYC based skateboard design and manufacturing company. 5boro Skateboards was created by skaters for skaters who live for the streets.

name: American Dream, Inc.
description: American Dream, Inc. was a brand founded by Ron Allen and Alyasha Moore which set out to prove that anyone, including minorities could achieve the American dream through skateboarding. Also known as AD Unit, ADI tried teaching Americana history to every race through use of Black Panther/black empowerment imagery, and even went as far as running ads in Korean and Spanish. But once Deluxe pulled it's backing, Alyasha moved the brand to Brethren Distribution, the makers of Drawls & Stepson Clothing, at which point Alyasha ceased to offer any guidance or feedback on the brand. Alfred Hawkins then took over managing ADI for another year or so, but ultimately called it quits due to lack of sales.

name: Ambiguous Clothing
description: The story of Ambiguous, now known as Ambig Clothing first started in 1995. Combining influences from their skateboarding roots and inspiration from music, art and fashion, Ambig Clothing continues the support of a professional skate team and the art & music communities. Offering an artist collective organization called 4A "Ambiguous Addicted Artists Association", Ambig works closely with a variety of artists and photographers for various projects and limited edition releases. Since it's inception, Ambig Clothing has kept its authenticity and continues to strive to a high-level of execution; keeping the company small and focused.

name: Apollo Backpacks
description: Apollo Backpacks was founded by San Diego, Ca. based sales rep Patrick Keener in the late 1990s. What started in Patrick's garage quickly grew to include a full line of packs and boasted a team consisting of Stevie Williams, Brian Anderson, James Craig, Chad Fernandez, Paul Machnau, Forrest Kirby and Trainwreck to name a few. Unfortunately, Patrick burned one too many bridges within the industry and ultimately fled town forcing the end of Apollo.

name: Adrenalin Skateboards
description: Adrenalin Skateboards was founded by Jaya Bonderov and Chris Senn in 1995, but in 1997 the two felt they were being ripped off by the financial backer and canned the brand. In 2000, Mike Manzoori, Taos, Jon Minor and Chris Senn started Adrenalin back up on their own, but after Chris Senn quit the brand in 2004 it was scrapped shortly thereafter.

name: Birdhouse Skateboards
description: In 1992, Tony Hawk left Powell Peralta to start Birdhouse Projects with friend and ex-Powell pro Per Welinder. Birdhouse turned out their fair share of classic videos through the 1990s, with their crown jewel coming in the form of 98s The End video. The End was the first skate video to be filmed primarily on film rather than digital tapes, and significantly raised the bar for video production. In 2008, Tony Hawk acquired controlling interest in the company and moved it's distribution from Blitz to Eastern Skateboard Supply, and then again to Syndrome near the end of 2010.

name: Ammon Watches
description: Ammon Watches was an early 2010s watch company that offered high quality timepieces with a lifetime warranty. But unfortunately, that amazing lifetime warranty became null in void once the company folded a few years later. Ammon sponsored a few skaters including Corey Duffel and Jason Jessee.

name: Accel Wheels
description: Accel was a wheel brand founded by Mike Vallely in the year 2000. Accel team riders included Mike Vallely, Stacy Lowery, Danny Montoya, Kristian Svitak, Joey Pulsifer, Steffan Attardo, Brian Howard and Kyle Berard to name a few. Unfortunately, Accel never quite caught on and ended up calling it quits after a few short years.

name: Altamont Clothing
description: Altamont is an apparel line which brings together a diverse group of creative outcasts including skateboarders, musicians, artists and designers alike. In a short time, Altamont has carved out a niche for themselves through unique designs and an eye for detail. The name Altamont comes from San Francisco's Altamont Speedway which is most notably known for The Rolling Stones 1969 concert in which 4 people were killed. This event was seen by many as signaling the end of the Love Generation. Altamont was founded in part by Andrew Reynolds and is distributed through Sole Technology.

name: Bizo Shoes
description: Bizo was a completely random shoe companies that operated in the late 1990s. Their shoe silhouette's were pretty hideous and never saw or heard of any shops carrying them, so it's kind of a mystery how they lasted as long as they did. Bizo even went as far as to offer a free deck with shoe purchase and 6 month warranty, but nothing seemed to help create a demand. Bizo team riders included Ozzy Alvarez, Steve James, Leonard Crowley, Casper Friedl, Szabolcs Ocsai and Benjamin Bohaner.

name: Absolute Wheels
description: Absolute Wheels was founded in 1995 by Kevin Hurtado of Trust Skateboards. Absolute was distributed through Tum Yeto and included team riders Chad Muska, Ronnie Bertino, Ron Whaley, Paul Sharpe and Matt Mumford.

name: Artafact Skateboards
description: Artafact Skateboards was a deck company founded by Daewon Song at the end of 2002. Artafact rose from the ashes of Deca after feeling Deca needed a change. But less than a year into Artafact, Rodney Mullen left enjoi and got together with Daewon to launch Almost Skateboards in 2003.

name: Alva Skates
description: Alva Skates was founded in 1977 by Tony Alva, the first skateboarder to successfully market himself as a brand name. Alva was the first skater owned and operated brand and is still run and owned by Tony Alva today.

name: Active Ride Shop
description: Active Ride Shop started in 1989 as a single store location in Chino, California, but has since grown to include over 20 retail locations throughout the Southern California area. Active also produces a mail order catalog which they have been printing/mailing since 1999.

name: Addikt Skateboards
description: Addikt Skateboards is an underground brand which mocks corporate skateboarding and employs the tag line "Skater owned not corporate cloned".

name: 11th Hour
description: 11th Hour was a short lived company from the late 1990s to early 2000s.

name: 1031 Skateboards
description: 1031 Skateboards was founded by Kristian Svitak in 2006 and is distributed through Regulator Distribution.

name: Abec 11 Wheels
description: Abec 11 was started from a desire to develop high performance products for all types of skateboarding. Although Abec 11's primary focus is on carving and longboarding, they offer a wide variety of state-of-the-art, high quality urethane to meet most any skaters needs.

name: 151 Skateboards
description: 151 Skateboards was started in the late '90s and was distributed through Imperial Distribution.

name: Analog Clothing
description: Analog is a Burton backed clothing company which was born in outerwear, raised at the beach and entrenched in cities everywhere. Since the beginning of action sports, influential kids have gravitated towards progressive and creative movements within snowboarding, skateboarding and surfing. Analog stands as a testament to this and is an invitation to take a stand, make a point, challenge a value and open a few minds.

name: 900 Films
description: Formed in 1999 to develop television, home video and multimedia projects, 900 Films has produced numerous noteworthy projects. 900 Films has also collaborated on numerous feature films, including the Revolution Studios hit "XXX" and Warner Bros. "The Grind".

name: Bitch Skateboards
description: In 1993, Sal Rocco Jr.(Steve's brother) and his wife Kim started Bitch Skateboards after several riders defected from World, Plan B, Blind and 101 to start Girl. Bitch directly attacked Girl and it's riders through various graphics and ad campaigns. Although Bitch was backed by World, where Sal Rocco Jr. ran the shipping department, the brand quickly self destructed and was licensed to a Japanese firm. Today the Bitch name and logo can be found in Japan on everything from shoes to boogie boards and everything in-between.

name: 88 Footwear
description: 88 Footwear was a short lived shoe company that was started by Kris Markovich in 2002. Alias Distribution (the makers of Osiris) committed to a three year plan for supporting 88, but after the three years were up ceased to fund the brand. At that point, 88 found a new financial backer, changed it's name to Vox Footwear and was re-introduced. 88 Footwear team riders included Kris Markovich, Neil Blender, Justin Strubing, Corey Duffel, Kristian Svitak, Peter Hewitt, Adrian Mallory, Mark Gutterman, Peter Watkins and JT Aultz.

name: Black Box Distribution
description: Black Box Distribution was founded in 2000 by Jamie Thomas in order to independently house and distribute Zero Skateboards. In the fall of 2003, Black Box launched Mystery Skateboards and shortly after integrated Fallen Footwear, $lave Skateboards, Insight Clothing, Destroyer Pads and Mouse Grip. The goal of Black Box is to efficiently create, market and distribute quality skate products while supporting skateboarding on every level.

name: Bennett Trucks
description: In 1975 Mr. Bennett made skateboard history with the introduction of the very first trucks made specifically for a skateboard. Known for their big red bushings, precision components and amazing turning ability, Bennett Trucks quickly became the choice of most professional and amateur skateboarders. Bennett has re-introduced their iconic Vector Trucks and Alligator Wheels, while finalizing the development of the next generation of precision Bennett Skateboards.

name: Bike Skateboards
description: Bike Skateboards was a Southern California based brand that started in the early to mid '90s. In '96, Bike Skateboards changed it's name to Media Skateboards.

name: Bald Apparel
description: Bald was a clothing company founded by Pablo Cruz in 1994. Bald was based out of La Jolla, California and included team riders Donny Barley, Andy Macdonald, Jamin Garrick, Kenta Iijiama and Quetzel Aguilar.

name: Ashbury Sunglasses
description: Ashbury Eyewear was founded in downtown Los Angeles, Ca. in 2007 as the manufacturer of quality sunglasses, goggles and apparel. Ashbury products are made using only the best possible materials and the highest quality manufacturing, including Carl Zeiss lenses to ensure the clearest, highest quality vision possible. Ashbury's timeless designs are currently distributed worldwide in finer boutiques and shops around the globe.

name: Bern Helmets
description: Bern is a brand which specializes in action sport head protection, pads and apparel for the skateboard, ski, snowboard, bike, kayak and wakeboard communities. The Bern line offers a wide variety of designs for men, women, boys and girls alike. Bern skate team riders include Andy Macdonald, Tom Knox, Jeff Grosso, Mike Rogers, Jake Reuter, Nora, Vasconcellos, Kevin Miranda, Noah Beschen and Faye Middleton amongst others.
